ACCT1501.title: Accounting and Financial Management 1A
ACCT1501.description: The compulsory core accounting unit will have a preparer perspective.
ACCT1501.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT1511.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT2507.description: This course provides an introduction to accounting research.

ACCT2522.description: This course examines management accounting practices directed towards the effective use of organisational resources in order to create value for customers and shareholders.
ACCT2522.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT2542.title: Corporate Financial Reporting and Analysis
ACCT2542.description: This intermediate financial accounting course is intended for students who will be involved in the preparation or use of corporate financial reports whether as accountants, financial executives, auditors, financial analysts, actuaries or legal advisors.
ACCT2542.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT2672.title: Accounting Analytics for Business Decision Making
ACCT2672.description: This course is concerned with developing students' analytical mindset.
ACCT2672.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3202.title: Industry Placement 2
ACCT3202.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the fundamental principles of accounting in an industry environment.
ACCT3202.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3303.description: It is the third of three fully assessable Industry Training courses Co-op Scholars complete as part of their Bachelor of Commerce (Co-op) degree.
ACCT3303.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3563.description: Building on the foundation laid in ACCT2542, this course covers controversial issues in financial reporting, for example leases, sharebased payments, extractive industries, biological assets,foreign currency transactions, diversified operations, and derivative financial instruments.
ACCT3563.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3583.title: Management Accounting 2
ACCT3583.description: This course explores the link between management accounting information and strategic issues.
ACCT3583.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3601.title: Global Financial Reporting and Analysis
ACCT3601.description: With the increasing globalisation of business and capital markets, there is a more extensive use of cross-border financial information.
ACCT3601.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3610.title: Business Analysis and Valuation
ACCT3610.description: This course is about the analysis of financial information arising primarily from the financial reports of entities.
ACCT3610.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3625.title: Integrated Reporting, Integrated Thinking and Value Creation
ACCT3625.description: This course is concerned with how organisations create and preserve value over time employing effective business models and a broader range of resources (capitals) than in conventional analyses.
ACCT3625.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT3708.title: Auditing and Assurance Services
ACCT3708.description: This course examines the practice of auditing and the underlying concepts, auditors responsibilities and the audit environment.
ACCT3708.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT4796.title: Thesis (Accounting) A

ACCT4797.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.

ACCT4798.title: Thesis (Accounting) C
ACCT4798.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.
ACCT4798.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT4809.title: Current Developments in Auditing Research
ACCT4809.description: ?Current Developments in Auditing Research is designed to extend disciplinary perspectives in auditing and provide training for research in auditing and assurance services.
ACCT4809.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT4851.title: Current Developments in Accounting Research - Financial
ACCT4851.description: Review of alternative approaches to the development of theories in external reporting.
ACCT4851.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACCT4852.title: Current Developments in Accounting Research - Managerial
ACCT4852.description: The aim of this course is to equip students with a comprehensive understanding of contemporary management accounting research, which emanates from different philosophical perspectives and employs different theories and research methods.

ACCT4897.title: Seminar in Research Methodology
ACCT4897.description: To assist BCom Hons students in completion of research project requirement.
ACCT4897.school: School of Accounting, Auditing and Taxation

ACTL1101.title: Introduction to Actuarial Studies
ACTL1101.description: This course is designed to provide an introduction to actuarial studies.
ACTL1101.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL2100.title: Industrial Training 1 (Co-op)
ACTL2100.description: Please Note: Co-op students are not liable for tuition fee charges for this course.

ACTL2101.title: Industry Placement 1
ACTL2101.description: The main aims of this course is to provide the Scholars with practical experience in Actuarial Studies that complements their academic studies, and to give Sponsors enthusiastic and talented young achievers who may wish to work with them upon graduation.
ACTL2101.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL2102.title: Foundations of Actuarial Models
ACTL2102.description: This course introduces the stochastic models used by actuaries to model both liabilities and assets and illustrates their applications in actuarial work.
ACTL2102.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL2111.title: Financial Mathematics for Actuaries
ACTL2111.description: This course develops the financial mathematics required for the analysis of financial and insurance transactions.
ACTL2111.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL2131.title: Probability and Mathematical Statistics
ACTL2131.description: This course covers probability and statistics topics relevant to actuarial studies.
ACTL2131.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3141.title: Actuarial Models and Statistics
ACTL3141.description: This course covers survival models, their estimation and application to mortality and other decrements.
ACTL3141.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3142.title: Actuarial Data and Analysis
ACTL3142.description: This course covers the actuarial professional syllabus for data analysis including techniques for mortality, health, and insurance data used in actuarial analysis and decision-making.
ACTL3142.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3151.title: Life Contingencies
ACTL3151.description: This course covers the techniques for deriving the value for pricing and reserving purposes of life insurance risks, including an appreciation of the analysis of change on the examination of the assumptions.
ACTL3151.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3162.title: General Insurance Techniques
ACTL3162.description: This course covers the actuarial mathematics, statistics and models used in non-life insurance actuarial practice.
ACTL3162.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3182.title: Asset-Liability and Derivative Models
ACTL3182.description: This course is to provide students with an appreciation of the mathematical and economic models of investment markets and highlight their application (and shortcomings) in asset-liability management for insurance, superannuation and funds management and in the pricing of derivatives.
ACTL3182.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3191.title: Superannuation and Retirement Benefits
ACTL3191.description: This course provides a comprehensive analysis of the economics and finance of retirement income provision.
ACTL3191.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3192.title: Retirement Saving and Spending Over the Lifecycle
ACTL3192.description: This course examines saving and spending decisions by individuals and households over the lifecycle in the context of national retirement savings and incomes policies.
ACTL3192.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3202.title: Industry Placement 2
ACTL3202.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the  principles of actuarial studies in an industry environment.
ACTL3202.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL3303.title: Industry Placement 3
ACTL3303.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the principles of actuarial studies in an industry environment.
ACTL3303.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4001.title: Actuarial Theory and Practice A
ACTL4001.description: This course develops the theory and practice underlying the actuarial management of risk-based and other products offered by financial institutions.
ACTL4001.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4002.title: Actuarial Theory and Practice B
ACTL4002.description: This course develops the theory and practice underlying the actuarial management of risk-based and other products offered by financial institutions.
ACTL4002.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4003.title: Research Methods in Risk and Actuarial Studies
ACTL4003.description: This course is designed as a research methods course for research students in the areas of actuarial modelling in insurance risk, general insurance, life insurance, superannuation, and financial economics.
ACTL4003.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4010.title: Thesis (Actuarial Studies) A
ACTL4010.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.
ACTL4010.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4011.title: Thesis (Actuarial Studies) B
ACTL4011.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.
ACTL4011.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4012.title: Thesis (Actuarial Studies) C
ACTL4012.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.
ACTL4012.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ACTL4301.title: Models for Risk Management
ACTL4301.description: This course explores quantitative methods of risk measurement and modelling in financial institutions, including insurers, reinsurers, superannuation funds, and banks, and the major types of risks encountered therein.

ACTL4302.title: Risk and Capital Management
ACTL4302.description: This course covers the motivations and techniques for risk and capital management in financial institutions, including insurers, reinsurers, superannuation funds, and banks and the major types of risks encountered.

ACTL4303.title: Asset-Liability Management
ACTL4303.description: This course covers the knowledge, skills and judgement necessary to understand investment and asset liability modelling with an emphasis on practical issues.

ACTL4305.title: Actuarial Data Analytic Applications
ACTL4305.description: This course covers the actuarial professional associateship syllabus for the data analytics process.
ACTL4305.school: School of Risk and Actuarial Studies

ADAD0600.title: Transmedia Storytelling Studio
ADAD0600.description: Transmedia storytelling is the practice of designing, sharing, and participating in a cohesive story experience across multiple traditional and digital delivery platforms - for entertainment, advertising and marketing, or social change.
ADAD0600.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD1001.title: Studio Gateway 1
ADAD1001.description: This course introduces you to studio practice in contemporary Art, Media and Design.
ADAD1001.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD1002.title: Studio Gateway 2
ADAD1002.description: Studio Gateway 2 introduces you to studio practice in contemporary Art, Media and Design.
ADAD1002.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD1100.title: Communication in Art, Design and Media
ADAD1100.description:
Are you a good Art, Design and Media communicator?
Communication underpins the success of Art, Design and Media practice.
ADAD1100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD2400.title: Introduction to Systems for Interactive Media
ADAD2400.description: In this course students will be introduced to algorithms and the basics of programming interactive systems for artists and designers.
ADAD2400.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD2402.description: This course explores how we can interact with electronic media, through the creation of bespoke physical interfaces and works that go beyond the conventions of the keyboard and mouse - to open up new ways of experiencing, and interacting with digital media, and worlds around and within us.
ADAD2402.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD2610.title: Art and Design for Environmental Challenges
ADAD2610.description: The nature and complexity of 21st century environmental challenges are unprecedented in their urgency and potential consequences for human societies and the natural environment.
ADAD2610.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD3114.title: Research Foundations in Art and Design
ADAD3114.description: Practitioners in the creative industries increasingly articulate the value of their practice in relation to research frameworks.
ADAD3114.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD3400.title: Interactive Installation
ADAD3400.description: This studio-based subject explores the transformation of electronic media from a static entity to a dynamic and responsive component of the environment.
ADAD3400.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD3402.title: Interactive Generative Visualisations
ADAD3402.description: Live generative visualisations can commonly be seen at live VJDJ events, often as a set of predefined parameters and as responsive scenography on stage or in museums and galleries.
ADAD3402.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD4000.title: Professional Experience Project A
ADAD4000.description: Professional Experience A is a flexible 'capstone' course which provides students studying Fine Art, Media Art or Design with an opportunity to work in the creative industries relevant to their studies and apply their academic knowledge in the workplace.

ADAD4001.description: Professional Experience B allows students studying Fine Art, Media Art or Design an opportunity to extend the professional contact time of Professional Experience Project A by an additional 150 hours.
ADAD4001.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD4010.title: Honours Research Project A
ADAD4010.description: Honours Research Project A requires students in the BFA (Hons), BMA (Hons) and BDes (Hons) to plan and undertake a research project into an issue, topic or area of art and design, and complete studio work along with appropriate documentation.
ADAD4010.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD4011.title: Honours Research Project B
ADAD4011.description: Honours Research Project B requires students in the BFA (Hons), BMA (Hons) and BDes (Hons) to plan and undertake a research project into an issue, topic or area of art and design, and complete both studio work and a written component.
ADAD4011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ADAD4100.title: Honours Professional Experience Program
ADAD4100.description: This course will prepare students to pursue a full-time creative career and develop into versatile artists, designers, thinkers and creative practitioners that work in a constantly shifting design, arts and media arts landscape.
ADAD4100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

AERO3110.title: Aerospace Design 1
AERO3110.description: This course aims to provide students with a grounding in aerospace design, in terms of both structural design and systems design.
AERO3110.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO3410.title: Aerospace Structures
AERO3410.description: This course covers introductory and intermediate topics related to analysis and design of airframes:Aerospace Materials and their PropertiesLightweight Materials - Alloys and CompositesTensors - Stress, Strain, InvariantsFailure PredictionMaterial Degradation - Fatigue, Corrosion, WearAnalysis of Composite MaterialsClassical Airframe AnalysisAirframe LoadsStressed Skin Design PhilosophyRole of Airframe ComponentsThin-walled ApproximationStructural IdealisationAnalysis of Indeterminate TrussesBending, Shear and Torsion of Complex BeamsDetailed Stressing - Joints and Cut-outsStructural Instability and AeroelasticityBuckling of Columns and PlatesStiffened Panel Analysis and DesignAeroelasticity - Divergence, Control Reversal and Flutter.
AERO3410.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO3630.title: Aerodynamics
AERO3630.description: The overall aim of this course is to introduce students to the art and science of aerodynamics: how fluid motion generates the forces and moments on air vehicles required for flight.
AERO3630.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO3660.title: Flight Performance and Propulsion
AERO3660.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO4110.title: Aerospace Design 2
AERO4110.description: This course is a capstone aerospace design project.
AERO4110.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO4120.title: Aerospace Design Project B

AERO4120.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO4500.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO4620.title: Dynamics of Aerospace Vehicles, Systems and Avionics
AERO4620.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO9500.title: Space Systems Architectures and Orbits
AERO9500.description: This course paints the overall picture of what a satellite system is.
AERO9500.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO9610.title: The Space Segment
AERO9610.description: This course gives the students a basis in the design issues involved in the engineering of the space segment in order to enable to fulfil the mission.
AERO9610.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AERO9660.title: Advanced Aerospace Propulsion
AERO9660.description:
This course aims to enable you to:
gain a deeper appreciation of gas turbine operation and to make high-level predictions of gas turbine behavior in various flight scenarios.
AERO9660.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

ANAT1521.title: Anatomy for Medical Science
ANAT1521.description: Introduction to the topographical anatomy of the whole human body, based on the study of prosected human specimens.

ANAT2111.title: Introductory Anatomy
ANAT2111.description: Introduction to the topographical anatomy of the whole human body, based on the study of prosected human specimens.

ANAT2241.title: Histology: Basic and Systematic
ANAT2241.description: Introduction to the microscopic anatomy of the human body based on the study of virtual histological images.

ANAT2341.title: Embryology: Early and Systematic Development
ANAT2341.description: Students completing this course will have a broad understanding of human development, and they will be introduced to some animal models of development and to cutting-edge developmental biology research.

ANAT2451.title: Functional Anatomy for Health and Exercise Science
ANAT2451.description: This course covers the musculoskeletal anatomy of the human trunk, lower limb and upper limb in relation to its function in movement.

ANAT2511.title: Fundamentals of Anatomy
ANAT2511.description: This course is intended for students who require a knowledge of anatomy but do not intend to pursue further anatomical study.

ANAT2521.title: Evolution of Human Structure
ANAT2521.description: This course introduces students to biological anthropology, the scientific discipline that deals with the adaptations, variability, and evolution of human beings and their living and fossil relatives.

ANAT3121.title: Visceral Anatomy
ANAT3121.description: This course will provide you with an understanding of the functional and clinical anatomy of the viscera of the thorax, abdomen and pelvis.

ANAT3131.title: Functional Anatomy of the Head, Neck and Back
ANAT3131.description: You will gain an understanding of functional and clinically-relevant anatomy of the head, neck and back regions of the human body.

ANAT3141.title: Functional Anatomy of the Limbs
ANAT3141.description: This course follows on from ANAT2111 and ANAT2511 and complements the other level III anatomy courses (ANAT3121 and ANAT3131).

ANAT3212.title: Microscopy in Research
ANAT3212.description: This is an advanced course in microscopy, which provides practical, research-oriented experience.

ANAT3231.title: Cell Biology
ANAT3231.description: Cell Biology has broad applications to medical and basic science research.

ANAT3411.title: Neuroanatomy
ANAT3411.description: Neuroanatomy is an advanced neuroscience course that provides students with an understanding of the development, structure, function and vascular supply of the spinal cord, brainstem and forebrain.

ARCH0006.title: Special Program (Architecture)

ARCH1080.title: Introduction to Architecture and Enabling Skills

ARCH1080.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1162.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1201.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1202.title: Architectural Design Studio 4
ARCH1202.description: This studio focuses on the design of adaptable, dynamic built spaces and landscapes on a dramatic Sydney foreshore site with industrial heritage.

ARCH1203.title: Architectural Design Studio 4
ARCH1203.description: This studio focuses on the design of adaptable, dynamic built spaces and landscapes on a dramatic Sydney foreshore site with indigenous and industrial heritage.
ARCH1203.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1261.title: Construction and Structures 2

ARCH1261.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1302.title: Architectural Design Studio 6
ARCH1302.description: The concern of this studio is with how multiple environmental, technological and social factors influence architectural thinking and production.
ARCH1302.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1311.title: Architectural Design Studio 5

ARCH1311.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1322.title: Architectural History and Theory 3

ARCH1322.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1331.title: Architectural Fabrication

ARCH1331.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1361.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1394.title: Honours Research Project 1
ARCH1394.description: The Architectural Research Project 1 explores the idea of research as it relates to a series of design requirements related to the built environment.

ARCH1481.title: Critical Review of Literature
ARCH1481.description: This course is a major research-based investigation into a subject related to the student’s area of specialisation.
ARCH1481.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH1482.title: Research Methods
ARCH1482.description: This course introduces students to architectural research in a general sense: its methodologies, its challenges and its organization, including those used in design research.

ARCH1483.title: Honours Thesis
ARCH1483.description: This course is a major research-based investigation into a subject related to the student’s area of specialisation.
ARCH1483.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARCH2170.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1010.title: The Life of Words
ARTS1010.description: This course will examine the form of the short story.
ARTS1010.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1010.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1011.description: What does it mean to write about ourselves in an age of reality hunger, with genres such as autofiction and memoir proliferating, and with social media providing everyone with a public profile? If print culture of the Gutenberg era has given way to digital culture of the Google era, this has only increased the amount of text that we are immersed in.
ARTS1011.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1030.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1030.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1031.title: Reading Through Time
ARTS1031.description: This course will develop your skills in English through a focused introduction to the development of English literature in time and place.
ARTS1031.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1031.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1032.description: This introductory course challenges you to think about writing as experimental, world-building, adventurous, challenging, radical, and even dangerous, and to write as though it can change the way things are.

ARTS1032.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1060.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1062.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1063.title: World Cinemas: Transnational Perspectives
ARTS1063.description: This course introduces you to a world of cinemas.

Subject Area: Film Studies

ARTS1064.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1090.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

Subject Area: Media, Culture and Technology

ARTS1091.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1091.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1092.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1092.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1120.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1120.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

Subject Area: Theatre and Performance Studies

Performance is the practice that brings creativity to life.
ARTS1121.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS1121.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1190.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1240.title: Environment and Society

ARTS1241.description: Environmental Advocacy and Activism offers you an opportunity to examine how environmental politics play out within society.

ARTS1270.title: Global History: Exploring the First Globalization, 15th-19th Century
ARTS1270.description: How did the modern world happen? How did a few small countries in Europe (and later the United States) come to dominate so much of the world’s wealth and power by 1900? How did they displace the great empires of the Middle East, South Asia and China? Between 1400 and the beginning of the twentieth century, an astonishing, global revolution took place.
ARTS1270.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1271.title: History of the Present: The World since 1900
ARTS1271.description: Today, news headlines are dominated by the rise of populist leaders like Donald Trump, by stories of ethnic and racial tensions, political violence, war and conflict.
ARTS1271.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1360.title: Truth and Human Existence: Introduction to Philosophy
ARTS1360.description: This course addresses core philosophical questions about knowledge, reality, and human existence.
ARTS1360.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1361.title: Mind, Ethics, and Freedom: Introduction to Philosophy
ARTS1361.description: Philosophy examines the fundamental presuppositions of every area of human life and inquiry.
ARTS1361.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1362.title: Critical Thinking for Today's World
ARTS1362.description: Critical Thinking is a skill that allows you to evaluate, analyse and synthesise information gathered by observation, experience, reflection and communication.
ARTS1362.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1450.title: Introductory Chinese A for Non-Background Students
ARTS1450.description: This is an introductory course in Modern Standard Chinese language (Mandarin) for non-background speakers.

ARTS1453.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1480.title: Introductory French A
ARTS1480.description: The French-speaking world represents one of the biggest linguistic zones in the world with an estimated 274 million French-speakers on all five continents.
ARTS1480.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1481.title: Introductory French B
ARTS1481.description: The French-speaking world represents one of the biggest linguistic zones in the world with an estimated 274 million French-speakers on all 5 continents.
ARTS1481.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1510.title: Introductory German A
ARTS1510.description: If you are interested in learning the most commonly spoken first language in Europe and have no prior knowledge of the German language, then Introductory German A is the right course for you.
ARTS1510.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1511.title: Introductory German B
ARTS1511.description: Introductory German B follows the successful completion of the Introductory German A course or an equivalent language level course offered through other institutions.
ARTS1511.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1540.title: Introductory Greek A
ARTS1540.description: The Greek language, however intricate, is more than yet another foreign language; it is the key to unlocking a great culture that is the backbone of our modern civilization.
ARTS1540.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1541.title: Introductory Greek B
ARTS1541.description: This course is a continuation of Introductory Greek A which is a pre-requisite, unless you who have otherwise acquired a basic knowledge of reading, writing and speaking Greek.
ARTS1541.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1570.title: Introductory Spanish A
ARTS1570.description: Spanish is the language of over four hundred million people.

ARTS1571.title: Introductory Spanish B

ARTS1571.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1620.title: Introductory Italian A
ARTS1620.description: Introductory Italian A will be perfect for you if you have no (or almost no) previous knowledge of the language.
ARTS1620.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1621.description: Knowing Italian means having access to: a cultural heritage that is of prime importance in European history and culture, and through immigration also to Australia.
ARTS1621.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1630.description: The course introduces the Japanese sound system, basic greetings as well as a number of basic Japanese structures and vocabulary expressed in Hiragana and Katakana syllabaries that are essential to basic Japanese communication.
ARTS1630.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1631.title: Introductory Japanese B
ARTS1631.description: The course follows 'Introductory Japanese A' and further introduces a number of basic Japanese structures and vocabulary that are essential to basic Japanese communication.
ARTS1631.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1660.title: Introductory Korean A
ARTS1660.description: This course provides introductory level tuition in Korean language from a communicative and task-based approach.
ARTS1660.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1661.title: Introductory Korean B
ARTS1661.description: This course provides introductory level tuition in Korean language from a communicative and task-based approach.
ARTS1661.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1690.title: The Structure of Language
ARTS1690.description: This course is an introduction to linguistics (the scientific study of language) and focuses on the traditional core areas of language structure including: the sound system (phonetics and phonology), morphology (word structure), syntax (clause and sentence structure), and meaning (semantics and pragmatics).
ARTS1690.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1691.title: The Use of Language
ARTS1691.description: You will examine how contemporary linguists address issues of language use.
ARTS1691.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1750.title: Introduction to Global Development
ARTS1750.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1753.title: Culture, Experience and Change
ARTS1753.description: Do you want to understand cultural experience? This interdisciplinary social science gateway course equips you with foundational knowledge in anthropology, sociology and development studies that will help you to understand some of the key social challenges, the world is grappling with such as power and inequality, human security, human mobility, human rights, and globalisation.
ARTS1753.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1780.title: Concepts of Europe
ARTS1780.description: What is Europe? How has it been conceived over the centuries and how have these conceptions changed? How have these concepts shaped ongoing controversies over Europe, its significance, its aspirations, its shortcomings? In this course you will learn about key concepts, institutions, and movements informing modern Europe's self-understanding.
ARTS1780.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1782.title: Contemporary Europe in Crisis: Power and Culture
ARTS1782.description: Contemporary Europe in Crisis: Power and Culture explores the unprecedented challenges facing contemporary Europe, through academic analysis, political commentary, film and novels.
ARTS1782.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1810.title: Foundations of Politics and International Relations
ARTS1810.description: Where does power lie in politics? Whose explanations about how the world works are valued and why? This course will equip you with some of the skills necessary to begin formulating your own answers to these questions.
ARTS1810.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1811.title: Contemporary Issues in Government and Global Politics
ARTS1811.description: This course investigates some of the most significant issues facing the world today such as the recurrence of violence between and within countries; the difficulty of lifting large numbers of people out of poverty; what is to happen to people who do not have a home in any country; increasing environmental destruction; intensifying global financial instability; and whether the current structures and processes of governance are adequate to address these issues.
ARTS1811.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1846.title: Politics, Peace and Prosperity
ARTS1846.description: Why are some countries more peaceful and prosperous than others? And how, and to what extent, are peace and prosperity related? In this course you will critically examine these questions, with a particular focus on the concept of political development and the role of the state in promoting prosperity and peace.
ARTS1846.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1870.title: Rethinking the Social
ARTS1870.description: This course is an introduction to sociological and anthropological perspectives on the nature of the social.
ARTS1870.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS1900.title: Gendered Worlds: Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies
ARTS1900.description: Subject Area: Women's and Gender Studies.
ARTS1900.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2020.title: Creative Writing
ARTS2020.description: The aim of this course is to familiarise you with a wide range of contemporary literature and to encourage you to experiment with a variety of different styles and genres in your own writing.
ARTS2020.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2020.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2021.title: Creative Writing Project
ARTS2021.description: This workshop-based course gives you the opportunity to develop a major creative work in fiction, poetry, memoir, play or screenwriting.
ARTS2021.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2021.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2031.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2031.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2033.title: Poetry and Poetics
ARTS2033.description:
Subject Area: English
This course can also be studied in the following specialisations: Creative Writing
What is poetry? How do we know a poem when we see it, and why is poetry the most moving, the most challenging, and the most memorable of literary forms? In this course you will read a range of accomplished and influential poems in a variety of genres, from biting satires, through ravishing love poems, to recent experiments in digital poetry.
ARTS2033.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2033.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2034.title: Shakespearean Drama
ARTS2034.description: The course is an opportunity for you to enjoy and understand Shakespeare's tremendous achievement in the theatre.
ARTS2034.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2034.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2035.title: American Literature: Past and Present
ARTS2035.description: This course provides a rich survey of the major movements and dynamics of American literature, situating some of the most significant works of American prose and poetry within historical and social frameworks.
ARTS2035.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2035.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2036.title: Modernism: Text and Screen
ARTS2036.description: This course introduces you to the wave of experimentation in the arts that we have come to call modernism.
ARTS2036.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2036.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2040.title: Global Literatures: Adventures with the "Contemporary Classic"
ARTS2040.description:
When we read contemporary literature, how do we know what is valuable, good or lasting?  Do we immediately recognise a "classic" work by its scope, complexity and challenge or its daring, beauty or dissidence?  How and why does the "classic" text emerge in the present?  Though "contemporary classic" sounds like a pitch used by publishers, is this a term that might enable discussion of rich and compelling literary works from the last thirty years?
The group of contemporary literary works that we might call "classic" is an intensely global one.
ARTS2040.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2040.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2041.title: What is Reading?
ARTS2041.description: This course explores the nature of reading over a range of periods and literary contexts, from the Renaissance to the present-day.
ARTS2041.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2041.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2050.title: Academic Writing for the Humanities
ARTS2050.description: This course develops students’ capacity to write academic essays according to the conventions of the Humanities.
ARTS2050.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2050.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2061.title: Contemporary Approaches to Cinema
ARTS2061.description: This course introduces students to some of the key debates in contemporary film theory from the 1970s to the present.

ARTS2063.school: School of the Arts and Media

ARTS2064.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2065.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2066.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2066.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2092.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2092.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2093.description: This course draws on contemporary theoretical and empirical work from the fields of media and social semiotics to explore new media practices across social media platforms.

ARTS2093.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2094.description: Visual communication in contemporary media typically combines a range of resources - written, visual, aural, spatial.
ARTS2094.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2094.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2095.title: Digital Technologies and the Self
ARTS2095.description: This course explores the ways that digital media and technologies shape our collective and individual understandings of ‘the self’.
ARTS2095.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2095.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2096.title: Media Rights, Media Wrongs
ARTS2096.description: Human rights and social justice are central to contemporary public life and as such they are central to media practices and representations.
ARTS2096.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2096.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2120.title: Writing for Performance
ARTS2120.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2120.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2121.title: Theatre in Our Times
ARTS2121.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2121.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2122.description: From page to stage – how do theatre-makers take a play script into production? This practical studio-based course gives you the authentic experience of working as a theatre-maker in the performing arts.
ARTS2122.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2122.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2123.description: This is a course about popular performance in contemporary culture.
ARTS2123.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2123.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2125.title: Acting and Performing
ARTS2125.description: What are actors doing when they perform? Why do actors build characters and engage spectators in such different ways? How does acting embody beliefs about the world and who we are? There are many styles of acting and experienced actors draw on various techniques.
ARTS2125.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2125.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2126.title: Reviewing the Arts
ARTS2126.description: Reviewers and arts journalists play a crucial role in the arts.
ARTS2126.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2126.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2127.description: What makes a play great? Why are some plays re-staged and re-interpreted by each new generation? Great Plays will develop your skills in reading canonical plays written for live performance.
ARTS2127.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2127.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2128.title: Art and Social Change
ARTS2128.description: Artistic strategies provide powerful means of making social and political messages heard by a wider audience.
ARTS2128.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2128.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2129.title: Cultural Performance and Digital Cultures: Creative Production in Metro Manila
ARTS2129.description: Creativity today is part of a global network.
ARTS2129.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS2129.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2150.title: The Making of Trump's America
ARTS2150.description: The election of Donald Trump to the United States presidency highlights gaping rifts in the society and politics of the contemporary United States.
ARTS2150.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2210.title: Modern India: Violence and Nonviolence in Colonial South Asia, 1750-1947
ARTS2210.description: In this course you will study the history of British colonialism and the movement for independence in India, focussing on the key question: if the struggle for freedom in India was conducted along Gandhian lines according to the principles of non-violence, then how can we understand the extent of violence that accompanied decolonisation, in 1947? The course answers this question by moving beyond the dominant tropes of the British Raj, replete with civilising missions, bejewelled maharajas and tiger hunts, to present a critical interrogation of colonial dynamics, demonstrating the relationships between imperial oppression, anti-colonial violence and Gandhian nonviolence, which culminated in the independence of India and the creation of East and West Pakistan, in 1947.
ARTS2210.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2211.title: East Asia
ARTS2211.description: This course focuses on interactions among China, Korea, and Japan; their relations with the West; and the issue of culture and civilization in the post-nation-state era.
ARTS2211.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2212.title: Southeast Asia
ARTS2212.description: The course focuses on modern Southeast Asia since the end of the colonial period until the present day.
ARTS2212.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2213.title: Asian Popular Culture
ARTS2213.description: Asia’s rapidly changing social and political context is contributing to the dynamic development of popular culture.
ARTS2213.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2240.title: Environment, Sustainability and Development
ARTS2240.description: Human society has experienced remarkable change as technological innovation, economic growth and population have produced rapidly changing social and environmental landscapes over the past current centuries.
ARTS2240.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2242.title: The Politics of Climate Change
ARTS2242.description: Climate change is often understood as primarily a scientific or environmental problem that requires economic or technological solutions.
ARTS2242.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2243.title: Waste and Society
ARTS2243.description: This course introduces you to the historical, social and cultural implications of the wastes generated by human society.
ARTS2243.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2244.title: Rethinking Wildlife: Philosophy, Biodiversity, Extinction
ARTS2244.description: In this course you will explore philosophical and political issues in wildlife conservation from a range of disciplinary perspectives.
ARTS2244.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2247.title: Indigenous People and the Environment
ARTS2247.description:
Subject Area: Environmental HumanitiesThis course can also be studied in the following specialisation: Australian Studies
This course focuses on the complex intersection between Indigenous people and the natural environment.

ARTS2248.title: Disasters and Society
ARTS2248.description: Increases in disasters along with the current and future predicted impacts of climate change has meant that disaster management and disaster risk reduction have emerged as a key project and policy areas.
ARTS2248.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2249.title: Environmental Philosophy
ARTS2249.description: This course examines influential theories of nature and the environment in philosophy and a range of interdisciplinary writings, from Aristotle to the present.
ARTS2249.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2270.title: Australia 1788-1900: Invasion to White Australia
ARTS2270.description: Controversies regularly erupt in Australia over issues where identity and justice intersect: who should be granted asylum? how can the rights of Indigenous peoples be fully respected? how should Australia relate to Asia? In this course you will explore how these issues were fostered by the major themes of Australia’s 19th century history: the settler revolution, Indigenous dispossession and resistance, and the rise of scientific racism on the one hand; movements towards democracy, universal education and better living standards on the other.
ARTS2270.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2271.title: Inventing Modern Australia: 1900 to Now
ARTS2271.description: Ever needed to understand the country you live in now? This course examines Australia from the earliest moments of the twentieth century to today, and asks you to think about how Australia’s peoples have imagined, devised, fought for, struggled against and debated their world.
ARTS2271.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2272.title: The European World, 1500-1800
ARTS2272.description: The European world, 1500-1800 is an introductory course to early-modern history.
ARTS2272.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2278.title: Slavery and Freedom: US History 1750-1890
ARTS2278.description: This course explores the interrelation of economic change, social structure, cultural life and politics from the origins of the American Revolution to the aftermath of the end of slavery.
ARTS2278.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2281.title: Ancient Egypt and Western Asia
ARTS2281.description: This course explores the origins and evolution of ancient Egyptian and West Asian civilizations from the Neolithic Revolution to the Achaemenid Persian Empire that conquered Egypt in the sixth century BCE.
ARTS2281.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2282.title: Rome
ARTS2282.description: This course traces the rise of Rome from a small city-state to the largest power in the Mediterranean world.
ARTS2282.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2283.title: Classical Greece
ARTS2283.description: This course explores the dynamic, diverse, and troubled civilization of Greece during the Bronze, Archaic, and Classical eras (circa 1200-323 BC).
ARTS2283.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2285.title: The Holocaust: Origins, Implementation, Aftermath
ARTS2285.description: You will be introduced to the history of the Nazi destruction of the European Jews during the Second World War.
ARTS2285.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2303.title: On Drugs: Industry, Science and Medicine since 1900
ARTS2303.description: Drugs are powerful forces of change.
ARTS2303.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2360.title: Knowledge and Reality
ARTS2360.description: Nothing is more human than to think that reality gives us knowledge.
ARTS2360.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2361.title: Philosophy of Mind and Psychology
ARTS2361.description: What is a mind? Is the conscious self an entity distinct from the body (a soul)? Or is it nothing more than the brain? This course begins by considering these and other foundational questions about the mind and its place in nature.
ARTS2361.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2362.title: Alienation and Social Critique
ARTS2362.description: This course asks how a society can legitimately criticise itself.
ARTS2362.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2363.title: Chinese Philosophy
ARTS2363.description: In this course, you will study Confucianism and Daoism (Taoism), philosophies which originated from China and which continue to influence thinking and practices in China and beyond.
ARTS2363.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2374.title: Ways of Reasoning
ARTS2374.description: The understanding we have of our nature as reasoning beings is a fascinating topic which has captivated thinkers for thousands of years.
ARTS2374.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2375.title: Philosophical Logic
ARTS2375.description: Logic is a wonderful achievement of the human mind.
ARTS2375.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2382.title: Philosophy of Religion: Defenders and Critics
ARTS2382.description: In this course, you will study key ideas in philosophy of religion including: conceptions of deity, cosmos, life and death, human society, the natural environment, human action, and ritual and ethical practices.
ARTS2382.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2383.title: Ethics: Theory and Practice
ARTS2383.description: In this course you will consider some of the most pressing practical ethical issues faced by society and by individual people in their everyday lives.
ARTS2383.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2384.title: Political Philosophy
ARTS2384.description: The course provides you with a solid foundation in political philosophy by means of close readings of central texts by thinkers such as Thomas Hobbes, John Locke and Hannah Arendt.
ARTS2384.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2450.title: Intermediate Chinese for Non-Background Speakers A
ARTS2450.description: This course is designed for students who have acquired a basic level of spoken Chinese (Mandarin) and a working knowledge of up to six hundred simplified characters in their first year of study, as well as for those students who enter the Chinese language program with an equivalent knowledge of Chinese characters.
ARTS2450.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2451.title: Intermediate Chinese for Non-Background Speakers B
ARTS2451.description: This course is designed for students who have acquired a basic level of spoken Chinese (Mandarin) and a working knowledge of up to eight hundred simplified characters in their 1.
ARTS2451.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2452.title: Chinese English Translation
ARTS2452.description: This course explores recent translation theories and methodologies, as well as the role of translators in modern multi-cultural societies.
ARTS2452.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2453.title: Chinese Cinema
ARTS2453.description: This course is intended to serve as an introduction to the evolution of Chinese cinema in its cultural, literary and historical context.
ARTS2453.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2455.title: Gender in China
ARTS2455.description: This course explores the dramatic changes to gender and sexuality norms experienced by people living in China or operating in the Sinophone world.
ARTS2455.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2457.title: China Imagined and Perceived
ARTS2457.description: In this course you will examine how the Chinese are imagined and portrayed by Western culture and how the Chinese depict themselves.
ARTS2457.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2458.title: Along the Silk Road: Conquerors, Traders and Explorers
ARTS2458.description: The ‘Silk Roads’ are often considered to be the world’s greatest network of throughways that linked China to the Mediterranean world over land and sea.
ARTS2458.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2461.title: Intermediate Chinese for Background Speakers A
ARTS2461.description: This course is for background speakers at the Intermediate Level.
ARTS2461.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2462.title: Intermediate Chinese for Background Speakers B
ARTS2462.description: This course is for background speakers at the Intermediate Level.
ARTS2462.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2463.title: Nationalism, Identity and Ethnicity in China
ARTS2463.description: By examining China, one of the largest multi-ethnic society in human history as a case study, this course intends to acquaint students to the concepts of ethnicity, (ethno)nationalism and identity.
ARTS2463.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2464.title: Chinese Ideas of Beauty and Erotica: Ancient to Modern
ARTS2464.description: This course is designed to explore the experiences and representations of beauty in Chinese culture.
ARTS2464.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2480.title: Intermediate French A

ARTS2481.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2482.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2484.description: The French Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, such as Monet, Renoir and Cézanne, remain fascinating artists whose works have made a major contribution to modern art.
ARTS2484.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2485.description: This course taught in English offers a systematic comparison of French and English as far as sounds, vocabulary, word formation, and sentence structure are concerned.
ARTS2485.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2486.description: In this course, students will have the opportunity to discover the centrality of the French language in framing French identity, and to explore the current status of the French language in societies and institutions around the world.
ARTS2486.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2487.title: French Popular Culture
ARTS2487.description: This course invites you to examine different forms of contemporary French popular culture with a grounding in the social and political history of France.
ARTS2487.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2510.title: Intermediate German A
ARTS2510.description: Intermediate German A is ideal if you have successfully accomplished the Introductory German A and B courses or, if you have the equivalent of a year of German language learning.
ARTS2510.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2511.title: Intermediate German B
ARTS2511.description: Intermediate German B builds on the successful completion of Intermediate A or the equivalent of 1.
ARTS2511.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2542.title: Gods, Heroines and Heroes in Greek Myth
ARTS2542.description: Greek myths have had a profound influence on our culture.
ARTS2542.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2570.title: Intermediate Spanish A
ARTS2570.description: With more than 33 million Spanish speakers in the USA alone, Hispanic culture is increasingly significant.
ARTS2570.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2571.title: Intermediate Spanish B
ARTS2571.description: Whether you want to enhance your travel experiences, expand your work choices, or appreciate Hispanic cultural contributions, Spanish is one of the languages that will best serve you.
ARTS2571.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2630.title: Intermediate Japanese A
ARTS2630.description: The course focuses on Japanese communication in upper beginners level through different topics that are related to daily life.
ARTS2630.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2631.title: Intermediate Japanese B
ARTS2631.description: The course focuses on Japanese communication in upper beginners level through different topics that are related to daily life as well as sociocultural issues surrounding you.
ARTS2631.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2633.title: A Cultural Survey of Japan: From Gods to Gadgets
ARTS2633.description: This course focuses on key themes in Japanese culture from the pre-modern to the modern periods.
ARTS2633.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2660.title: Intermediate Korean A
ARTS2660.description: This course provides intermediate level tuition in Korean language study from a communicative and task-based approach.
ARTS2660.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2661.title: Intermediate Korean B
ARTS2661.description: This course provides an intermediate level program in Korean language study from a communicative and task-based approach.
ARTS2661.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2663.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2690.title: Semantics and Pragmatics
ARTS2690.description: In this course you will explore the nature and scope of semantics and pragmatics and their place within Linguistics.
ARTS2690.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2692.title: Syntax
ARTS2692.description: This course focuses on syntax – traditionally defined as the study of the grammatical relation between words within the sentence.
ARTS2692.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2693.title: Psycholinguistics
ARTS2693.description: This course will introduce you to the complexity and creativity of the human use of language with particular reference to first language acquisition and development.
ARTS2693.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2694.title: Phonology: Theory and Description
ARTS2694.description: This is an introductory course in phonology – the systematic study of the sound system of language.
ARTS2694.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2696.title: The Grammar of English
ARTS2696.description: This course provides a step-by-step account of English grammar covering the most important and central constructions and categories.
ARTS2696.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2698.title: Intercultural Interaction
ARTS2698.description: This course views interaction as the management of communication, including negotiation, conflict and power relations.
ARTS2698.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2750.title: Modern Latin America: Dependency and Development
ARTS2750.description: This course explores the history and development of Latin America from the Independence period in the early nineteenth century to the present.
ARTS2750.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2751.title: International Development
ARTS2751.description: Why does global inequality persist? Why do some countries remain poor, beset by conflict, while others leap ahead? What role do international and state actors play in promoting better development, or in holding it back? In order to find the answer to these questions, you will learn about contemporary academic and policy debates about international development and the quest to find solutions to global inequality and persistent underdevelopment.
ARTS2751.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2752.title: Local Politics of Development
ARTS2752.description: In this course you will learn about the politics that shape and are shaped by development in local contexts.
ARTS2752.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2754.title: Research for Impact in Global Development
ARTS2754.description: Tackling the world's greatest challenges such as poverty, inequality, environmental destruction, urbanisation and climate induced disasters requires an understanding of these issues from diverse disciplinary perspectives.
ARTS2754.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2755.title: Global Development in Practice: Concepts and Practices for Inclusive Development
ARTS2755.description: ‘Empowerment’, ‘participation’, ‘social inclusion’, ‘resilience’ ‘justice’: we all know that we want to achieve these ideals, but what do they mean and how are they operationalized in practice? In this course, you will gain a critical knowledge of the core vocabulary and approaches common in global development today.
ARTS2755.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2781.title: Postwar Europe: Politics, Societies, Cultures
ARTS2781.description: The course provides a wide-ranging introduction to the social, cultural and political history of Europe since 1945, both east and west.
ARTS2781.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2785.title: Europe's Age of Catastrophe, 1914-1945

ARTS2785.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2788.description: From controversies over the veil to conflicts around blasphemy and 'freedom of speech', one of the major challenges and controversies of contemporary Europe is the role of religion in public life.
ARTS2788.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2813.title: International Security

ARTS2813.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2815.title: Politics and Security in the Indo-Pacific
ARTS2815.description: The Indo-Pacific is a new and dynamic region, one that poses significant challenges and opportunities.
ARTS2815.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2816.description: Is power where the money is? Why do some people get so much, while others struggle to survive? What does it mean to take inequality in global politics seriously as a decisive factor in people’s lives? In this course, you will question the nature, constitution and effects of the contemporary global political economy from a critical perspective, discussing the variety of approaches to and understandings of global political-economic practices, actors, patterns and ideas.
ARTS2816.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2817.title: Diplomacy and Statecraft: Past, Present, Futures
ARTS2817.description: This course will give you an introduction to the study of twentieth-century international history and diplomacy.
ARTS2817.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2818.title: Australian Politics
ARTS2818.description: This course introduces you to the institutions, practices and principles of representative democracy and justice, within a comparative context.
ARTS2818.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2819.title: Globalisation and Governance
ARTS2819.description: Most scholars, policy-makers and governance practitioners argue that ‘globalisation’ exists and is important, but not all offer a clear understanding of what globalisation means for contemporary world politics.
ARTS2819.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2820.title: Justice
ARTS2820.description: Justice is considered by many people to be the first virtue of social and political life.
ARTS2820.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2821.title: Colonialism: Resistance, Justice, and Transition

ARTS2821.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2845.title: Sex, Human Rights and Justice

ARTS2845.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2852.title: Qualitative Research for Political and Social Problems
ARTS2852.description: What is research and how is it carried out to address questions concerning political and social life? What are the methods and methodologies that have been developed in and across Politics and International Relations to allow researchers to ask questions, and make claims, about the ‘political’ and the ‘social’ world? Through the analysis of key scholarly texts centred on pressing global issues, you will be introduced to a range of qualitative methodologies deployed in political science, and often adapted from other disciplinary contexts.
ARTS2852.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2870.title: Citizens, Action and Dissent
ARTS2870.description: In this course, you will consider individual and collective action through historical and contemporary case studies.
ARTS2870.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2871.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2872.title: Living and dying

ARTS2873.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2874.title: Culture and Emotion
ARTS2874.description: This subject will explore the cultural dimensions of emotion in everyday life.
ARTS2874.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2876.title: Understanding the Self
ARTS2876.description: Each of us has a self and an identity by virtue of being human.
ARTS2876.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2877.title: Technologies, Culture, Society
ARTS2877.description: This course uses anthropological and sociological approaches to analyse the effects of technologies on human life.
ARTS2877.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2900.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2904.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2905.title: Frida Kahlo: Performing Passion and Pain

ARTS2905.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2906.title: History of Sexuality

ARTS2906.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2908.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS2909.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3013.title: Performing Arts Industry Experience

ARTS3013.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3013.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3022.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3023.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3025.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3025.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3030.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3039.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3040.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3061.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3063.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3064.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3068.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3090.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3091.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3091.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3092.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3093.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3093.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

Subject Area: Media, Culture and Technology

ARTS3096.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3096.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3097.title: Current Debates in Media and Culture
ARTS3097.description: Media are centrally implicated in our lives – both public and private.
ARTS3097.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3097.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3122.title: Working in the Performing Arts
ARTS3122.description: Prepare yourself for a career in the performing arts.
ARTS3122.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3122.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3123.description:
Subject Area: Theatre and Performance Studies

ARTS3123.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3123.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3124.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3124.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3125.description: From dancing robots to smartphone theatres, this course examines the shifting relationship between technology and performance cultures.
ARTS3125.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3125.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3130.description: Choreography, Performance and the Visual Arts surveys key moments in the relationship between dance and performance on the one hand, and the plastic or visual arts on the other.

ARTS3130.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

Subject Area: Theatre and Performance Studies

ARTS3131.school: School of the Arts and Media
ARTS3131.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3132.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3212.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3216.description: China offers a rich context for examining the cultures and politics of media and communication.
ARTS3216.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3217.title: History of Modern China: Contested Visions

ARTS3220.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3240.title: Environmental Humanities Capstone
ARTS3240.description: You will have the opportunity to design your own independent research project that will speak to contemporary debates in the Environmental Humanities.
ARTS3240.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3241.title: Environmental Justice
ARTS3241.description: UNSW’s 2025 strategy offers a framework for addressing social justice aspirations of disadvantaged and marginalized communities.
ARTS3241.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3242.description: In this course you will gain a global perspective on our modern environmental condition and its development, since the beginnings of civilisation.
ARTS3242.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

Subject Area: Environmental Humanities

ARTS3245.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3270.description:
Subject Area: History

ARTS3270.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3292.description: At a time when much of the world's population is on the move, immigration and asylum have become two of the most contentious issues today.

ARTS3360.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3366.description: Human beings are evaluators: we praise and blame, take things to be good and bad, and think of ways that we, and the world we live in, could be better than they currently are.

ARTS3575.description: What makes contemporary Spain such a fascinating place is the immense and frenetic change it has undergone and that has, many argue, produced a new country.

ARTS3638.description: Given the popularity of both Japanese comics or manga and anime with learners of Japanese, the course focuses on a single title (available both in manga and anime) that reflects various aspects of contemporary Japanese life such as family life, education, and work.
ARTS3638.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3639.description: By using the broad social themes of post-1945 Japanese politics, economics and cultural development, this course attempts to produce an alternative socio-cultural timeline by considering how these themes were and are represented in domestic Japanese popular culture.
ARTS3639.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3640.description: Focuses on the relations between Japan and Korea from the late 19th century and the role of Japanese colonialism in the development of Korean cultural nationalism.
ARTS3640.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3641.description: This course provides you with an opportunity to learn how to interact successfully when working and doing business with Japanese people.
ARTS3641.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3663.description: This course provides a professional and business Korean program from thematic and task-based approaches.
ARTS3663.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3664.description: This course provides a para-professional level translation program in Korean from a task-based approach.
ARTS3664.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture
