ARTS3667.description: Explores issues relating to teaching Korean as a Foreign Language.
ARTS3667.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3690.title: Language Universals and Linguistic Typology
ARTS3690.description: This course will enable you to develop skills in extracting and synthesising information regarding linguistic diversity.
ARTS3690.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3695.title: Multilingualism and Language Planning
ARTS3695.description: In this course you will learn about the factors which impact on the spread and use of various languages and you will develop an understanding of how policies and language planning initiatives can change the language ecology of multicultural and multilingual communities.
ARTS3695.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3750.title: Development, Community and Environment
ARTS3750.description: Are you interested in understanding and tackling important environment-development challenges in the 21st century? Do you think a community-based approach to development and environment management delivers more sustainable and equitable outcomes? The course interrogates these and many more critical questions surrounding the community-based approach to development and environmental management.
ARTS3750.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3751.title: Development Studies: Research, Practice and Ethics
ARTS3751.description: How is development theory translated into practical outcomes? How can we make sure that a good idea leads to good development programmes and projects? This course provides you with a cutting-edge for entering into development practice as it exposes you to the real-life challenges you will face when working in development organisations.
ARTS3751.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3755.title: Development in Practice: Project Design
ARTS3755.description: In this course, you will draw upon the knowledge and skills from previous courses to design a humanitarian or development project.
ARTS3755.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3756.title: Current Debates in Development Studies
ARTS3756.description: In Current Debates in Development Studies we will analyse the concepts and cases at the heart of current debates in Development Studies from the global to the local level (and back again).
ARTS3756.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3757.title: Experiences and Everyday Practices of Development
ARTS3757.description: The anthropology of development and critical development studies have been central to understanding the everyday experiences and unintended consequences of development.
ARTS3757.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3758.title: Global Change Internship
ARTS3758.description: This course provides you with the unique opportunity to gain international exposure and deeper understanding of the political, social and cultural context of a development context.
ARTS3758.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3759.title: Preparing for and Reflecting on International Internships
ARTS3759.description: This course prepares you for the intensive demands of an international work-integrated learning experience.
ARTS3759.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3780.title: Contemporary Germany: History, Politics, Society
ARTS3780.description: Germany has faced enormous challenges and undergone radical transformations since the end of the Second World War, when it was a defeated, occupied pariah with no central government.
ARTS3780.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3783.title: Great, Emerging and Declining Powers in the Contemporary World
ARTS3783.description: ARTS3783 examines the foreign policies of a number of the world's major powers from 1945 to the present.
ARTS3783.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3786.title: Confronting the Past in Contemporary Europe
ARTS3786.description: What role does Europe's terrible twentieth-century history play today and how has this changed since 1945? To what extent does history divide or unite Europeans? Has Germany 'come to terms' with its Nazi past? How are Stalinism and the Soviet Union remembered in Putin's Russia? In this course you will explore how Europeans have coped with their recent pasts, particularly the experiences of fascism and Nazism, of World War II and the Holocaust, and of Soviet-style communism.
ARTS3786.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3787.title: European Modernity: Religion, Politics, Culture
ARTS3787.description: Whether in public or academic discourse the notions of ‘modernity’ and ‘modern’ are ubiquitous.
ARTS3787.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3789.title: Ethnic and Religious Minorities in Modern Europe
ARTS3789.description: This course examines interethnic and interfaith relations in Europe in the last two centuries.
ARTS3789.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3810.title: Politics & International Relations: Theory and Practice
ARTS3810.description: What is theory? What is praxis? What assumptions guide us when we theorise about events or phenomena in domestic and global politics? And what does it mean to undertake theoretically informed research and then actually apply it, in the discipline of Politics & International Relations? This course encourages you to consider the broader context of the discipline through critical, reflective and engaged thinking about contemporary Pols & IR.
ARTS3810.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3812.title: Manias, Panics and Crashes: Global Political Economy in an Era of Crisis
ARTS3812.description: The period from the early 1970s is often noted as a particularly volatile one for the global political economy (GPE).
ARTS3812.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3814.title: Australian Foreign Policy
ARTS3814.description: This course introduces you to the theory and practice of Australian foreign policy across a range of key relationships and policy areas in both historical and contemporary terms.
ARTS3814.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3816.title: US, China and International Law
ARTS3816.description: Considers the nature of US engagement with international law during the years of its rise to superpower status and since, and the impact of the US on international law.
ARTS3816.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3817.title: The Middle East and International Law
ARTS3817.description: This course will encourage you to examine the way in which international law and the Middle East interact.
ARTS3817.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3819.title: Emerging Challenges in International Security
ARTS3819.description: What do we mean by the 'new' security agenda? Are emerging threats to international security really 'new'? If so, how should security studies scholars analyse them, and what are the implications for security praxis? How are policymakers dealing with these emerging or 'new' security challenges, to what effect, and what are some of the alternatives? These are some of the key questions explored in this course, which investigates the broad and evolving agenda of security studies, and key themes and dynamics in contemporary security relations.
ARTS3819.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3820.title: How to start a revolution: activism, social movements and political change
ARTS3820.description: How to start a revolution and change the world? In a world of growing inequality, environmental pollution, and conflict this question seems more important than ever.
ARTS3820.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3821.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3822.title: The Art of Political Science
ARTS3822.description: The systematic study of politics has a long history, stretching back some two and a half thousand years to the ancient Greeks.
ARTS3822.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3871.description: In this course you will be confronted with fascinating riddles.

ARTS3872.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3874.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

ARTS3875.title: Decolonising Research Methods
ARTS3875.description: In this course you will reflect on the practice of key social research methods for investigating culture and society.

ARTS3886.description: In this course, you will explore the relationship between justice, social life and everyday experience.

ATSI0001.title: Enabling Skills 1
ATSI0001.description: Enabling Skills 1 introduces students to fundamental skills of studying at university.

ATSI0002.title: Enabling Skills 2
ATSI0002.description: Enabling Skills 2 develops the fundamental skills of studying at university.

ATSI1011.title: Indigenous Australia
ATSI1011.description: Indigenous Australia is the gateway course to the Indigenous Studies Major.

ATSI1012.title: Aboriginal Sydney
ATSI1012.description: In this course students are introduced to Aboriginal Sydney through local written and oral histories, as well as notable works in film, performance, television and art, seeking to make visible Aboriginal experiences, lives and connections to place in the city.

ATSI2003.title: Indigenous Material Culture-Objects and Their Journey
ATSI2003.description: The focus of this course is on the role of museums and art galleries in the representation of Indigenous peoples and their cultures.

ATSI2004.title: Popular Culture of Indigenous Australia
ATSI2004.description: Representations and misrepresentations of Australian Indigeneity as part of the national identity are most often portrayed through forms of popular culture.

ATSI2011.title: Indigenous Australian Political History
ATSI2011.description: Indigenous Australian Political History tells the story of Indigenous resistance, activism and political organisation during the twentieth century in Australia.

ATSI2012.title: Contemporary Issues in Indigenous Politics
ATSI2012.description: Contemporary Issues in Indigenous Politics examines contemporary debates in Australian Indigenous affairs, placing an emphasis on the political contexts within which these debates take place.

ATSI2014.title: Indigenous People and Policy
ATSI2014.description: This course aims to develop student understanding of the role of public policy in shaping Indigenous communities.

ATSI2015.title: The Science of Indigenous Knowledges
ATSI2015.description: In this course students will explore the history, philosophy, theory, and methods of Western science and ethnoscience.

ATSI3002.title: Gendered Identities in Indigenous Australia
ATSI3002.description: The course explores the way in which gender influences and structures the experiences of Indigenous women and men in the past and the present.

ATSI3003.title: Indigenous Cultural Heritage and the Environment
ATSI3003.description: This course explores Indigenous perspectives on the management of country, waterways, culture and heritage in Australia.

ATSI3005.title: Race, Colonialism and Whiteness
ATSI3005.description: There are (at least) two sides to the colonial relationship.

ATSI3008.title: Indigenous Studies Capstone
ATSI3008.description: This is the Capstone course for students completing the Indigenous Studies Major.

ATSI3017.title: Indigenous Histories and the Colonial World
ATSI3017.description: This course explores Australia's Indigenous histories and their contemporary resonance.

ATSI4001.title: Advanced Indigenous Studies: Issues and Debates
ATSI4001.description: The course is designed to build on and extend knowledge of Indigenous Studies developed over an undergraduate degree.

ATSI4003.title: Research Design in Indigenous Studies
ATSI4003.description: This course is a core component of the Honours year in Indigenous Studies.

ATSI4101.title: Indigenous Studies Honours I
ATSI4101.description: A 6 UOC thesis in Indigenous Studies to be completed as part of the 30 UOC of thesis component in the Honours Program.

ATSI4103.title: Indigenous Studies Honours III
ATSI4103.description: A 12 UOC thesis in Indigenous Studies to be completed as part of the 30 UOC of thesis component in the Honours Program.

ATSI7001.title: Pre-Business Program (Indigenous)
ATSI7001.description: The Indigenous Pre-Business course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in the Australian Business School at UNSW.

ATSI7002.title: Pre-Law Program (Indigenous)
ATSI7002.description: The Indigenous Pre-Law course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in Law at UNSW.

ATSI7003.title: Pre-Medicine Program (Indigenous)
ATSI7003.description: The PMP is an intensive academic program that runs for four weeks at the University of New South Wales in Sydney.

ATSI7004.title: Pre-Social Work Program (Indigenous)
ATSI7004.description: The Indigenous Pre-Social Work course is designed for Indigenous students wanting to enter the Bachelor of Social Work or any of the combined Social Work degrees.

ATSI7006.title: Pre-Teacher Education Program (Secondary) (Indigenous)
ATSI7006.description: The Pre-Teacher Education Program is an academic preparatory and enabling program designed for Indigenous students to undertake further undergraduate degree studies in education for the pupose of becoming secondary school teachers.

ATSI7007.title: Pre-Science and Engineering Program (Indigenous)
ATSI7007.description: The Indigenous Pre-Science/Engineering course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in the faculties of Science or Engineering at UNSW.

AVEN1920.title: Introduction to Aircraft Engineering
AVEN1920.description: This course gives an explanation of how aircraft fly and how engineering technologies relate to the vehicle.
AVEN1920.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

AVIA1111.title: Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
AVIA1111.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for Recreational Pilot Licence level Basic Aeronautical Knowledge, specifically the BAKC, RBKA, RFRC, RMTC and PHFC units of competency.

AVIA1321.title: Fundamentals of Aviation
AVIA1321.description: The course provides a foundation for the range of courses provided in the BAv, and includes a general description of the aviation industry.

AVIA1401.title: Introduction to Human Factors
AVIA1401.description: Human performance is highly dependent on a number of factors, some of which are under our direct control while others are outside our sphere of control.

AVIA1901.title: Aviation Transport Economics
AVIA1901.description: This course covers the economics of an airline and how airline management personnel address airline economic problems.

AVIA1902.title: Airline Financial Analysis and Decision Support
AVIA1902.description: This course is designed to provide students with an understanding of the financial decision-making required in the commercial air transport industry.

AVIA2013.title: Flight Operations 1
AVIA2013.description: The course comprises the aeronautical theory and associated ground training for Stage 1 of the Bachelor of Aviation (Flying).

AVIA2014.title: Flight Operations 2
AVIA2014.description: Pre-requisites: AVIA1002 or 2013Excluded: AVIA2003, AVIA2004The course comprises the aeronautical theory and associated ground training for Stage 2 of the Bachelor of Aviation (Flying).

AVIA2025.title: Introduction to Airborne Drone Management
AVIA2025.description: Airborne drones (unmanned aerial vehicles (or remotely piloted aircraft (RPA)) of varying shapes and sizes are permeating the civil aviation sector across recreational, commercial and research activities.

AVIA2101.title: Baggage Handling System Design, Technology & Operations
AVIA2101.description: A good working baggage handling system is essential for the functioning of modern airports.

AVIA2111.title: Commercial Navigation
AVIA2111.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for commercial pilot licence level Navigation, specifically the PNVC and CNVC units of competency.

AVIA2112.title: Commercial Meteorology
AVIA2112.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for commercial pilot licence level meteorology, specifically the PMTC and CMTC units of competency.

AVIA2113.title: Commercial Human Factors, Flight Rules and Air Law
AVIA2113.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for commercial pilot licence level Human Factors, Flight Rules and Air Law, specifically, the CHFC, CFRA and CFRC units of competency.

AVIA2114.title: Commercial Aircraft General Knowledge
AVIA2114.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for commercial pilot licence level Aircraft General Knowledge (Aeroplane), specifically the PAKC, PAKA (Section 2), CAKC (Sections 2.

AVIA2115.title: Commercial Aerodynamics
AVIA2115.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the Civil Aviation Safety Regulations 1998 Part 61 Manual of Standards for commercial pilot licence level Aerodynamics, specifically the Commerical Aerodynamics - all aircraft categories (CADC) and Commercial Aerodynamics - aeroplane (CADA) units of competency.

AVIA2116.title: Commercial Operation, Performance and Planning
AVIA2116.description: The course includes a component of the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for the grant of a Commercial Pilot Licence specifically POPC, POPA, COPC and COPA units of competency.

AVIA2117.title: Instrument Rating
AVIA2117.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for the grant of an instrument rating, specifically the IREX and GNSS units of competency.

AVIA2401.title: Aviation Law and Regulations
AVIA2401.description: This course aims to provide students with an overview of the regulatory structure of civil aviation in Australia.

AVIA2501.title: Airline Marketing Strategies
AVIA2501.description: This course uses the classic approach to marketing management strategies but is entirely focused on how this is achieved in the airline industry.

AVIA2601.title: Aviation Operations Research
AVIA2601.description: This course aims to introduce students with Operations Research (OR) concepts in the aviation context.

AVIA2701.title: Aviation Security and Airport Management
AVIA2701.description: The first component of this course provides a framework for understanding how airports function, the many demands placed upon them by a wide range of stakeholders and what is needed for airports to be successful at both an operational and business level.

AVIA2801.title: Regional and General Aviation
AVIA2801.description: This course covers the broad range of management decisions faced within the general, corporate and regional aviation sectors and how that is impacted by Government and regulation.

AVIA2910.title: Air Transport: Economics and the Environment
AVIA2910.description: This course is designed to develop non-economics majors’ economic literacy in the understanding of the key drivers of the commercial air transport industry and the industries’ impact on society.

AVIA2950.title: Current Affairs in Aviation
AVIA2950.description: Be up to date with the latest in the aviation industry, both globally and locally.

AVIA3013.title: Workplace Safety
AVIA3013.description: The ways in which work can affect people's health, safety and well-being is an important consideration for all organisations.

AVIA3014.title: Flight Operations 3
AVIA3014.description: The course comprises the aeronautical theory and associated ground training for Stage 3 of the Bachelor of Aviation (Flying).

AVIA3101.title: Airline Management
AVIA3101.description: This course considers the main facets of corporate airline management, and begins with airline organisational practice, management's visions and objective setting.

AVIA3111.title: Air Transport Flight Planning
AVIA3111.description: The course includes the aeronautical knowledge training required by the Civil Aviation Safety Regulations 1998 Part 61 Manual of Standards to achieve the competencies of Air Transport Flight Planning, specifically the Air Transport Pilot Flight Planning - Common and Air Transport Pilot Flight Planning - Aeroplane units of competency.

AVIA3112.title: Air Transport Aerodynamics and Aircraft Systems
AVIA3112.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for the Air Transport Pilot Licence level Aerodynamics and Aircraft Systems, specifically the AAGC and AAGA units of competency.

AVIA3113.title: Air Transport Performance and Navigation
AVIA3113.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for the Air Transport Pilot Licence level Navigation and Performance & Loading, specifically the APLC, APLA and ANVC units of competency.

AVIA3114.title: Air Transport Air Law, Meteorology and Human Factors
AVIA3114.description: The course includes all the aeronautical knowledge training required by the CASR 1998 Part 61 MOS for the Air Transport Pilots Licence level Air Law, Meteorology and Human Factors, specifically the AFRC, AFRA, AHFC, AMTC and AMTA units of competency.

AVIA3201.title: Airline Resource Management
AVIA3201.description: Airline operations are defined as the functional areas which are directly associated with the operations of aircraft or at least in the provision of services for aircraft operations.

AVIA3301.title: Simulation Application and Air Traffic Management
AVIA3301.description: The first component of this course addresses the broad application of simulation to training in the aviation industry.

AVIA3401.title: Aviation Safety and Resource Management
AVIA3401.description: The success of safe operations within aviation relies as much on the individual performing his/her role, as on the way he/she interacts with others.

AVIA3410.title: Advanced Law and Regulation in Aviation
AVIA3410.description: The course aims to provide students with a deeper understanding of contemporary aviation law and associated regulations by focusing in greater detail aspects of the course content covered in AVIA2401 by exploring judicial and regulatory developments of both international and domestic case law which is of particular relevance to the contemporary globalized context in which aviation operates.

AVIA3710.title: Aviation Research Methods
AVIA3710.description: Basic research skills are important to the aviation industry.

AVIA3851.title: Airport Management 2
AVIA3851.description: This course follows AVIA1850 and provides an in-depth coverage of the key elements outlined in Airport Management 1.

AVIA3900.title: Sustainable aviation and tourism
AVIA3900.description: This course offers an introduction to concepts and tools necessary for understanding the challenges of sustainable development in the transport-environment-tourism nexus.

AVIA4001.title: Aviation Honours - Full Time
AVIA4001.description: This course introduces students to major research areas through a course of advanced lectures and a major research thesis of 20,000 words.

AVIA4002.title: Aviation Honours
AVIA4002.description: Undertaken over two years, this course introduces students to major research areas through a course of advanced lectures and a major research thesis of 20, 000 words.

AVIA4003.title: Aviation Honours - Full Time
AVIA4003.description: This course aims to help students achieve, through research, a deep understanding of a specific aspect of aviation, while developing a range of skills that are highly valued in industry.

AVIA4004.title: Aviation Honours - Part Time
AVIA4004.description: Undertaken over two years, this course aims to help students achieve, through research, a deep understanding of a specific aspect of aviation, while developing a range of skills that are highly valued in industry.

AVIA5015.title: Safety Management Systems
AVIA5015.description: This course is intended to provide the student with an understanding of the principles that apply to an aviation safety system and an understanding the complex interaction between individuals and organisations to which those principles apply.

BABS1111.title: Big Fat Myths
BABS1111.description: Weight loss fads in the form of diets and exercise regimes (with mostly unrealistic claims) are ubiquitous in modern day life; however, there is surprising ignorance and confusion about how we lose weight, with most people unable to answer the simplest question: when you lose weight, where does the fat go? Popular (incorrect) answers include energy, heat, faeces and sweat.
BABS1111.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS1112.title: Genetics and Society
BABS1112.description: Since the release of the first human genome about two decades ago, our understanding of genetics has improved significantly.
BABS1112.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS1201.title: Molecules, Cells and Genes
BABS1201.description: The course is concerned with the basic characteristics of all life.
BABS1201.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS1202.title: Applied Biomolecular Sciences
BABS1202.description: This course provides an overview of the application of molecular and cellular biology to the fields of medicine, plant and animal science, and food, marine and environmental sciences.
BABS1202.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS2011.title: Current Trends in Biotechnology
BABS2011.description: Through case study presentations students will be introduced to how biotechnology advances are impacting on society by solving problems in medicine, agriculture, and environmental management.
BABS2011.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS2202.title: Molecular Cell Biology 1
BABS2202.description: Cells are not only the basic building blocks of all organisms they are also the source of the vast diversity that characterizes life on earth.
BABS2202.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS2204.title: Genetics
BABS2204.description: Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields.
BABS2204.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS2264.title: Genetics (Advanced Level)
BABS2264.description: Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields.
BABS2264.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3021.title: Microbial Genetics
BABS3021.description: This course provides a broad coverage of material describing the fundamentals of microbial genetics.
BABS3021.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3031.title: Biotechnology and Bioengineering
BABS3031.description: In order to bring new biotechnology products to the market, scalable bioprocesses must be developed and validated.
BABS3031.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3041.title: Immunology
BABS3041.description: BABS3041 provides a broad coverage of immunology.
BABS3041.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3061.title: Medical Biotechnology
BABS3061.description: Biotechnology innovation is in a large part driven by the requirement for improvements in medical diagnosis and therapy for a range of diseases including autoimmune diseases, diseases of inflammation and cancer, and infectious diseases.
BABS3061.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3071.title: Commercial Biotechnology
BABS3071.description: NOTE: Up to Session 1 2010 this course was offered as BIOT3071.
BABS3071.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3081.title: Bacteria and Disease
BABS3081.description: Bacteria and Disease aims to provide students with a high level of understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms used by a diverse array of bacterial pathogens to cause human disease.
BABS3081.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3091.title: Professional Issues in Biotechnology
BABS3091.description: The objective of the course is to provide students with the skills and knowledge required to identify and pursue business opportunities based on technological discovery.
BABS3091.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3121.title: Molecular Biology of Nucleic Acids
BABS3121.description: The syllabus comprises a detailed analysis of gene structure and function which includes: structure and properties of polynucleotides such as DNA and RNA; structure of chromatin; mechanisms and regulation of gene replication, transcription and translation, DNA repair and the molecular biology of cancer induction; recombinant DNA technology; nulceic acid sequencing, ecombinant DNA technology, application of genomics and proteomics, microarray analyses; protein production using recombinant DNA systems.
BABS3121.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3151.title: Human Molecular Genetics and Disease
BABS3151.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3200.title: Synthetic Biology
BABS3200.description: Synthetic biology is the design and construction of novel biological systems or the redesign of existing biological systems.
BABS3200.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3281.title: Molecular Frontiers
BABS3281.description: This course focuses on molecular biology techniques commonly used in biomedical research.
BABS3281.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3291.title: Genes, Genomes and Evolution
BABS3291.description: This course covers cutting edge concepts in genetics, genomics and evolution: genome structure (how genes are organised into genomes), genomics (genome sequencing, assembly and annotation), genome variation and the forces that shape it (mutation, recombination and genetic drift), molecular phylogenetics (capturing and using patterns of evolution), and applications of genomics (conservation genomics, host-pathogen interactions, genome engineering, and systems biology).
BABS3291.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3301.title: Biomolecular Science Laboratory Project (Advanced)
BABS3301.description: This course is designed to introduce students to research methodology, and to stimulate critical and lateral thinking in the context of problem solving.
BABS3301.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS3631.title: Biotechnology & Bioengineering Advanced
BABS3631.description: In order to bring new biotechnology products to the market, scalable bioprocesses must be developed and validated.
BABS3631.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS4053.title: Biotechnology Research Project
BABS4053.description: Students in program 3052 (BSc Biotechnology), who qualify for the 4th  year by obtaining a credit average or greater in their Stage 3 courses,  will complete their training by undertaking full-time research in the  fourth year, enrolling in BABS4053.
BABS4053.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS4516.title: Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences Honours
BABS4516.description: A 16 UOC Research Project in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, taken in three trimesters providing a total of 48 UOC.
BABS4516.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BABS4524.title: Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences Honours 24 Units of Credit
BABS4524.description: A 24 UOC Research Project in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, taken in two semesters providing a total of 48 UOC.
BABS4524.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BEES0006.title: Special Program in Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences - Undergraduate 6 units of credit
BEES0006.description: Short theoretical or experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff.
BEES0006.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES0010.title: Australian Environment, Wildlife and Conservation
BEES0010.description: NOTE: This course is only available to Study Abroad students, i.
BEES0010.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES1041.title: Methods for Exploring the Natural World
BEES1041.description: The course will introduce students to the scientific method within the life, environmental and Earth sciences.
BEES1041.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES2041.title: Data Analysis for Life and Earth Sciences
BEES2041.description: Development of skills in applying statistics to biological, earth and spatial data; design and analysis of experiments in life and earth sciences; sampling strategies for estimating sample size; analysis of community and environment structure using multivariate statistics; simulation modelling in population biology, and statistical fitting of non-linear models to population growth data; correlation and both simple and multiple regression; improving statistical models using analysis of residuals; analysis of spatial data.
BEES2041.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES2680.title: Introduction to science communication
BEES2680.description: Successful scientists - whether in the university environment or the outside workplace - have to be effective communicators.
BEES2680.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES2741.title: Introduction to Astrobiology: Life in the Universe
BEES2741.description: Astrobiology is the study of the search for life elsewhere in the universe, the origin of life on Earth, and the future of life on Earth.
BEES2741.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES3041.title: Big Data in the Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences
BEES3041.description: This is an advanced quantitative methods course which uses a project-based approach to consider the analysis, visualisation and communication of large and complex data sets.
BEES3041.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES4514.title: Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences Honours - 24 Units of Credit
BEES4514.description: A 24 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combination with BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC.
BEES4514.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES4515.title: Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences Honours - 18 Units of Credit
BEES4515.description: A 18 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combination with BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC.
BEES4515.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES4516.title: Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences Honours
BEES4516.description: A 12 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combination with BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC.
BEES4516.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES4517.title: Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences Honours
BEES4517.description: A 16 UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, in which students enrol three times for a total of 48 UOC.
BEES4517.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES4518.title: Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences Honours - 6 Units of Credit
BEES4518.description: A 6UOC Research Project in the School of Biological, Earth & Environmental Sciences, taken in combinationwith BEES4522 and additional BEES Research Project courses to total 48 UOC.
BEES4518.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES4523.title: Research Proposal
BEES4523.description: This course is an essential component of the Honours Program in the School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences and is completed in the first session of an Honours Program.
BEES4523.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES6601.title: An Introduction to the Sydney Environment
BEES6601.description: !Important! This course is not available to students who are taking Majors in the School of BEES.
BEES6601.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES6741.title: Astrobiology: Life in the Universe
BEES6741.description: Astrobiology is the study of life in the universe and the chemistry, physics, and adaptations that influence its origin, evolution and destiny.
BEES6741.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES6761.title: Expedition New Zealand: Environmental Challenges
BEES6761.description: Environmental changes and their impacts are increasingly providing valuable insights into how our planet works.
BEES6761.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEES6800.title: The Science of Science Communication
BEES6800.description: The Science of Science Communication course aims to teach science students how to effectively communicate across a range of audiences why science matters, how it works, and what the relevance of science is to the way we live our lives.
BEES6800.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BEIL0001.title: Graphic Design for the Built Environment
BEIL0001.description: This elective is open to students in the Architecture, Interior Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Industrial Design, Computational Design, Construction Management and Planning disciplines.
BEIL0001.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0003.title: Built Environment Annual Design Competition
BEIL0003.description: BE Design Competitions is one of four streams of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative offered by the Faculty of Built Environment.
BEIL0003.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0004.title: Design Competitions and Bids
BEIL0004.description: BE Design Competitions is one of four streams of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative offered by the Faculty of Built Environment.
BEIL0004.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0005.title: People, Place and Design
BEIL0005.description: People, Place, Design provides an introduction to the extensive body of environment-behaviour research and theory on people’s relationship to place.
BEIL0005.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0006.title: BE OutThere Elective
BEIL0006.description: This elective is open to all undergraduate students in BE, who are in their third year or above.
BEIL0006.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0007.title: Sustainable Design Thinking
BEIL0007.description: BEIL0007 is offered as part of the suite of courses under the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) initiative.
BEIL0007.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0008.title: Design Project Management - Vision to Reality
BEIL0008.description: In BEIL0008 Design Project Management students will explore how each of the Faculty’s professional disciplines, working together & individually, can project manage the design process & the project management knowledge areas of design scope, time & cost for a Client’s vision for their buildings, to make it a reality.
BEIL0008.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0009.title: Exhibition Design: Transforming Temporary Space
BEIL0009.description: Exhibition design is inherently interdisciplinary with practitioners coming from a wide variety of design disciplines.
BEIL0009.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0010.title: Creating Value for Built Environment Clients
BEIL0010.description: Our Built Environment Faculty is fundamentally about creating value.
BEIL0010.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0011.title: Healthy Planning
BEIL0011.description: Healthy Planning is an inter-disciplinary elective for senior students studying to be built environment and health professionals.
BEIL0011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0013.title: Architectural Photography
BEIL0013.description: This elective provides an opportunity for students to understand and practice basic principles and techniques of digital photography when applied to their particular built environment practice.

BEIL0014.title: Digital Making
BEIL0014.description: 'Digital Making' builds on the advanced knowledge generated and documented within CODE2230 - Human-Machine Interaction, CODE2250 - Advanced Digital Fabrication and CODE2270 - Design Information Management, and represent the completion of the 'Applied Level' stream of the Computational Design degree.
BEIL0014.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0015.title: Digital Design Foundations
BEIL0015.description: 'This course introduces students to developing and applying fundamental skills in a visual programming language interface, and apply fundamental mathematical concepts to inform computational design methods.

BEIL0016.title: Renewing the Urban Environment
BEIL0016.description: This course will focus on precincts and public and/or community based projects that have the potential to catalyse revitalisation and/or renewal in urban environments.
BEIL0016.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0017.title: Business Start Up
BEIL0017.description: This course offers those intending to start up their own creative business an understanding of the essential business requirements for setting up and running a small creative enterprise.
BEIL0017.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0018.title: Kirigami Architectural Principles & Creative Paper Engineering
BEIL0018.description:
Kirigami  is a variation of origami that includes cutting of the paper (from Japanese "kiru" = to cut, "kami" = paper)
How can flat surfaces be transformed into useful three-dimensional structures? 
Kirigami patterns can be robustly manipulated into a variety of three-dimensional shapes by folding and cutting a flat surface into complex target configurations.
BEIL0018.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL0020.title: International Construction Study Trip
BEIL0020.description: This course is run jointly with two overseas universities, and comprises of two separate international study trips that students can choose from.
BEIL0020.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6000.title: Mapping Social Justice in the City
BEIL6000.description: This elective course is designed as a vehicle for the exploration of current interdisciplinary knowledge on social justice issues in Sydney.
BEIL6000.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6001.title: International Planning
BEIL6001.description: The primary purpose of this course is to introduce students to relevant concepts of planning that look beyond the Australian context to that of the developing societies of our world.
BEIL6001.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6002.title: Urban and Regional Design
BEIL6002.description: This course reviews the principles of urban design and guides students through urban design methodology via a series of small design projects.
BEIL6002.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6003.title: Cinematic Space
BEIL6003.description: Cinema is an art form closely tied to architecture and the built environment.
BEIL6003.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6005.title: Researching Art, Architecture and Design
BEIL6005.description: The course is offered under the auspices of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning initiative [BEIL] and is open to all students in the Faculty of the Built Environment who have completed at least 96UOC.
BEIL6005.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6006.title: Heritage Planning
BEIL6006.description: This course provides students with an overview of the theory and practice of heritage planning.
BEIL6006.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6007.title: International Study Tour
BEIL6007.description: Affordable housing is a basic requirement and an essential ingredient of a just, inclusive and sustainable city.
BEIL6007.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6008.title: International Design Studio
BEIL6008.description: The BEIL International Design Studio is a course that will be offered once per year as part of the Built Environment Interdisciplinary Learning (BEIL) suite of courses.
BEIL6008.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6009.title: Integrated Building Design Case Studies
BEIL6009.description: This course will focus on the Sydney Opera House (SOH) as a landmark case-study to explore the key role of interdisciplinary collaboration (IC) and integrated building design (IBD) in the achievement of high performance architecture (HPA).
BEIL6009.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6010.title: Sydney Urban Lab
BEIL6010.description: This course considers the city as a site of inquiry, experimentation, and collaboration.
BEIL6010.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6011.title: Street Life Studies: Sydney Phnom Penh
BEIL6011.description: Street Life Studies: Cambodia is an international, interdisciplinary urban design elective that places you, the student, on the streets of Phnom Penh and Sydney in collaboration with your Cambodian design colleagues.
BEIL6011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BEIL6012.title: Asian Urbanism Laboratory
BEIL6012.description: This intensive interdisciplinary studio is open to architecture, landscape, interior, urban design and city planning students.

BENV0001.title: Fabrication Fundamentals
BENV0001.description: Fabrication Fundamentals introduces students to safe and effective operation of fabrication equipment, processes and materials.

BENV1010.title: Communication in the Built Environment
BENV1010.description: This course will give students the communication strategies and techniques to both create and share design ideas and concepts with others.
BENV1010.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV1012.title: Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication
BENV1012.description:
This course introduces students to Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication, with emphasis on the direct
relationship between Mathematics and Geometry, and how these two fields constitute the foundations of
any parametric design process.
BENV1012.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV1015.title: History of Design Thinking
BENV1015.description: This course on the history of design thinking explores connections between the disciplines of architecture, interior architecture and industrial design.
BENV1015.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV1043.title: Multimedia in Design Presentation
BENV1043.description: The course develops skills in effective digital communication and explores the potential of multimedia as a design presentation tool.
BENV1043.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV1072.title: Design for Energy Efficiency
BENV1072.description: This course develops an understanding of solar efficient architecture and builds on this to develop skills in energy performance simulation.
BENV1072.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2000.title: Re-enchanting the City: Designing the Human Habitat
BENV2000.description: This course is an introduction to the interdisciplinary nature of city making that focuses on a cutting-edge, high-density urban infill project, Central Park, Sydney as its case study.
BENV2000.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2001.title: Emerging Digital Technologies
BENV2001.description: Students in this course will gain knowledge in the technical and operational principles of emerging digital technologies and identify applications of emerging digital technologies in and for the design of the built environment.
BENV2001.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2112.title: Landscape Design for Well Being
BENV2112.description: This course centres on understanding holistic concepts such as wellbeing, restoration, social inclusion and health and their implications for design of the built environment.
BENV2112.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2137.title: Children, Youth and Environments
BENV2137.description: This course will challenge students' thinking about planning, designing and creating environments for children and young people.
BENV2137.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2219.title: History of Australian Landscape Design
BENV2219.description: This course traces the evolutionary development of significant periods in the history of landscape design in Australia by means of a chronological thread in the form of lectures and field excursions if applicable.
BENV2219.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2220.title: The Culture of Nature
BENV2220.description: This course explores the ways in which culture fosters specific ideas about "Nature.
BENV2220.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2255.title: Architecture in Sydney
BENV2255.description: The emphasis of the course is on the study and analysis of buildings through a series of site visits and tours of the city of Sydney.
BENV2255.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2409.title: Immersive Digital Environments
BENV2409.description: This course explores advanced multimedia technology and 3D game development and, in doing so, develops insight into applications for architectural and built environment contexts.
BENV2409.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2708.title: Interior Detailing
BENV2708.description: Design resolution, at a fine scale, highlights issues of quality and plays a central role in detailing to achieve buildings and interiors which are original and coherent examples of good design.
BENV2708.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2930.title: Living Architecture: Green Roofs and Green Walls
BENV2930.description: This course will introduce students and practitioners to issues related to planning, design and implementation of green roofs and green walls in urban environments.
BENV2930.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2938.title: Transport Planning
BENV2938.description: This subject provides an introductory understanding of the role of transport planning as a planning tool that can be used to achieve positive overall planning outcomes in the built urban environment.
BENV2938.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV2942.title: Rural Planning
BENV2942.description: This course has been designed specifically to give students an appreciation of the issues associated with planning for rural areas, a vital component of land use management in Australia.
BENV2942.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV4000.title: Research Methods in the Built Environment
BENV4000.description: This course provides an introduction to the research process, qualitative and quantitative research, mixed methods research, it also covers the basic techniques of survey design, data collection and analysis, introductory statistics, which are an integral component of a built environment graduate’s skill set.
BENV4000.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV6713.title: Architectural Spatialisation
BENV6713.description: This course is focused on the critical study of spatiality of the built environment through interpretive sketching and live architectural drawing.
BENV6713.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BENV6728.title: Classical Architecture
BENV6728.description: The course explores the origins, vocabulary and grammar of the Classical Orders and their application in Greek and Roman architecture, in the Renaissance and the Baroque periods, as well as in Neo-Classicism and the nineteenth century.

BENV6800.title: Professional Placement
BENV6800.description: The Professional Placement provides Built Environment students an opportunity to gain targeted professional work experience, and to explore the dynamics, requirements and expectations of a built environment workplace.
BENV6800.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BINF2010.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics
BINF2010.description: The course surveys the major areas of bioinformatics, exploring the history of bioinformatics in relation to advances in computing hardware and software; the biological problems currently being addressed using bioinformatics; and future applications of bioinformatics.
BINF2010.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

BINF3010.title: Applied Bioinformatics
BINF3010.description: Bioinformatics (the use of computing methods for the management and analysis of molecular biology data) has become an integral component of biomolecular sciences, especially genomics and proteomics.
BINF3010.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

BINF6111.title: Genome Informatics Engineering Design Workshop
BINF6111.description: Engineering software systems for managing and analysing large datasets derived from genomics experiments is a key application of bioinformatics.
BINF6111.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

BINF6112.title: Computational Biology Engineering Design Workshop
BINF6112.description: Through a practical software project and targeted lectures this course examines various issues in the design and implementation of software systems for the analysis of large complex biological datasets and the application of mathematical and statistical methods to problems in modern life science.
BINF6112.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

BIOC2101.title: Principles of Biochemistry (Advanced)
BIOC2101.description: BIOC2101 introduces modern biochemistry, covers fundamental aspects of the structure-function relationships of proteins and an overall coverage of intermediary metabolism.
BIOC2101.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOC2181.title: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
BIOC2181.description: Introduces modern biochemistry, covers fundamental aspects of the structure-function relationships of proteins and an overall coverage of intermediary metabolism.
BIOC2181.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOC2201.title: Principles of Molecular Biology (Advanced)
BIOC2201.description: Provides an introduction to modern molecular biology and covers the molecular mechanisms of gene expression and fundamental aspects of recombinant DNA technology.
BIOC2201.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOC3111.title: Molecular Biology of Proteins
BIOC3111.description: Modern aspects of the structure function relationships of proteins including discussion of the latest techniques of protein characterisation.
BIOC3111.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOC3261.title: Human Biochemistry
BIOC3261.description: This course showcases some more advanced aspects of biochemistry that are particularly relevant to humans.
BIOC3261.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOC3271.title: Molecular Cell Biology 2
BIOC3271.description: The discipline known as Molecular Cell Biology investigates how cells develop, operate, communicate, construct multicellular organisms, control their activities, and (on occasion) go awry.
BIOC3271.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOC3671.title: Molecular Cell Biology 2 (Advanced)
BIOC3671.description: A molecular approach to understanding the complex, dynamic interactions that comprise cellular function.
BIOC3671.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOM1010.title: Engineering in Medicine and Biology
BIOM1010.description: This course introduces the field of biomedical engineering where the principles of engineering are used to solve problems in medicine and biology.

BIOM2451.title: Biomechanics for Sports Scientists
BIOM2451.description: Students will study the basic principles of biomechanics and apply these to the analysis of human movement and the musculoskeletal system.

BIOM4951.title: Research Thesis A
BIOM4951.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

BIOM4952.title: Research Thesis B
BIOM4952.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

BIOM4953.title: Research Thesis C
BIOM4953.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

BIOM5001.title: Thesis Part A (Mechanical Engineering, Mechatronics)
BIOM5001.description: Thesis topic for BE(Mech)/MBiomedE and BE(Mtrn)/MBiomedE students only.

BIOM5003.title: Thesis Part B (Mechanical Engineering, Mechatronics)
BIOM5003.description: Thesis topic for BE(Mech)/MBiomedE and BE(Mtrn)/MBiomedE students only.

BIOM5904.title: Thesis B for BE(Soft)/MBiomedE Students
BIOM5904.description: Second part of an undergraduate project to satisfy BE and MBiomedE thesis requirements for students enrolled in Program 3749 only.

BIOM5909.title: Thesis A for BE(Soft)/MBiomedE Students
BIOM5909.description: Thesis for students enrolled in BE (SENG)/MBiomedE only.

BIOM5910.title: Thesis A for BE(Elec, Tele, Mat)/MBiomedE Students
BIOM5910.description: Thesis topic for BE(Elec)/MBiomedE students only.

BIOM5911.title: Thesis Part B
BIOM5911.description: Thesis topic for BE(Elec)/MBiomedE students only.

BIOM5930.title: Research Project A for BE(Chem)/MBiomedE Students
BIOM5930.description: Thesis topic for BE(Chem)/MBiomedE students only.

BIOM5932.title: Thesis Part B (CHEM)
BIOM5932.description: Thesis topic for BE(Chem)/MBioimedE students only.

BIOM5940.title: Thesis A for BE(Binf)/MBiomedE Students
BIOM5940.description: Thesis for students enrolled in BE (BINF)/MBiomedE only.

BIOM5950.title: Thesis Part A (CSE)
BIOM5950.description: This thesis is for CSE/Biomedical Engineering students only.

BIOM5951.title: Thesis Part B (CSE)
BIOM5951.description: This thesis is for CSE/Biomedical Engineering students only.

BIOM5960.title: Thesis Part A (SENG)
BIOM5960.description: This thesis is for Software Engineering/Biomedical Engineering students only.

BIOM5961.title: Thesis Part B (SENG)
BIOM5961.description: This thesis is for Software Engineering/Biomedical Engineering students only.

BIOM5971.title: Thesis Part B (BINF)
BIOM5971.description: This thesis is for Bioinformatic Engineering/Biomedical Engineering students only.

BIOM9020.title: Masters Project (Half Time)
BIOM9020.description: Please note: candidates must contact the School for consent to enrol.

BIOM9021.title: Masters Project (Half Time)
BIOM9021.description: BIOM9021 is the second half of the 12 UOC research project.

BIOM9027.title: Medical Imaging
BIOM9027.description: Fundamentals of producing a medical image, image collection techniques, image reconstruction algorithms.

BIOM9311.title: Mass Transfer in Medicine
BIOM9311.description: Mass transfer in the living organism and in extracorporeal medical devices.

BIOM9332.title: Biocompatibility
BIOM9332.description: Interaction of biological fluids and cells with foreign surfaces, in vitro tests to assess biocompatibility and thrombogenicity, current status of biocompatible materials as applied to extracorporeal systems, surgical implants and prosthetic devices.

BIOM9333.title: Cellular and Tissue Engineering
BIOM9333.description: This course outlines concepts underlying development of cell-based products and aims to give students a theoretical and practical understanding of the tools available for producing such "devices" as well as the biological, physical and chemical constraints of these systems.

BIOM9410.title: Regulatory Requirements of Biomedical Technology
BIOM9410.description: The regulatory requirements of medical devices in Australia, Japan, North America and Europe will be reviewed.

BIOM9420.title: Clinical Laboratory Science
BIOM9420.description: BIOM9420 explores the science behind clinical diagnostics covering areas of biochemistry, haematology, immunology, imaging and clinical biomechanics as well as the renal and cardiovascular systems.

BIOM9450.title: Biomedical and Health Informatics
BIOM9450.description: An introduction to biomedical and health informatics, including informatics and information systems, evidence-based medicine and clinical decision support.

BIOM9541.title: Mechanics of the Human Body
BIOM9541.description: The course covers in depth the methods used in the analysis of the biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system.

BIOM9551.title: Biomechanics of Physical Rehabilitation
BIOM9551.description: The application of biomechanics principles to the areas of performance testing and assessment, physical therapy, design of rehabilitation equipment, design of internal and external prostheses and orthoses.

BIOM9561.title: Mechanical Properties of Biomaterials
BIOM9561.description:
This course addresses the interlinked theme of engineering tissues and smart materials by learning from Nature's
paradigms.

BIOM9621.title: Biological Signal Analysis
BIOM9621.description: Use of digital computers to extract information from biological signals.

BIOM9640.title: Biomedical instrumentation
BIOM9640.description: This course serves as an introduction to physiological measurement of bioelectric phenomena and neurostimulation.

BIOM9650.title: Biosensors and Transducers
BIOM9650.description: This course serves as an introduction to physiological measurement using biosensors and transducers.

BIOM9660.title: Bionics and Neuromodulation
BIOM9660.description: This course serves as an introduction to the engineering issues related to  implantable bionics for therapeutic electrical stimulation of neural and muscle  tissue.

BIOM9701.title: Dynamics of the Cardiovascular System
BIOM9701.description: Fundamentals of circulatory physiology; structure and function of large arteries; oscillatory phenomena; relationships of pulsatile pressure and flow; arterial properties and wave propagation; wave reflection; blood rheology; microcirculation; cardiac biophysics; cardiac dynamics; dynamics of assisted circulation; regulation of pressure and flow; cardiovascular control.

BIOM9711.title: Modelling Organs, Tissues and Devices
BIOM9711.description: Computer modelling of complex physiological systems and their interaction with medical devices is becoming increasingly important in modern medical device design.

BIOM9914.title: Masters Project
BIOM9914.description: Please note: candidates must contact the School for consent to enrol.

BIOS1101.title: Evolutionary and Functional Biology
BIOS1101.description: The course examines the evolutionary history of life on earth from origins to humans and the relationship between environment, adaptation and function.
BIOS1101.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS1301.title: Ecology, Sustainability and Environmental Science
BIOS1301.description: This course provides an introduction to ecology, sustainability and environmental science, introducing a range of biological topics and how scientists approach these topics to solve problems.
BIOS1301.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS1501.title: Australia's Unique and Deadly Animals and Plants
BIOS1501.description: The Australian fauna and flora evolved during a long period of isolation from the biota of other continents.
BIOS1501.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS2011.title: Evolutionary and Physiological Ecology
BIOS2011.description: This course provides an introduction to the functional relationships between living organisms and the environments in which they live.
BIOS2011.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS2031.title: Biology of Invertebrates
BIOS2031.description: A study of invertebrate diversity emphasising their evolution, morphology, behaviour, and relationships to marine, freshwater and terrestrial environments.
BIOS2031.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS2051.title: Flowering Plants
BIOS2051.description: Basic plant biology including cell structure, plant morphology and anatomy, water and sugar transport, seed structure and germination, plant growth and development, leaves and photosynthesis, roots, micro-organisms and nutrition, evolution of land plants and plant taxonomy.
BIOS2051.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS2061.title: Vertebrate Zoology
BIOS2061.description: Australia has a high diversity of vertebrate species (e.
BIOS2061.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS2123.title: Ecosystem Conservation and Management
BIOS2123.description: This course has an intensive field trip component to the internationally important and spectacular Macquarie Marshes where you will sample wetland environments and learn about river management.
BIOS2123.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS2500.title: Evolution and the Modern World
BIOS2500.description: Evolution shaped the living world, from the flu virus to millions-strong colonies of leaf-cutter ants, and from simple sessile invertebrates to conscious and highly cultural humans.
BIOS2500.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3011.title: Animal Behaviour
BIOS3011.description: Theory and practice in the biological study of animal behaviour: ethology and behavioural ecology.
BIOS3011.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3061.title: Plant Ecology
BIOS3061.description: Topics include: plant-animal interactions, including herbivory, seed dispersal and pollination; biological invasions; disturbance, including life in fire-prone ecosystems and the effects of human influences on plant communities; plant regeneration, including reproduction and mating systems, and seed and seedling ecology; evolutionary radiations; plant ecological strategies.
BIOS3061.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3081.title: Ocean to Estuarine Ecosystems
BIOS3081.description: Oceans occupy 75% of the planet's surface and have the capacity to moderate our climate and supply our food, water and oxygen.
BIOS3081.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3091.title: Marine and Aquatic Ecology
BIOS3091.description: Ecology of marine and freshwater systems, emphasising benthic communities.

BIOS3123.title: Conservation in Practice
BIOS3123.description: This course is an intensive field-based course which is run in conjunction with the management of endangered species.
BIOS3123.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3161.title: Life in Arid Lands
BIOS3161.description: Forty-four percent of Australia is desert and a further 37% is semi-arid grassland or shrub communities.
BIOS3161.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3171.title: Evolution
BIOS3171.description: BIOS3171 Evolution is an advanced course covering the core concepts and research techniques of modern evolutionary biology.
BIOS3171.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3221.title: Assembling the Tree of Life
BIOS3221.description: Systematics investigates historical aspects of evolution and establishes evidence-based classifications and genealogical relationships between organisms.
BIOS3221.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3601.title: Advanced Field Biology
BIOS3601.description: An advanced practical training in diversity, systematics, biology and identification of terrestrial animals and plants.
BIOS3601.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS3681.title: Ocean to Estuarine Ecosystems (Advanced)
BIOS3681.description: Oceans occupy 75% of the planet's surface and have the capacity to moderate our climate and supply our food, water and oxygen.
BIOS3681.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS6671.title: Biodiversity and Conservation of Natural Resources
BIOS6671.description: Note: This course was previously offered as  BIOS3071  but changed to  BIOS6671  as of 2011.
BIOS6671.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS6692.title: Advanced Underwater Field Ecology
BIOS6692.description: This course is a field-based course offering students advanced practical training in conducting marine ecological field studies underwater.
BIOS6692.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOS6723.title: River Basin Ecosystem Management
BIOS6723.description: This course is an intensive field-based course located in Botswana's Okavango Delta, one of the world's hotspots of biodiversity and a UNESCO World Heritage site.
BIOS6723.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

BIOT3081.title: Environmental Biotechnology
BIOT3081.description: This course discusses the principles and commercial applications of biotechnology to environmental problems.
BIOT3081.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BIOT4073.title: Biotechnology Honours Full-Time
BIOT4073.description: Advanced formal training in selected areas of biotechnology and participation in one of the School's research projects.
BIOT4073.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

BLDG1011.title: Low Rise Building Construction
BLDG1011.description: In Low rise Building Construction, details of the procedure adopted in Australia on commercial and residential projects will be discussed.
BLDG1011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1012.title: Construction Materials
BLDG1012.description: In Construction Materials, details of the major structural material adopted in commercial and residential projects will be covered.
BLDG1012.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1013.title: Introduction to Construction Management & Property
BLDG1013.description: This course introduces broad management principles relevant to the construction and property industry, including global and national construction and property sectors; construction project life cycle; time, cost, and quality management; construction safety; sustainable construction; and human resource management.
BLDG1013.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1014.title: Building Measurement
BLDG1014.description: This course introduces the "Why, What and How" of construction building measurement.
BLDG1014.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1021.title: Industrial & Infrastructure Construction
BLDG1021.description:
The course is designed to extend your knowledge on technologies, systems and processes of Industrial and
Infrastructure Construction (IIC).
BLDG1021.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1022.title: Building Structures
BLDG1022.description:
The aim of this course is to introduce students to the concepts of structural systems and
basic analysis instructions.
BLDG1022.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1023.title: Construction Project Management Theory
BLDG1023.description: This course introduces the principles, methods and processes of project management in the context of the construction industry.
BLDG1023.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG1024.title: Construction & Property Economics
BLDG1024.description: This course has been developed to allow students to gain a deeper understanding of the basic economic issues that are encountered in the construction sector.
BLDG1024.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG2011.title: Building Services
BLDG2011.description: Building Services is concerned with aspects of the built environment that ensure the performance and productivity, comfort, safety and wellbeing of building occupants.
BLDG2011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG2012.title: Construction & Property Law
BLDG2012.description: This course introduces students to the core principles of both commercial law and real property law with a particular focus on laws related to the governance and operation of the building and construction industry in Australia.
BLDG2012.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG2013.title: Construction Estimating
BLDG2013.description: This course aims to offer students the opportunity to develop an understanding of the fundamentals of estimating building costs and competitive bidding practices.
BLDG2013.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG2021.title: High Rise Building Construction
BLDG2021.description: This course introduces high-rise building functional requirements as well as technologies and processes used in high-rise building construction.
BLDG2021.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG2022.title: Procurement & Contract Administration
BLDG2022.description: The course introduces students to procurement methods and the practice of construction contract management.
BLDG2022.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG2023.title: Construction Planning
BLDG2023.description: This course teaches important skills for construction planning and scheduling, e.
BLDG2023.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG3011.title: Organisational & People Management in Construction
BLDG3011.description:
The course offers an introduction to the critical role of human resource management (HRM) to
the construction sector’s efficiency, effectiveness and productivity.
BLDG3011.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG3012.title: Risk, Health & Safety Management
BLDG3012.description: This course provides guidance on characteristics and industry good practices of effective and efficient project risk management and qualitative and quantitative risk assessment methodologies as well as possible risk treatment options including contingency allowances.
BLDG3012.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG3013.title: Digital Construction
BLDG3013.description: In Digital Construction, students will be exposed to the state-of-the -art technology used to deliver projects on a digital platform.
BLDG3013.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG3021.title: Property Development
BLDG3021.description: Several factors influence property development decisions.
BLDG3021.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG3022.title: Construction Project Management Practice Capstone
BLDG3022.description: This Subject involves a major actual UNSW building Capstone Project that provides you with the opportunity to demonstrate and integrate their professional construction project management knowledge and skills acquired throughout their Bachelor of Construction Management & Property course.
BLDG3022.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG3023.title: Construction Business Strategy & Entrepreneurship
BLDG3023.description: This course offers an introduction to contemporary business and entrepreneurship management.
BLDG3023.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4018.title: Building Appraisal & Land Economics
BLDG4018.description: This course provides an introduction to economic principles to the use of land, predominantly in urban areas covering development, investment and the regulatory environment.
BLDG4018.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4019.title: Property & Asset Management
BLDG4019.description: This course provides an introduction to property asset management through a consideration of property market analysis; lease and tenancy management; building maintenance and maintenance economics; strata title management; and taxation in property management.
BLDG4019.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4020.title: Total Building Performance and Management
BLDG4020.description: In Building Performance, details of the major factors impacting the performance of commercial and residential buildings will be covered.
BLDG4020.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4022.title: Construction Cost Management
BLDG4022.description:
This course focusses on fundamentals of cost management in post-contract stage of building
construction projects.
BLDG4022.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4023.title: Construction Value Management
BLDG4023.description: This course develops an understanding of the fundamentals of value management in building design and construction.
BLDG4023.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4024.title: Business Intelligence & Data Analytics
BLDG4024.description: This course is an introduction to research, data analytics and business intelligence (BI), and is of high relevance to the construction and property industries considering the amount of data generated by organisations and their projects.
BLDG4024.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4501.title: Thesis Foundation
BLDG4501.description: This course is a pre-requisite for BLDG 4502 Thesis Program and must be satisfactorily completed before you are eligible to advance to the latter course.
BLDG4501.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

BLDG4504.title: Thesis
BLDG4504.description:
This is the thesis continuation course, following your satisfactory completion of BLDG 4501 Thesis
Foundation.
BLDG4504.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

CDEV1112.title: Creating Your Career: Employability for the Future
CDEV1112.description:
Creating Your Career: Employability for the Future covers four principal topics:
Understanding yourself and developing your employabilityResearching career opportunities and organisations now and into the futureUsing career development competencies to create your careerCommunicating your professional point of difference.

CDEV3000.title: Practice of Work
CDEV3000.description: This course has been designed to enable students to integrate theory with the practice of work.

CDEV3001.title: WIL Experience Term
CDEV3001.description: The WIL Experience Term enables students to work directly with a partner organisation to undertake a substantive industry or community project, either locally or overseas, under supervision from UNSW academic staff.

CEIC1000.title: Sustainable Product Engineering and Design
