CEIC1000.description: This course is an introduction to process/product engineering and design in which the technical, environmental, social, economic and marketing aspects involved in the manufacture of products ranging from everyday consumer goods (food, pharmaceuticals, etc.

CEIC2000.title: Material and Energy Systems
CEIC2000.description: In this course students will learn sufficient thermodynamics and problem solution strategies to be able to apply thermodynamic concepts with material and energy balances to chemical process problems involving several unit operations and involving chemical reactions.

CEIC2002.title: Heat and Mass Transfer
CEIC2002.description: In this course, the principles of transport phenomena introduced previously in fluid flow are extended to heat and mass transport.

CEIC2004.title: Industrial Chemistry for Chemical Engineers
CEIC2004.description: This course covers the main aspects of applied chemistry in a context especially designed for chemical engineers.

CEIC2005.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering
CEIC2005.description: Applied physical chemistry, kinetics and reaction engineering.

CEIC2007.title: Chemical Engineering Lab A
CEIC2007.description: This course is designed to consolidate your understanding of basic principles in chemical engineering and develop your skills in planning, experimental technique including data acquisition, and analysis.

CEIC2009.title: Material and Energy Balances in the Chemical Process Industry
CEIC2009.description: In this course, the relationships between the integration of thermodynamics and mass and energy balance in chemical plants are elucidated.

CEIC3000.title: Process Modelling and Analysis
CEIC3000.description: The previous course name was Chem Eng Fundamentals 3.

CEIC3001.title: Advanced Thermodynamics and Separation
CEIC3001.description: In this course, the student will learn to apply his or her fundamental knowledge of transport phenomena with concepts in thermodynamics to develop models for industrial separation operations, in conjunction with additional study of thermodynamics of phase equilibria for multi-component systems.

CEIC3002.title: Experimental Practice
CEIC3002.description: Advanced laboratory practice, data analysis and technical communications are the focus for this course.

CEIC3003.title: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
CEIC3003.description: Pre requisites: CEIC2001, CEIC2002 and MATH2089.

CEIC3004.title: Process Equipment Design
CEIC3004.description: This course teaches the student about selection and design of chemical process equipment and the use of simulation software as an aid to equipment design.

CEIC3005.title: Process Plant Design
CEIC3005.description: The previous course name was Chem Eng Design 3B.

CEIC3006.title: Process Dynamics and Control
CEIC3006.description: The previous course name was Chem Eng Design 3C.

CEIC3007.title: Chemical Engineering Lab B
CEIC3007.description: This course is designed to develop and extend your skills in designing and executing experimental investigation of chemical engineering problems.

CEIC4000.title: Environment and Sustainability
CEIC4000.description: This course aims to develop a profound understanding of concepts of environmental and social responsibility and professional ethics, both in the wider sense and as they relate to the specific context of chemical engineering and industrial chemistry.

CEIC4001.title: Process Design Project
CEIC4001.description: Please Note: Pre-requisites: at least 144 UOC taken in Industrial Chemistry or Chemical Engineering programs.

CEIC4002.title: Thesis A
CEIC4002.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

CEIC4006.title: Thesis Advanced
CEIC4006.description: Higher level theoretical and experimental research on a selected topic in chemical engineering as proposed in CEIC4002 will be undertaken under the guidance of an academic staff member.

CEIC4007.title: Product Design Project Thesis A
CEIC4007.description: Design and creative development is the engine of growth for economies and industry product portfolios.

CEIC4008.title: Product Design Project Thesis B
CEIC4008.description: Design and creative development is the engine of growth for economies and industry product portfolios.

CEIC4951.title: Research Thesis A
CEIC4951.description: Research Thesis is an inquiry-based learning course that provides an opportunity for students to bring together engineering principles learned through academic study.

CEIC4952.title: Research Thesis B
CEIC4952.description: Research Thesis s an inquiry-based learning course that provides an opportunity for students to bring together engineering principles learned through academic study.

CEIC4953.title: Research Thesis C
CEIC4953.description: Research Thesis is an inquiry-based learning course that provides an opportunity for students to bring together engineering principles learned through academic study.

CEIC4954.title: Research Thesis Extension
CEIC4954.description: This course will provide students with an opportunity to go extend their thesis project by exploring their research problem in more breadth &/or depth.

CEIC6004.title: Advanced Polymers
CEIC6004.description: We will explore exciting macromolecular chemistry in a range of selected cutting edge research fields.

CEIC6005.title: Fuel and Energy
CEIC6005.description: Current energy resources and alternatives for the future.

CEIC6711.title: Complex Fluids Microstructure and Rheology
CEIC6711.description: The link between molecules and the macroscopic properties we measure depends on the microscale and mesoscale structures the molecules form in complex fluids like emulsions, foams, aerosols, and particle dispersions.

CEIC6712.title: Pharmaceutical Design and Engineering
CEIC6712.description: Students will learn how to design, develop and evaluate pharmaceutical and nutraceutical agents in line with research and industry methods, where chemical engineers, nutritionists and medical researchers work together to transform raw materials and small molecular agents to valuable pharma products.

CEIC6789.title: Data-driven Decision Making in Chemical Engineering and Food Science
CEIC6789.description: The recent surge in the volume of data collected owing to technological advances provides opportunities to improve processes and take better decisions across various industries.

CEIC8102.title: Advanced Process Control
CEIC8102.description: Concepts of linear Multi-Input Multi-Output (MIMO) systems, state-space representation of process systems, linear spaces and linear operators, controllability and observability analysis, Lyapunov stability analysis, stability of interconnected systems, linear optimal control, frequency-domain analysis and controller synthesis for MIMO process systems.

CEIC8204.title: Topics in Business Management in Chemical Engineering
CEIC8204.description: The aims of this course are to introduce issues which affect business  decisions encountered by management in the chemical industry.

CEIC8341.title: Membrane Processes
CEIC8341.description: Please note that CEIC2001 (Fluid and particle mechanics) and CEIC2002 (heat and mass transfer) are prerequisites to enrol in CEIC8341.

CHEM1001.title: Introductory Chemistry
CHEM1001.description: Introductory Chemistry is designed for students entering University with little or no previous background in Chemistry.

CHEM1011.title: Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy
CHEM1011.description: This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to one year of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements.

CHEM1021.title: Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life
CHEM1021.description: CHEM1021 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science.

CHEM1031.title: Higher Chemistry 1A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy
CHEM1031.description: This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 12 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements.

CHEM1041.title: Higher Chemistry 1B: Elements, Compounds and Life
CHEM1041.description: CHEM1041 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science.

CHEM1051.title: Higher Chemistry 1A (Medicinal): Atoms, Molecules and Energy
CHEM1051.description: This course builds on an elementary knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 12 chemistry, or CHEM1001 at UNSW) to explore the quantum mechanical structure of atoms leading to an understanding of the periodic trends in the properties of the elements.

CHEM1061.title: Higher Chemistry 1B (Medicinal): Elements, Compounds and Life
CHEM1061.description: CHEM1061 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science.

CHEM1151.title: Introductory Medicinal Chemistry
CHEM1151.description: This course will provide students with an understanding of what medicinal chemistry is and how it is carried out.

CHEM1811.title: Engineering Chemistry 1A
CHEM1811.description: This course builds on an introductory knowledge of chemistry (equivalent to two years of high school chemistry, such as Year 11 and 12 chemistry) to explore the engineering aspects of chemistry.

CHEM1821.title: Engineering Chemistry 1B
CHEM1821.description: This course further develops the introduction to the engineering aspects of chemistry started in CHEM1811.

CHEM1829.title: Biological Chemistry for Optometry Students
CHEM1829.description: CHEM1829 deals with a range of fundamental concepts that can be used to explain various phenomena in chemistry, biology and material science.

CHEM1831.title: Chemistry for Exercise Physiology
CHEM1831.description: Designed for students in the Exercise Physiology program, this course covers the chemistry required to understand atomic and molecular structure, states of matter, thermodynamics, equilibrium chemistry in aqueous solution and introductory kinetics, the chemistry of organic compounds, stereochemistry, functional groups and their reactions especially amines, amides, acids and esters, redox chemistry of oxygen.

CHEM2011.title: Physical Chemistry: Molecules, Energy and Change
CHEM2011.description: Physical Chemistry seeks to explain chemical processes in terms of energy changes and the molecular nature of matter.

CHEM2021.title: Organic Chemistry: Mechanisms and Biomolecules
CHEM2021.description: Organic molecules are at the heart of the chemistry of life and industry.

CHEM2031.title: Inorganic Chemistry: The Elements
CHEM2031.description: This course provides a general introduction to both theoretical and practical aspects of advanced inorganic chemistry.

CHEM2041.title: Analytical Chemistry: Essential Methods
CHEM2041.description: This course teaches the essential methods in analytical chemistry applicable to chemists, biologists, and most other disciplines of science.

CHEM2921.title: Food Chemistry
CHEM2921.description: This course covers the chemical structures and properties of protein, carbohydrate, lipids, minerals, and vitamins, and their functions in food systems.

CHEM2996.title: Introduction to Chemistry Research
CHEM2996.description: This course provides an essential introduction for students undertaking research in the School of Chemistry.

CHEM2999.title: Special Project in Chemistry
CHEM2999.description: This course provides an early introduction to the university research environment through undertaking an authentic short research project under the direction of a Chemistry academic member of staff taking advantage of UNSW's world-class researchers and research facilities.

CHEM3011.title: Quantum Nature of Molecules - from Earth to Space
CHEM3011.description: CHEM3011 builds on previous physical chemistry content and deepens students’ understanding and ability to utilise contemporary computational and experimental methods to solve chemical problems.

CHEM3021.title: Organic Chemistry: Modern Synthetic Strategies
CHEM3021.description: The need for new functional molecules is greater than ever, with ever-growing demand for new therapeutics and materials for the future.

CHEM3031.title: Inorganic Chemistry: Transition Metals and Complexes
CHEM3031.description: This course provides insight into the current state-of-art research where metals are used in technologies such as semiconductors, batteries, solar cells, superconductors, and where metals are used in life such as photochemical processes, nitrogen fixation.

CHEM3051.title: Medicinal Organic Chemistry
CHEM3051.description: The course is focused on presenting the key principles of medicinal chemistry.

CHEM3061.title: Chemistry of Materials
CHEM3061.description: Chemistry is fundamental not just to the design of small molecules, but increasingly to the preparation of materials ranging from hard colloidal nanomaterials to soft complex macromolecular architectures.

CHEM3071.title: The Chemistry of Catalysis, Systems and Biology
CHEM3071.description: Building on students' existing background in both organic and inorganic chemistry, this course provides an understanding of the parallels between the function of synthetic and biological molecules, including enzymes, when it comes to catalysis and the formation of complex and self-assembled structures through intermolecular (supramolecular) interactions.

CHEM3901.title: Environmental Toxicology
CHEM3901.description: Environmental toxicology is concerned with the toxicological effects of environmental chemicals (both natural and anthropogenic) on living organisms.

CHEM3998.title: Advanced Special Project in Chemistry
CHEM3998.description: This course provides a more sophisticated introduction to the university research environment than CHEM2999 through undertaking a more complex short research project which utilises the skills and knowledge obtained by students in their early undergraduate degree.

CHEM4003.title: Advanced Chemistry 4 Honours
CHEM4003.description: Designed for those with a higher level of preparedness in Chemistry.

CHEM4004.title: Advanced Chemistry 4 Honours (Mid-Year Start)
CHEM4004.description: Designed for those with a higher level of preparedness in Chemistry.

CHEM4005.title: Chemical Sciences 4 (Honours)
CHEM4005.description: Designed for those with broad interests in Science but with a wish to specialise in Chemistry.

CHEM4006.title: Honours in Medicinal Chemistry
CHEM4006.description: This Honours year is designed specifically for students enrolled in the Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry program.

CHEM4501.title: Chemistry Project Proposal and Research Skills
CHEM4501.description: Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory.

CHEM4502.title: Chemistry Honours Coursework
CHEM4502.description: Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory.

CHEM4503.title: Medicinal Chemistry Honours Coursework
CHEM4503.description: Medicinal Chemistry Honours coursework is designed to provide students with advanced knowledge relevant to the discipline of Medicinal Chemistry.

CHEM4506.title: Chemistry Honours Project
CHEM4506.description: Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory.

CHEM4512.title: Chemistry Honours Project
CHEM4512.description: Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory.

CHEM4518.title: Chemistry Honours Project 18 UOC
CHEM4518.description: Chemistry Honours Project is a year-long (3 term) research project comprised of a combination of cutting edge research, skills units and theory.

CHEM4524.title: Chemistry Honours Project 24 UOC
CHEM4524.description: This course is designed for students undertaking a full-time Honours year as part of the Bachelor of Medicinal Chemistry (Honours) or undertaking Honours in the School of Chemistry.

CHEM6041.title: Advanced Instrumental Analysis
CHEM6041.description: This course builds on students' existing background in analytical chemistry to develop both theory and practice relating to the latest analytical techniques used in industry and research.

CHEM6701.title: Topics in Contemporary Chemistry A
CHEM6701.description: Topics in contemporary Chemistry A is a premier lecture course run by the School of Chemistry.

CHEN6701.title: Advanced Reaction Engineering
CHEN6701.description: This subject is geared towards senior undergraduate students with interests in the design and optimization of process reaction vessels in the chemicals/petrochemicals, biological/food as well as materials/minerals processing industries.

CHEN6703.title: Advanced Particle Systems Engineering
CHEN6703.description: The course covers lectures and demonstrations on: Particle characterisation and preparation using the latest techniques, floc characterisation and its relevance in separation techniques.

CHEN6706.title: Advanced Transport Phenomena
CHEN6706.description: This course presents a unified and advanced approach to the study of transport phenomena, which unifies the topics of mass, momentum and heat transport.

CHEN6710.title: Chemical process operations
CHEN6710.description: This course aims to develop student's skills in managing a chemical process operation, from a technical and operational standpoint.

CLIM1001.title: Introduction to Climate Change
CLIM1001.description: Why do people disagree so much about climate change? How can you tell fact from fiction in the debate? How do we know climate change is happening and what are the causes? Climate change is now an issue confronting many disciplines, from architecture, engineering and business through to environmental science, public health, law and economics.
CLIM1001.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

CLIM2001.title: Fundamentals of Atmospheric Science
CLIM2001.description: This course covers the basic physical principles and processes which govern our atmosphere and its climate.
CLIM2001.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

CLIM2002.title: Risks and Impacts of a Changing Climate
CLIM2002.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

CLIM3001.title: Climate Systems Science
CLIM3001.description: Analysis of interactions in the climate system (atmosphere, ocean, biosphere, cryosphere), including the complex feedbacks between the Earth's carbon cycle, hydrological cycle, biosphere and key chemical species; observational approaches including uncertainties; statistical methods used to detect and understand environmental changes; modelling techniques including idealised models, process models and comprehensive state-of-the-art climate and Earth system models.
CLIM3001.school: School of Biological, Earth and Environmental Sciences

CODE1110.title: Computational Design Theory 1
CODE1110.description: 'This course addresses architecture’s digital turn and introduces students to historical and contemporary discourses, theoretical concepts and ideas, and architectural projects that have engaged digital technologies and computational design thinking and methods from the late twentieth century onwards.
CODE1110.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

CODE1150.title: Computational Design I (Fundamentals)
CODE1150.description: 'Computational Design I (Fundamentals)' is the first of four Computational Design courses that introduce students to Computational Design.

CODE1161.title: Design Computing
CODE1161.description: The communication and visualisation course introduces students to the simulation, manipulation and visualisation of complex data information.
CODE1161.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

CODE1210.title: Computational Design Theory 2
CODE1210.description: 'The Computational Design Theory II course builds on the foundational knowledge of CODE1110 – Computational Design Theory I, that introduced students to computational thinking and methods in the context of the architectural discipline and practice, to investigate historic and contemporary approaches to representing, conceptualising, and designing the built environment in relationship to digital culture and computing technologies.

CRIM2032.description: All anglo-western criminal justice systems have significant over-representation, at all levels, of people with mental health disorders and cognitive disability.

CRIM2034.title: Crime, Politics and the Media
CRIM2034.description: Crime and justice issues dominate politics, the media and popular culture.
CRIM2034.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM2036.title: Prison and Punishment: Introduction to Penology
CRIM2036.description:
Subject Area: Criminology
This course provides an introduction to penology.
CRIM2036.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM2037.title: Explaining Punishment
CRIM2037.description: In this course you will be introduced to a theoretical and policy-oriented consideration of how and why we punish criminal offending, particularly through the use of imprisonment.
CRIM2037.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM2038.title: Young People and Juvenile Justice
CRIM2038.description: In this course you will develop a critical understanding of the juvenile justice system, as well as the interdisciplinary perspectives on how young people become involved in antisocial behaviour and offending.
CRIM2038.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM2040.title: Criminal Networks and Organised Crime
CRIM2040.description: This course examines organised crime and criminal networks across a number of contexts including drug trafficking, terrorism, and the trade in illicit commodities.
CRIM2040.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM2041.title: Crime and Punishment in Historical Perspective
CRIM2041.description: This course examines the history of criminal justice systems from the eighteenth to the twentieth century.
CRIM2041.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM2042.title: Explaining Crime
CRIM2042.description: What causes crime? Who is more likely to offend and why? What can we do to prevent crime? How does criminological theory help us understand the current criminal justice system? This course builds upon your understanding of the major theoretical approaches to crime and criminal justice, and seeks to answer the above questions.
CRIM2042.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3000.title: Criminology in Practice
CRIM3000.description: This capstone course draws together key concepts, themes and debates in criminology and encourages the application of these to current issues.
CRIM3000.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3011.title: Crime Prevention Policy
CRIM3011.description: In this course you will map the evolution and adoption of crime prevention policy both within Australia and internationally in the context of broader social policy and shifting political landscapes.
CRIM3011.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3012.title: Violence and Victimisation
CRIM3012.description: In this course you will critically analyse crime prevention strategies and criminal justice responses to violent crime.
CRIM3012.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3015.title: State Crime and Human Rights
CRIM3015.description: This module draws on some of the material previously taught in the criminology elective Crime, Power and Human Rights (CRIM 2018).
CRIM3015.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3017.title: Cybercrime
CRIM3017.description: ‘Cybercrime’ examines how the online world has borne new crimes and law enforcement responses, as well as investigates how the computer has become both a target of attack and a tool for criminal activity.
CRIM3017.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3018.title: Victims' Rights
CRIM3018.description: In this course you will examine victims' rights and victimology as emerging areas of criminological theory and practice.
CRIM3018.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3019.title: Restorative Justice
CRIM3019.description: Explores the theory and practice of restorative justice; that is, conflict resolution that involve victims, offenders and communities in a joint decision-making process rather than traditional legal and court-based responses.
CRIM3019.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3020.title: The Criminal Trial
CRIM3020.description: In this course you will examine the conduct of criminal trials in Australia and other countries.
CRIM3020.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3022.title: Public Health and Corrections
CRIM3022.description: Prisoners, community-based offenders, and other detainee groups exert huge, social, health and economic impacts on the community and pose significant challenges for society.
CRIM3022.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3024.title: Issues in Drug Policy
CRIM3024.description: In Issues in Drug Policy (CRIM3024) you will take a multi-disciplinary approach in the examination of Australian and international drug laws and policies, drawing on a wide range of historical, socio-legal, political and criminological research.
CRIM3024.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM3025.title: Criminology Work Integrated Learning Placement
CRIM3025.description: This course provides you with the unique opportunity to gain practical experience and deeper understanding of the criminal justice and related agencies.
CRIM3025.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM4001.title: Criminology Honours
CRIM4001.description: A 6 UOC thesis in Criminology to be completed as part of the 30 UOC of thesis component in the Honours Program.
CRIM4001.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM4002.title: Criminology Honours
CRIM4002.description: A 12 UOC thesis in Criminology to be completed as part of the 30 UOC of thesis component in the Honours Program.
CRIM4002.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CRIM4003.title: Criminology Honours
CRIM4003.description: An 18 UOC thesis in Criminology to be completed as part of the 30 UOC of thesis component in the Honours Program.
CRIM4003.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

CVEN1300.title: Engineering Mechanics for Civil Engineers
CVEN1300.description: An introductory subject in engineering mechanics dealing with Statics (the equilibrium of objects, structures and fluids) and Dynamics (the mechanics of bodies in motion).
CVEN1300.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN1701.title: Environmental Principles and Systems
CVEN1701.description: This is an introductory course in techniques to analyse the environmental impact of corporations and economies in regions, using operations research, environmental material accounting and environmental risk assessment.
CVEN1701.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2002.title: Civil and Environmental Engineering Computations
CVEN2002.description: An introduction to the application of advanced analytical, statistical and numerical techniques to the solution of engineering problems relevant to civil and environmental engineers and surveyors.
CVEN2002.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2101.title: Engineering Construction
CVEN2101.description: An introduction to construction systems and processes.
CVEN2101.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2201.title: Soil Mechanics
CVEN2201.description: An introductory course to fundamentals of soil mechanics.
CVEN2201.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2301.title: Mechanics of Solids for Civil Engineers
CVEN2301.description: An introduction to the strength of materials: revision of statics and properties of sections; 3 dimensional statics; concepts of stress and strain; stress-strain relationships; bars under axial force, bending moment, shear force, torsion; deflections due to bending and shear; combined stresses; stresses and strains at a point; principal stresses and strains; failure criterion; slender column buckling.
CVEN2301.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2302.title: Materials and Structures
CVEN2302.description: This course consists of a material and a structural design strand.
CVEN2302.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2303.title: Structural Analysis and Modelling
CVEN2303.description: This course introduces students to structural analysis and computer modelling of structures.
CVEN2303.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2401.title: Sustainable Transport and Highway Engineering
CVEN2401.description: The course is presented as 2 strands.
CVEN2401.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2402.title: Transport Engineering and Environmental Sustainability
CVEN2402.description: The course is presented as 2 strands.
CVEN2402.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2501.title: Principles of Water Engineering
CVEN2501.description:
Assumed Knowledge: CVEN1300 or equivalent
The object of CVEN2501 is to introduce students to the practice of water engineering.
CVEN2501.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2701.title: Water and Atmospheric Chemistry
CVEN2701.description: This course aims to provide an introduction to water chemistry and atmospheric chemistry, as a foundation for understanding both the natural processes in these environments and the effects of pollution on them.
CVEN2701.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN2702.title: Engineering Computations for Environmental Engineers
CVEN2702.description: An introduction to the application of advanced analytical, statistical and numerical techniques to the solution of environmental engineering problems.
CVEN2702.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3031.title: Civil and Environmental Engineering Practice
CVEN3031.description: This course is about the doing of engineering design.
CVEN3031.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3101.title: Engineering Operations and Control
CVEN3101.description: This subject is an introduction to the general principles of the organisation and control of engineering operations.
CVEN3101.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3201.title: Applied Geotechnics and Engineering Geology
CVEN3201.description: This course covers two important areas of geotechnical engineering: geology and applied geotechnics.
CVEN3201.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3202.title: Soil Mechanics
CVEN3202.description: An introductory course to fundamentals of soil mechanics.
CVEN3202.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3203.title: Applied Geotechnics and Engineering Geology
CVEN3203.description: This course covers two important areas of geotechnical engineering: geology and applied geotechnics.
CVEN3203.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3301.title: Structural Analysis and Modelling
CVEN3301.description: This course introduces students to structural analysis and computer modelling of structures.
CVEN3301.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3303.title: Steel Structures
CVEN3303.description: A course on the design concepts and design of structural elements subject to bending, shear and combined bending and axial compression.
CVEN3303.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3304.title: Concrete Structures
CVEN3304.description: A course on concrete materials and the design of reinforced concrete structural elements subject to bending, shear and combined bending and axial compression.
CVEN3304.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3401.title: Sustainable Transport and Highway Engineering
CVEN3401.description: The course is presented in 2 strands.
CVEN3401.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3402.title: Transport Engineering and Environmental Sustainability
CVEN3402.description: The course is presented in 2 strands.
CVEN3402.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3501.title: Water Resources Engineering
CVEN3501.description: The object of CVEN3501 is to introduce engineering hydrology and its application in water resources management and flood estimation.
CVEN3501.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3502.title: Water and Wastewater Engineering
CVEN3502.description: Assumed Knowledge: MATS1101To introduce students to the principles of public health engineering, water and wastewater treatment, water supply systems, wastewater disposal systems, stormwater systems, biosolids treatment and management, and water quality and contamination indicators.
CVEN3502.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3701.title: Environmental Frameworks, Law and Economics
CVEN3701.description: ASSUMED KNOWLEDGE CVEN1701This course builds on the introduction to EISs in CVEN1701 to provide details of EIS methods, and the ISO14001 Environmental Management System framework.
CVEN3701.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3702.title: Solid Wastes and Contaminant Transport
CVEN3702.description: An introduction to waste management systems, from generation to treatment and disposal; including waste characterisation, waste minimisation, transfer stations, recycling facilities, composting and landfill design.
CVEN3702.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN3731.title: Environmental Engineering Practice
CVEN3731.description: This course will use negotiation as a framework for the further development of analysis, communication and teamwork skills.
CVEN3731.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4002.title: Design Practice A
CVEN4002.description: This is a project-based course where, working in groups of four, students undertake a major multi-disciplinary design project.
CVEN4002.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4003.title: Design Practice B
CVEN4003.description: A second project-based course where, working in groups of four, students undertake a major multi-disciplinary design project involving discipline areas that are different from those dealt with in CVEN4002 Design Practice A.
CVEN4003.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4030.title: Honours Thesis A
CVEN4030.description: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken prior to CVEN4031 Honours Thesis B.

CVEN4031.title: Honours Thesis B
CVEN4031.description: This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after the satisfactory completion of CVEN4030 Honours Thesis A.

CVEN4032.title: Higher Honours Thesis A

CVEN4033.title: Higher Honours Thesis B
CVEN4033.description: This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after to CVEN4032 Higher Honours Thesis A.
CVEN4033.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4040.title: Research Thesis A
CVEN4040.description: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken prior to CVEN4041 Research Thesis B.
CVEN4040.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4041.title: Research Thesis B
CVEN4041.description: This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after the completion of CVEN4040 Research Thesis A usually in the proceeding semester.
CVEN4041.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4050.title: Thesis A
CVEN4050.description: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken before CVEN4051 Thesis B, usually in the proceeding semester.
CVEN4050.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4051.title: Thesis B
CVEN4051.description: This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after the completion of CVEN4050 Thesis A, usually in the proceeding semester.
CVEN4051.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4101.title: Problem Solving for Engineers
CVEN4101.description: Engineers are characterized as being problem solvers.
CVEN4101.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4102.title: Operations and Projects
CVEN4102.description: Most engineering work fits within what is broadly referred to as operations and projects.
CVEN4102.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4103.title: Engineering Contracts
CVEN4103.description: The majority of engineering work is procured through contracts, within an array of delivery methods.
CVEN4103.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4104.title: Sustainability in Construction
CVEN4104.description: This course will provide fundamental knowledge and hands-on experience for practising sustainability in construction.
CVEN4104.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4106.title: Construction Practicum
CVEN4106.description: This course involves students working on a hands on infrastructure project.
CVEN4106.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4201.title: Rock and Slope Engineering
CVEN4201.description: Description of rock mass and discontinuities; rock strength and failure criteria.
CVEN4201.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4202.title: Advanced Topics in Geotechnical Engineering
CVEN4202.description: Topic 1: Application of computer simulation techniques to geotechnical engineering problems.
CVEN4202.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4204.title: Ground Improvement and Monitoring Techniques
CVEN4204.description: Prerequisites: CVEN2201, CVEN3201 or equivalentAssessment of the suitability and design of stabilisation techniques for difficult foundation soils including instrumentation and application observational techniques to geotechnical engineering.
CVEN4204.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4300.title: Structures Practicum
CVEN4300.description: A practical course that involves both advanced analysis and design of an engineered structure to solve a given problem.
CVEN4300.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4301.title: Advanced Concrete Structures
CVEN4301.description: A course on the advanced analysis and design of concrete structures for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering.
CVEN4301.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4305.title: Advanced Materials Technology
CVEN4305.description: Concrete: high performance concrete; new methods of workability measurement; methods of placing-pumping, spraying; mix design methods; special concrete mixes.
CVEN4305.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4307.title: Steel and Composite Structures
CVEN4307.description: A course on the advanced analysis and design of structural elements for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering.
CVEN4307.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4308.title: Structural Dynamics
CVEN4308.description: Fundamentals of structural dynamic analysis for discrete and continuous structures; free and forced vibration of single and multiple degrees of freedom systems; normal modal analysis; transient dynamic analysis by numerical integration; response spectrum; introduction to nonlinear dynamic analysis of structures; wind, earthquake, human-induced vibration and wave loads: definitions and effects on structures; design of structures to resist dynamic loads.
CVEN4308.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4309.title: Sustainable Timber Engineering
CVEN4309.description: Structural and Construction Engineers may be responsible for the design and construction of timber structures; from timber frame housing to high rise engineered timber structures.
CVEN4309.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4310.title: Deformation Monitoring Surveys
CVEN4310.description: This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for deformation monitoring to civil engineering students with an interest in structures or geotechnical.
CVEN4310.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4401.title: Urban Transport Planning
CVEN4401.description: Analytical techniques for urban land use/transport planning practice.
CVEN4401.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4402.title: Transport Systems - Part 1: Network Analysis
CVEN4402.description: Definition of basic traffic elements, zero flow travel time, capacity, impedance flow relationship.
CVEN4402.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4403.title: Transport Systems - Part 2: Queuing Theory
CVEN4403.description: Historical introduction to transport systems and development of various transport modes, road (vehicles, pedestrians, cycles), conveyor, rail, sea and air.
CVEN4403.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4404.title: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering
CVEN4404.description: CVEN4404: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering aims to provide undergraduate students the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute as a practicing Traffic Engineer.
CVEN4404.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4405.title: Human Factors in Civil and Transport Engineering
CVEN4405.description: Human factors is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions between humans and other elements of a system.
CVEN4405.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4501.title: Catchment Modelling and Water Resources Management
CVEN4501.description: An introduction to lumped and distributed catchment runoff models; an introduction on the rationale used for model verification and validation, model development and parameter estimation; Bayesian methods for estimating model parameters; reservoir and channel routing; reservoir operation and design; wetland design and conceptual processes; introduction to stochastic generation of hydrologic time series in the context  of water resources management.
CVEN4501.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4502.title: Coastal Engineering
CVEN4502.description: Theory of periodic waves in coastal waters.
CVEN4502.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4503.title: Groundwater Resource Investigation
CVEN4503.description: Review of groundwater occurrence in Australia.
CVEN4503.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4504.title: Advanced Water and Wastewater Treatment
CVEN4504.description: Detailed examination of unit processes used in water and wastewater treatment including chemical selection, dosing and mixing, coagulation, flocculation, clarification, filtration and disinfection technology in water treatment and sedimentation and aerobic and anaerobic biological processes in wastewater treatment.
CVEN4504.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4505.title: River Engineering
CVEN4505.description: Professional elective that in any offering may include various combinations of the following topics:- river morphology, river engineering and stream remediation; models for channel and river routing; model theory, selection, calibration, validation and reliability; models may include Muskingham, kinematic wave, non-inertial and diffusion and dynamic wave; sediment and pollutant transport methods and models including plug-flow and advection-dispersion in both coupled and uncoupled applications; hydraulic control structures; estuarine classification and density structure; tides, water level response, mixing processes and flushing of rivers and estuarties; hydrodynamic stratification and algal dynamics; random walk and box models; biochemical processes in rivers and estuaries.
CVEN4505.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4507.title: Advanced Water Engineering
CVEN4507.description: Advanced closed conduit and open channel hydraulic design, designing for peak pump efficiency, sedimentation engineering, reservoir behaviour and design, estimation of large and extreme floods, advanced topics in hydrological design.
CVEN4507.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4701.title: Planning Sustainable Infrastructure
CVEN4701.description: The course enables engineers to analyse and design sustainable infrastructure to support the needs of regional economies and populations.
CVEN4701.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4702.title: Hazardous Waste Treatment
CVEN4702.description: Waste audits and characterisation of hazardous wastes in regions and industries; control of generation and transport of hazardous waste, manifest systems; waste minimisation; on-site treatment methods; integrated off-site treatment facilities; management of residues from treatment facilities; introduction to planning of regional hazardous waste management systems.
CVEN4702.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4703.title: Advanced Water Quality Principles
CVEN4703.description: Fundamental aspects of the chemistry and biology of aquatic environments are reviewed and extended enabling analysis and interpretation of processes occurring in surface and ground waters as well as water and wastewater treatment systems.
CVEN4703.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4705.title: Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management
CVEN4705.description: An introduction to sustainable engineering principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented.
CVEN4705.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4800.title: Satellite Remote Sensing and Applications
CVEN4800.description: This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for satellite remote sensing to civil and environmental engineering students.
CVEN4800.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4951.title: Research Thesis A
CVEN4951.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.
CVEN4951.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4952.title: Research Thesis B
CVEN4952.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.
CVEN4952.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN4953.title: Research Thesis C
CVEN4953.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.
CVEN4953.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9405.title: Urban Transport Planning Practice
CVEN9405.description: Analytical techniques for urban land use/transport planning practice.
CVEN9405.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9415.title: Transport Systems Part 2
CVEN9415.description: Historical introduction to transport systems and development of various transport modes, road (vehicles, pedestrians, cycles), conveyor, rail, sea and air.
CVEN9415.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9612.title: Catchment and Water Resources Modelling
CVEN9612.description: Processes, generation and modelling of catchment surface runoff quantity and quality; a broad range of surface runoff and water quality models ranging from simple to process based will be considered; selection, calibration, validation and reliability of the various models is presented; water resources data, analysis and modelling including considerations of data sources, errors, time series analysis, stochastic models and extension of hydrological records; stochastic reservoir analysis; optimisation in water resources.
CVEN9612.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9620.title: Channels, Rivers and Estuaries
CVEN9620.description: Models for routing of flows along channels and rivers will be presented including model theory, selection, calibration, validation and reliability; models will include Muskingham, kinematic wave, non-inertial and diffusion and dynamic wave; sediment and pollutant transport water quality methods and models will also be presented including plug-flow and advection-dispersion in both coupled and uncoupled applications; estuarine classification and density structure; tides, water level response, mixing processes and flushing of estuaries; estuarine difference models including hydrodynamic stratification and algal dynamics; random walk and box models; biochemical processes in estuaries.
CVEN9620.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9640.title: Coastal Engineering
CVEN9640.description: Waves in coastal waters including theory, measurement, analysis, forecasting, growth, refraction, diffraction, shoaling and breaking processes; coastal and beach processes including tides, storms, currents, elevated water levels, morphology, sediment transport mechanisms, beach erosion and nourishment, longshore transport, prediction and modelling of shoreline change; wave forces on coastal and ocean structures with application to engineering design of harbours, breakwaters, seawalls, piles, decks, marinas, pipelines and outfalls.
CVEN9640.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9806.title: Prestressed Concrete Design
CVEN9806.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9809.title: Reinforced Concrete Design
CVEN9809.description: A dynamic course in the design of reinforced concrete structures to AS3600-2009 and international standards using advanced methods of analysis and design.
CVEN9809.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9818.title: Bridge Engineering
CVEN9818.description: Introduction to bridge engineering; site selection, type selection, bridge hydraulics, design philosophies.
CVEN9818.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9820.title: Computational Structural Mechanics
CVEN9820.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9822.title: Steel and Composite Structures
CVEN9822.description: A course on the advanced analysis and design of structural elements for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering.
CVEN9822.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9824.title: Advanced Materials Technology
CVEN9824.description: Concrete: high performance concrete; new methods of workability measurement; methods of placing-pumping, spraying; mix design methods; special concrete mixes.
CVEN9824.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9826.title: Advanced Mechanics of Structures and Materials
CVEN9826.description: A course in advanced mechanics of structures and materials for higher degree research students, and graduate students that require, or desire, a higher capability in the application of elasticity, plasticity and fracture to analysis of structures and structural materials.
CVEN9826.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9840.title: Structural Health Monitoring Fundamentals and Practices
CVEN9840.description: Structural health monitoring (SHM) refers to the process of design and implementing a condition monitoring and characterization strategy for engineering structures [1].
CVEN9840.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9881.title: Hazardous Waste Management
CVEN9881.description: Waste audits and characterisation of hazardous wastes in regions and industries; control of generation and transport of hazardous waste, manifest systems; waste minimisation; on-site treatment methods; integrated off-site treatment facilities; management of residues from treatment facilities; introduction to planning of regional hazardous waste management systems.
CVEN9881.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

CVEN9884.title: Environmental Chemical and Microbial Processes
CVEN9884.description: Application of chemical principles to aqueous systems; pH and alkalinity, solubility and precipitation, complexation, redox and surface chemistry.
CVEN9884.school: School of Civil and Environmental Engineering

DART1100.title: Studio Art Practice 1
DART1100.description: Studio Art Practice 1 is the first in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice.
DART1100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1101.title: Studio Art Practice 2
DART1101.description: Studio Art Practice 2 is the second in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice.
DART1101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1110.title: Drawing 1: Foundations
DART1110.description: Drawing is a fundamental human endeavour through which we can see, discover, imagine, and create.
DART1110.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1111.title: Life Drawing
DART1111.description: This course provides an opportunity for students to study life drawing.
DART1111.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1120.title: Painting 1: Foundations
DART1120.description: This course is a studio focused introduction to painting that prepares you for further individual development as you work towards a professional career in the context of contemporary art.
DART1120.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1121.title: Painting and the Body
DART1121.description: This studio course introduces you to the creative and conceptual principles for making paintings of and about the human form.
DART1121.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1130.title: Photography 1: Foundations
DART1130.description: This course introduces you to the fundamentals of traditional darkroom photography practices.
DART1130.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1131.title: Digital Fine Art Photography
DART1131.description: This course places emphasis on the development of ideas and concepts of photography within the context of digital culture and contemporary art.
DART1131.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1140.title: Printmaking 1: Foundations
DART1140.description: The print, as a way of presenting and broadly circulating innovative ideas, is a constant presence in contemporary life.
DART1140.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1141.title: Custom Printing
DART1141.description: This unique course emphasises printmaking as a collaborative and community-oriented practice.
DART1141.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1142.title: Printmaking: Lithography
DART1142.description: Printmaking: Lithography offers studio-based instruction in a range of lithographic skills from image development using crayon, tusche, photo transfer and black manner methods through to several printing strategies that work independently or in combination with other printing processes.
DART1142.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1150.title: Sculpture 1: Foundations
DART1150.description: Expanded sculpture practices and conversations play a central role in the contemporary art world today in Australia and internationally.
DART1150.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1151.title: Sculpture Performance & Installation: Visual Poetics
DART1151.description: This studio based course, SPI: Visual Poetics, focuses on the sophisticated poetic languages deployed by artists to represent their ideas, such as heightened, immersive aesthetics, parodox, irony, metaphor, and symbolism.
DART1151.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1191.title: Ceramics: Method and Meaning
DART1191.description: This course explores the ceramic object as a metaphor for human form, introducing you to the range of studio knowledge, skills and attitudes that form a foundation for the Ceramics studio stream in Design, Art and Media studies.
DART1191.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1192.title: Fine Arts Field Studies
DART1192.description: This course is designed to enable students to experience the practical applications of a concentrated time in the field using a variety of media and motifs derived from a first hand encounter with a specific landscape.
DART1192.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1200.title: Media Arts Gateway 1
DART1200.description: Media Arts Gateway 1 is an introductory course designed to orient you in the Media Arts program, and provide you with opportunities to develop foundational skills and knowledge in media arts.
DART1200.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1201.title: Media Arts Gateway 2
DART1201.description: In this course, you will build on your foundational skills and knowledge in Media Arts adding new skills with a particular focus on interaction.
DART1201.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1210.title: Animation 1
DART1210.description: This course introduces you to the creative and adaptive fundamentals of animation.
DART1210.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1220.title: Visual Effects 1
DART1220.description: This course introduces you to the key principles and approaches for working with and in the sculptural space of 3D Computer Generated Imagery (CGI).
DART1220.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1230.title: Moving Image 1
DART1230.description: This course introduces you to the key creative and conceptual principles for working with video and moving images.
DART1230.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1240.title: Sound 1
DART1240.description: This course introduces you to the key creative principles and skills for working with sound, whether as a standalone medium or as part of a sound installation or audio-visual work.
DART1240.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1250.title: Interactive Media 1
DART1250.description: This course introduces you to creative computer programming as a medium in media arts contexts.
DART1250.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1300.title: Histories of Contemporary Art: Part 1
DART1300.description: This course introduces you to the histories and contexts that inform the major themes of contemporary art.
DART1300.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1301.title: Histories of Contemporary Art: Part 2
DART1301.description: This course introduces you to recent histories and contexts that inform the major themes of contemporary art.
DART1301.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1302.title: Theories of Art History and Culture
DART1302.description: This course investigates major theories and methods applied to the study of art history and culture in the modern period.
DART1302.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1303.title: Theories and Practices of Cross-Disciplinary Art
DART1303.description: This course examines the evolution, theorisation and interpretation of experimental art engaged in dialogue with other cultural and social practices.
DART1303.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1310.title: Australian Art
DART1310.description: This course introduces you to ‘the canon’ of Australian Art in order to critically engage with and debate the construction of official histories of art.
DART1310.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1340.title: Contexts for Art
DART1340.description: The course exposes you to the different types of contemporary art exhibited locally - in public galleries, dealer galleries, contemporary art spaces, artist run initiatives, community centres and non-art spaces such as shopping malls.
DART1340.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1350.title: Media Arts Histories
DART1350.description: This course traces the key practices, themes, and approaches that have shaped contemporary media arts practice.
DART1350.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1351.title: Critical Discourses in Media Arts
DART1351.description: This course focuses on the key themes and theories that inform contemporary media arts practice.
DART1351.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART1390.title: Theories of the Image
DART1390.description: This course provides you with an introduction to ways of understanding and evaluating the making, reception and theoretical understandings of images in our culture.
DART1390.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2100.title: Studio Art Practice 3
DART2100.description: Studio Art Practice 3 is the third in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice.
DART2100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2101.title: Studio Art Practice 4
DART2101.description: Studio Art Practice 4 is the fourth in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice.
DART2101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2110.title: Drawing 2: Studio Processes
DART2110.description: This course expands your skills and knowledge in drawing by focusing on the imaginative, narrative, abstract, and spatial potentials of the medium.
DART2110.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2120.title: Painting 2: Studio Processes
DART2120.description: Building on your foundational skills and knowledge in painting, this course helps you to develop and discover your individual painting language.
DART2120.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2130.title: Photography 2: Studio Processes
DART2130.description: This course builds your skills and knowledge in contemporary photographic practice by introducing you to the principles and techniques of studio lighting for still photography.
DART2130.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2140.title: Printmaking 2: Studio Processes
DART2140.description: Building on your foundational skills and knowledge in printmaking, this studio-based course will help you to develop intermediate and advanced matrix-based and screen printing techniques.
DART2140.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2141.title: Advanced Custom Printing
DART2141.description: Building on your previous experiences in printmaking, this course asks you to assume a leadership role in the setting of an artist residency program, providing opportunities for you to work with visiting artists in the studio.
DART2141.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2150.title: Sculpture 2: Studio Processes
DART2150.description: This course develops your skills and knowledge in 'expanded' sculptural practice through a focus on the iterative and process-based potentials of the medium.
DART2150.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2190.title: Creative Experimentation
DART2190.description: ‘Creative Experimentation’ is designed to help you experience the full potential of your own creativity by engaging in experimental art, design or digital media practices.
DART2190.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2210.title: Animation 2
DART2210.description: This course allows you to develop your practical, technical, and conceptual skills in Animation.
DART2210.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2211.title: Animation 3
DART2211.description: This course further enriches your media arts practice by engaging you with a range of advanced processes, technologies, and techniques in animation.
DART2211.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2220.title: Visual Effects 2
DART2220.description: This course focuses on how 3D Computer Generated Imagery (CGI) and Visual Effects have become important mediums of creative experimentation.
DART2220.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2221.title: Visual Effects 3
DART2221.description: This course supports you in exploring how Computer Generated Imagery (CGI) and Visual Effects strategies are used to realise complex creative ideas.
DART2221.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2230.title: Moving Image 2: Studio Processes
DART2230.description: This course enables you to further develop your creative and technical skills in contemporary moving image practice.
DART2230.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2231.title: Moving Image 3: Advanced Practice
DART2231.description: This course supports you to explore the expanded potentials of contemporary moving image practice.
DART2231.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2240.title: Sound 2
DART2240.description: This course provides you with opportunities to further develop and explore your sound practice by constructing screen-based audiovisual works that focus on sound as a storytelling component.
DART2240.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2241.title: Sound 3
DART2241.description: This course supports you in creating a major sound or audiovisual work that draws on and questions a range of histories and definitions of the medium.
DART2241.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2250.title: Interactive Media 2
DART2250.description: This course examines the critical and creative potentials of human-computer interfaces in media arts practice.
DART2250.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2251.title: Interactive Media 3
DART2251.description: This course provides you with the opportunity to conceive and create interactive and responsive media installations that consider audience engagements and spatial environments.
DART2251.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2310.title: Right Here Right Now: Aboriginal Art Since 1984
DART2310.description: This course aims to challenge the mainstream view that Aboriginal art exists only in the Desert or the Top End regions of Australia through a study of exhibitions, writings and films from 'Koori Art 84' through to the present day.
DART2310.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2311.title: East Asian Contemporary Art
DART2311.description: This course provides a critical introduction to contemporary art in and from East Asia.
DART2311.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2320.title: Art and the Body
DART2320.description: This course concentrates on contemporary art and gender, sexuality and the body.
DART2320.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2321.title: Sensing the Arts
DART2321.description: This course will expand your knowledge and understanding of the role of the senses in recent and contemporary arts practices.
DART2321.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2330.title: Ecomedia Art Practices
DART2330.description: This course provides an introduction to a diverse range of media art practices that connect with environmental themes.
DART2330.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2331.title: Data Aesthetics
DART2331.description: This course examines contemporary theories and practices relating to data and information visualisation and data rendering, in various forms, as applied in relation to digital media, new media arts, art, design and processes and practices at the nexus of art and science.
DART2331.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART2341.title: Art, Exhibitions, and Institutions
DART2341.description: This course reviews current research and theoretical frameworks on museums and art museums.
DART2341.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3100.title: Studio Art Practice 5
DART3100.description: Studio Art Practice 5 is the fifth in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice throughout the BFA program.
DART3100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3101.title: Studio Art Practice 6
DART3101.description: Studio Art Practice 6 is the sixth in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice.
DART3101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3110.title: Drawing 3: Advanced Practice
DART3110.description: This course focuses on expanding the artistic strategies, concepts, and vocabulary of your drawing practice in the context of contemporary art.
DART3110.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3120.title: Painting 3: Advanced Practice
DART3120.description: This course focuses on advancing your self-initiated painting practice in the context of contemporary art.
DART3120.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3130.title: Photography 3: Advanced Practice
DART3130.description: This course allows you to expand and deepen your photographic practice in contemporary art contexts.
DART3130.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3140.title: Printmaking 3: Advanced Practice
DART3140.description: This course seeks to reinforce and extend your theoretical, conceptual, technical, and analytical skills in contemporary printmaking.
DART3140.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3150.title: Sculpture 3: Advanced Practice
DART3150.description: This course allows you to extend your sculptural practice by creating a new body of work ready for exhibition.
DART3150.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3200.title: Media Arts Project 1
DART3200.description: This course enables you to extend your media arts practice by planning and working towards a major self-initiated work.
DART3200.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3201.title: Media Arts Project 2
DART3201.description: This course enables you to extend your media arts practice by creating a resolved major self-initiated work.
DART3201.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3310.title: Art in the 21st Century
DART3310.description: What defines art of the 21st century? How does one approach the art that reflects and shapes our present? This undergraduate course offers students a critical toolkit through which to engage and develop understandings of art of in the 21st century.
DART3310.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3320.title: Art, Gender, and Sexuality
DART3320.description: This course looks at the human body and its representation over time and across diverse contexts.
DART3320.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3321.title: Affect in Art
DART3321.description: This course explores contemporary and recent art and design in the context of new thinking about affect.
DART3321.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3330.title: Art and the Anthropocene
DART3330.description: This course engages with speculative fiction, design, and contemporary art to explore creative practices in a new geologic era marked by the impact of humans on the earth.
DART3330.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3331.title: Peripheral Visions: The Ethnographic Camera
DART3331.description: This course tracks the vital role of the camera in documentary, history, and the production of the real (archive, witness, testimony).
DART3331.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3340.title: Socially Engaged Art
DART3340.description: This course will trace the emergence of Socially Engaged Art as a post-Relational response to the urgencies of contemporary life.
DART3340.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3341.title: Writing as Practice
DART3341.description: Writing as Practice examines contemporary critical and creative writing.
DART3341.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3342.title: World Biennales: Field Trip
DART3342.description: This course offers first-hand experience of biennales in various parts of the world.
DART3342.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3390.title: Critical Theories of Photography
DART3390.description: This course investigates major theories of photography from the Nineteenth Century up to the present.
DART3390.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART3391.title: Art and Everyday Life
DART3391.description: This course examines the practices of art and of criticism in an era characterised by the pervasiveness of mass media and the aestheticisation of everyday life.
DART3391.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART4101.title: Fine Arts Honours Research Project 1
DART4101.description: Fine Arts Honours Research Project 1 is a 12 UOC course designed to support you in initiating and establishing your Honours research project.
DART4101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART4102.title: Fine Arts Honours Research Project 2
DART4102.description: Fine Arts Honours Research Project 2 is a 12 UOC core course in the Fine Arts Honours program.
DART4102.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART4201.title: Media Arts Honours Research Project 1
DART4201.description: Media Arts Honours Research Project 1 is a 12 UOC course designed to support you in initiating and establishing your Honours research project.
DART4201.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART4202.title: Media Arts Honours Research Project 2
DART4202.description: Media Arts Honours Research Project 2 is a 12 UOC core course in the Media Arts Honours program.
DART4202.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART4300.title: Contemporary Art Theories and Methods
DART4300.description: This course introduces you to advanced theoretical frameworks and approaches in contemporary art research.
DART4300.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DART4301.title: Art Theory Honours Research Project
DART4301.description: Art Theory Honours Research Project is a 12 UOC core course in the Art Theory Honours program.
DART4301.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DATA1001.title: Introduction to Data Science and Decisions
DATA1001.description: This course will be taught as a number of distinct, but related, topics covering the fundamentals of Data Science as it is applied in Mathematics and Statistics, Computer Science, and Economics.

DATA3001.title: Data Science and Decisions in Practice
DATA3001.description: This is the capstone course for the Data Science and Decisions program.

DDES1100.title: Design Studio 1 - Design Narratives
DDES1100.description: This course introduces you to contemporary design as an integrated practice, which involves creative understanding and engagement with design elements, principles, contexts, experimentation and research.
DDES1100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1101.title: Design Studio 2 - Design Communication
DDES1101.description: Design Studio 2 builds on the fundamental principles and processes of design as learnt in Design Studio 1.
DDES1101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1110.title: 3D Visualisation 1 - 3D Virtual Objects
DDES1110.description: This foundation studio course will develop your understanding of creative 3D computer visualisation.
DDES1110.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1120.title: Object 1 - Objects and the Hand
DDES1120.description: This course introduces you to object-based design by emphasising thinking-through-making; an iterative design process that involves critical evaluation to creatively explore and generate ideas throughout the making process.
DDES1120.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1130.title: Experience 1 - Spaces and Senses
DDES1130.description: In this course, you will explore the way people experience and interact with space, connecting this with ideas of the body, materiality, culture and spectacle.
DDES1130.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1140.title: Graphics 1 - Image and Type
DDES1140.description: This course offers you an introductory opportunity to develop critical skills in the creation of graphic images through photography and various types of illustration.
DDES1140.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1150.description: Interaction design focuses upon the creation of cohesive user experiences, typically but not exclusively associated with digital systems, for products, websites, environments and services.
DDES1150.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1160.title: Textiles 1 - Concepts and Context
DDES1160.description: This course will introduce you to the narrative aspect of textiles, and their story telling ability via patterns, materials and construction.
DDES1160.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1200.title: Design History and Theory 1
DDES1200.description: This course will provide you with an overview of the historical context of design and introduce you to the core principles and theories that underpin design history.
DDES1200.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1201.description: In this course, you will investigate the central question, “what is design?” and consider key theories that will explore this question from a number of different historical and contemporary perspectives.
DDES1201.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES1290.title: Australian Design History
DDES1290.description: This course aims to develop your understanding, critical and aesthetic awareness of the history, cultural and philosophical stances that underpin a variety of Australian design objects and images.
DDES1290.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES2100.description: This course is an agile, industry focussed project that provides a platform for collaboration across real-world industry and stakeholder project possibilities.
DDES2100.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES2101.title: Design Studio 4 - Interdisciplinary Project
DDES2101.description: This is a culminating design course that encourages you to draw together insights and expertise from two or more specialisations from within the Design program.
DDES2101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

DDES2102.description: This course will help you develop essential skills to transition into the rapidly changing design industry through the principles of professionalism and a commercial grounding in the realities and complexities of design practice.
DDES2102.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture
