LAWS3523.description: How do you copyright your novel? Do you own your invention (or does your employer/university)? How do you patent your invention? Is internet file-sharing legal? Is it legal to buy a counterfeit DVD? What about a fake designer handbag? Do you still own your photos if you post them on social networking sites?  This course introduces core areas of intellectual property law such as copyright, trademarks, patents and designs law, covering foundational legal principles from a practical perspective.
LAWS3523.school: School of Private and Commercial Law

LAWS3524.title: Indigenous Women and the Law
LAWS3524.description: This course, will focus on the historical and contemporary place and experience of Indigenous women within and beyond the constructs of law and society.
LAWS3524.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

LAWS3532.title: Cyberspace Law 2.0
LAWS3532.description: This course will focus on the regulation of the online world and its social and cultural expression, and will explore these ideas from the viewpoint of users, community members, creators, citizens and consumers, particularly those engaging with Social Media and other ‘user generated content’ services.
LAWS3532.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

LAWS3541.title: Pacific Islands Laws (USP)
LAWS3541.description: An introduction to the merging legal systems of the Pacific Islands states, including issues of constitutional development, the recognition and application of customary law, modern and traditional legal institutions, land tenure regimes, personal law, and the legal recognition of economic activity, such as international trade, foreign investments and national resources projects.
LAWS3541.school: School of Global and Public Law

LAWS3549.title: Child Rights Comparative Clinical Program: India
LAWS3549.description: This course is offered as part of a partnership between UNSW Law and VM Salgaocar College of Law.
LAWS3549.school: School of Global and Public Law

LAWS3555.title: UNSW Law Internships
LAWS3555.description: This course affords students the opportunity to work in a host organisation which undertakes advocacy or research on aspects of policy and practice relating to an area of law.
LAWS3555.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

LAWS3589.title: Class Actions and Mega-Litigation
LAWS3589.description: Civil litigation is more frequently giving rise to cases that are  labelled "mega-litigation", "heavy and complex" or "supercase".
LAWS3589.school: School of Private and Commercial Law

LAWS3600.title: Housing Clinic (Redfern Legal Centre) Intensive
LAWS3600.description: The Housing Clinic (Redfern Legal Centre (Intensive) is an experiential learning program.

LAWS3623.title: The Criminal Trial
LAWS3623.description: The Criminal Trial is a course that grounds the study of the criminal trial by contextualising the impact of the law of evidence and advocacy practice while building on students' basic knowledge of the doctrine, principles and rules relating to criminal litigation.
LAWS3623.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

LAWS3713.title: Indigenous Peoples in International Law
LAWS3713.description: The past three decades have seen the worlds more than 300 million indigenous people make significant advances in international law with the recognition of Indigenous rights through current and newly established mechanisms that advance the development of norms relating to Indigenous rights.
LAWS3713.school: School of Global and Public Law

LAWS3751.title: Business Taxation
LAWS3751.description: The complexity and comprehensiveness of the Australian taxation system demands that tax considerations must be taken into account in most business decisions.
LAWS3751.school: School of Private and Commercial Law

LAWS3758.title: Roman Law
LAWS3758.description: The law of Ancient Rome is examined so as to illustrate the following: (a) how laws emerged to meet the needs of a developing society, (b) how law reform in the more developed stages of that society adapted to changing social, political and economic conditions, (c) aspects of Roman Law which are especially meaningful to students who are being trained in a Common Law system, (d) Roman law concepts which form the basis of modern Civil Law systems and today play a key role in the European Economic Community.
LAWS3758.school: School of Global and Public Law

LAWS3789.title: Policing
LAWS3789.description: Focuses on policing as a set of social and legal practices and  institutions, including beyond the public police.
LAWS3789.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

LAWS3812.title: Sport and the Law
LAWS3812.description: Sport is a central part of modern Australian society and culture.
LAWS3812.school: School of Private and Commercial Law

LAWS3901.title: Honours Research Thesis
LAWS3901.description: The course is designed for LLB (Honours) students and permits the learner to undertake a research project on a legal topic of his or her choice.
LAWS3901.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

LAWS9801.title: Aspects of Environmental Policy and Law
LAWS9801.description: The course is a postgraduate elective.
LAWS9801.school: School of Law, Society and Criminology

MANF3100.title: Product and Manufacturing Design
MANF3100.description: This course focuses on making certain that a design, whether mechanical, mechatronic or aerospace, can also be successfully manufactured, from a quality as well as cost perspective.
MANF3100.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF3510.title: Process Technology and Automation
MANF3510.description: This course focuses on manufacturing technology, including material removal, joining, additive and finishing processes and their characteristics, as well as the main building blocks of industrial automation including materials handling technologies and actuation technologies such as pneumatics, electric motors, solenoids, switches, programmable logic controllers, CNC technology and industrial robotics.
MANF3510.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF3610.title: Manufacturing Operations
MANF3610.description: Principles and techniques of operations research as well as an appreciation of the applications and computations in the field; principles of linear programming; the transportation algorithm; network models including critical path method (CPM) algorithm; deterministic dynamic programming; basic queuing theory and stochastic processes.
MANF3610.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF4020.title: Manufacturing Systems
MANF4020.description: Students will work in project teams to perform design and analysis of selected functions of manufacturing systems in collaboration with a manufacturing company.
MANF4020.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF4100.title: Design and Analysis of Product-Process Systems
MANF4100.description: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MANF3100 and MANF3510.
MANF4100.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF4430.title: Reliability and Maintenance Engineering
MANF4430.description: The course will introduce statistics, mathematics and associated techniques for analyzing an industrial process for the purpose of maintaining and improving it.
MANF4430.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF4611.title: Process Modelling and Simulation
MANF4611.description: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MATH2089.
MANF4611.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MANF6860.title: Strategic Manufacturing Management
MANF6860.description: This course focuses on the links between both  manufacturing strategies as well as operational performance  and  effective supply chain strategies for companies that operate globally with emphasis on how to plan and integrate supply chain components into a coordinated system.
MANF6860.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MARK1012.title: Marketing Fundamentals
MARK1012.description: In today's business world, marketing is viewed as central to creating and delivering value both to the organisation and to the customer.

MARK2051.title: Consumer Behaviour
MARK2051.description: The need for marketers to understand why consumers act as they do in the marketplace is the crux of this subject.

MARK2052.title: Marketing Research
MARK2052.description: Qualitative market research is addressed in this course.

MARK2053.title: Marketing Communications and Promotions Management
MARK2053.description: The aim is to offer insights into the various decisions and principles that marketing managers have to consider when developing an overall communications and promotions strategy.

MARK2060.title: Event Management and Marketing
MARK2060.description: Today events are central to our culture as perhaps never before.

MARK2071.title: International and Global Marketing
MARK2071.description: The purpose of this course is to develop a thorough appreciation of the international aspects of contemporary marketing.

MARK2085.title: Consumer Centric Innovation
MARK2085.description: Innovation is critical for organisational growth, and adding value to the firm and its stakeholders.

MARK2101.title: Industry Placement 1
MARK2101.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the fundamental principles of marketing in an industry environment.

MARK2999.title: Internship 1
MARK2999.description:
Please Note: Co-op students are not liable for tuition fee charges for this course
Students consider the practical application of the fundamental principles of marketing in an industry environment.

MARK3054.title: Marketing Analytics and Big Data
MARK3054.description: MARK3054 helps students to understand the use of analytical tools in marketing, and develop students’ capabilities of using analytical tools to address marketing problems – key skills that numerous companies have stated they look for in marketers, particularly in challenging business environments.

MARK3081.title: Distribution Strategy and Retail Channels
MARK3081.description: This course presents an integrated approach to distribution strategy and retail channel management.

MARK3082.title: Strategic Marketing
MARK3082.description: Strategic Marketing Management is a capstone course that ‘pulls together’ what has been learned in earlier marketing courses and introduces marketing decision making and planning frameworks in the global environment: exploring strategy options; opportunity analysis; strategy setting and implementation.

MARK3085.title: Digital Marketing and Web Analytics
MARK3085.description: This course explores the impact of the Internet, digital and social media, and emerging technological innovations on the marketing of goods and services.

MARK3087.title: Customer Analytics
MARK3087.description: The constantly increasing availability of customer data offers great opportunities to gain manageable insights for attracting new customers and developing and maintaining relationships with existing customers.

MARK3090.title: Marketing Decision Analysis
MARK3090.description: The intention of the course offered is to focus on the concepts learned in marketing analyses classes to synthesize strategies based on consultant outputs.

MARK3091.title: New Product and New Service Development
MARK3091.description: Developing and introducing new products and new services is an important business function for many organisations.

MARK3092.title: Brand Management
MARK3092.description: Brands are strategic assets that can provide firms with long-lasting competitive advantage.

MARK3202.title: Industry Placement 2
MARK3202.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the fundamental principles of marketing in an industry environment.

MARK3303.title: Industry Placement 3
MARK3303.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the fundamental principles of marketing in an industry environment.

MARK3999.title: Internship 2
MARK3999.description:
Please Note: Co-op students are not liable for tuition fee charges for this course
Students consider the practical application of the fundamental principles of marketing in an industry environment.

MARK4210.title: Business Research Methods in Marketing
MARK4210.description: This course is a critical overview of selected methodological issues in academic research in marketing.

MARK4211.title: Research Seminar in Marketing
MARK4211.description: The study, analysis, and critique of a diverse range of marketing scholarship with a particular emphasis on theory and research in managerial and strategic marketing as well as marketing organisation, systems, and institutions.

MARK4212.title: Quantitative Methods and Models in Marketing
MARK4212.description: This course will extend the knowledge of elementary statistics into the area of multivariate statistics, with special attention to the underlying theory and assumptions of the methods used.

MARK4213.title: Contemporary Research Methods in Marketing
MARK4213.description: The Marketing discipline - its origin, development and future direction.

MARK4214.title: Seminar in Consumer Behaviour
MARK4214.description: This seminar focuses on psychological processes in consumer judgement, decision making, and behaviour.

MARK4300.title: Thesis (Marketing) A
MARK4300.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.

MARK4301.title: Thesis (Marketing) B
MARK4301.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.

MARK4302.title: Thesis (Marketing) C
MARK4302.description: Honours students complete a thesis under the direction of a supervisor.

MARK4999.title: Internship 3
MARK4999.description:
Please Note: Co-op students are not liable for tuition fees charges for this course
Students consider the practical application of the fundamental principles of marketing in an industry environment.

MATH1011.title: Fundamentals of Mathematics B
MATH1011.description: Functions (and their inverses), limits, asymptotes, continuity; differentiation and applications; integration, the definite integral and applications; inverse trigonometric functions; the logarithmic and exponential functions and applications; sequences and series; mathematical induction; the binomial theorem and applications; introduction to probability theory; introduction to 3-dimensional geometry; introduction to linear algebra.

MATH1031.title: Mathematics for Life Sciences
MATH1031.description: MATH1031 will provide you with a good knowledge of topics in Calculus and Linear Algebra and show applications in interdisciplinary contexts through lectures, videos and exercises.

MATH1041.title: Statistics for Life and Social Sciences

MATH1081.title: Discrete Mathematics
MATH1081.description: Role of proof in mathematics, logical reasoning and implication, different types of proofs.

MATH1099.title: Industrial Placement 1 (Co-Op)
MATH1099.description: This course provides scholars with a practical application of the fundamental principles of mathematics in an industry environment.

MATH1131.title: Mathematics 1A
MATH1131.description: Complex numbers, vectors and vector geometry, linear equations, matrices and matrix algebra, determinants.

MATH1141.title: Higher Mathematics 1A
MATH1141.description: As for MATH1131 but in greater depth.

MATH1151.title: Mathematics for Actuarial Studies and Finance 1A
MATH1151.description: Vectors and vector geometry, linear equations, matrices and matrix algebra, basic input-output linear models, determinants, least squares approximation, probability and statistics.

MATH1231.title: Mathematics 1B
MATH1231.description: Vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

MATH1241.title: Higher Mathematics 1B
MATH1241.description: Vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

MATH1251.title: Mathematics for Actuarial Studies and Finance 1B
MATH1251.description: Complex numbers, vector spaces, polynomial interpolation, linear transformations, Markov processes, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

MATH2011.title: Several Variable Calculus
MATH2011.description: Functions of several variables, limits and continuity, differentiability, gradients, surfaces, maxima and minima, Taylor series, Lagrange multipliers, chain rules, inverse function theorem, Jacobian derivatives.

MATH2018.title: Engineering Mathematics 2D
MATH2018.description: Partial differentiation and applications, vector algebra, double integrals, ordinary differential equations, introduction to vector field theory, extrema of functions of 2 variables, matrices and their applications, Laplace transforms, Fourier series, partial differential equations and their solution for selected physical problems.

MATH2019.title: Engineering Mathematics 2E
MATH2019.description: Partial differentiation and applications, vector algebra, double integrals, ordinary differential equations, introduction to vector field theory, extrema of functions of 2 variables, matrices and their applications, Laplace transforms, Fourier series, partial differential equations and their solution for selected physical problems.

MATH2069.title: Mathematics 2A
MATH2069.description: Several Variable Calculus:Vectors, differential calculus of curves in R3 and  surfaces, Taylor series for functions of two variables, critical points, local maxima and minima.

MATH2089.title: Numerical Methods and Statistics
MATH2089.description: This course gives an introduction to numerical methods and statistics essential in a wide range of engineering disciplines.

MATH2099.title: Mathematics 2B
MATH2099.description: Linear algebra: Vector spaces, linear transformations, change of basis, inner products, orthogonalization, least squares approximation, QR factorization, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, Jordan forms, matrix exponentials and applications to systems of differential equations, other applications of linear algebra.

MATH2111.title: Higher Several Variable Calculus
MATH2111.description: Functions of several variables, limits and continuity, differentiability, gradients, surfaces, maxima and minima, Taylor series, Lagrange multipliers, chain rules, inverse function theorem, Jacobian derivatives, double and triple integrals, iterated integrals, Riemann sums, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, change of variables, centre of mass, curves in space, line integrals, parametrised surfaces, surface integrals, del, divergence and curl, Stokes' theorem, Green's theorem in the plane, applications to fluid dynamics and electrodynamics, orthogonal curvilinear coordinates, arc length and volume elements, gradient, divergence and curl in curvilinear coordinates.

MATH2121.title: Theory and Applications of Differential Equations
MATH2121.description: The following topics are treated both theoretically and with illustrative applications in physics, engineering and biology.

MATH2221.title: Higher Theory and Applications of Differential Equations
MATH2221.description: In first year you learnt how to solve first order ordinary differential equations and second order ordinary differential equations with constant coefficients.

MATH2241.title: Introduction to Atmosphere and Ocean Dynamics
MATH2241.description: An introduction to mathematical models for the circulation of the atmosphere and oceans.

MATH2301.title: Mathematical Computing
MATH2301.description: An introduction to mathematical computing, programming and visualization using Matlab, with a focus on mathematical modelling and simulation.

MATH2400.title: Finite Mathematics
MATH2400.description: This is an introduction to those areas of Mathematics which underpin parts of computing.

MATH2501.title: Linear Algebra
MATH2501.description: Linear algebra is a key tool in all of mathematics and its applications.

MATH2521.title: Complex Analysis
MATH2521.description: This is a first course in the theory and applications of complex functions.

MATH2601.title: Higher Linear Algebra
MATH2601.description: The course begins with a revision of vector spaces, linear transformations and change of basis.

MATH2621.title: Higher Complex Analysis
MATH2621.description: This is a first course in the theory and applications of complex functions, taught at the Higher level.

MATH2701.title: Abstract Algebra and Fundamental Analysis
MATH2701.description: Mathematics went through quite a revolution around the turn of the 20th century.

MATH2801.title: Theory of Statistics
MATH2801.description: Probability, random variables, standard distributions, bivariate distributions, transformations, central limit theorem, sampling distributions, point estimation, interval estimation, hypothesis testing.

MATH2831.title: Linear Models
MATH2831.description: Multiple linear regression models and examples.

MATH2859.title: Probability, Statistics and Information
MATH2859.description: Sample spaces, probability, random variables and probability distributions; examples of discrete and continuous distributions; Central Limit Theorem; statistical inference, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing; bivariate normal distribution, optimal mean square estimation, introduction to the multivariate normal distribution; linear regression and least squares estimation; inference in the linear model; on-line and off-line estimation; statistical quality control; models, applications and statistical algorithms relevant to the fields of computer, electrical, software and telecommunications engineering.

MATH2871.title: Data Management for Statistical Analysis
MATH2871.description: The course covers the use of database and spreadsheet tools to organise and query statistical data, programming in an advanced statistical package for file management, data manipulation and cleaning; methods for data screening, cleaning, graphical displays and data analysis using a range of statistical procedures; creation of data analysis reports using modern statistical and graphical methods.

MATH2901.title: Higher Theory of Statistics
MATH2901.description: As for MATH2801 but in greater depth:This course provides an introduction to the theoretical underpinning of statistics; it covers fundamental results from probability and distribution theory and shows how to apply the theory to the analysis of data.

MATH2931.title: Higher Linear Models
MATH2931.description: This course coveres multiple linear regression models and examples and graphical methods for regression analysis.

MATH3000.title: Mathematics/Statistics Project
MATH3000.description: This course enables the student to undertake an investigation into a specific area of mathematics and statistics under the supervision of a member of staff from the School of Mathematics & Statistics.

MATH3001.title: Mathematics/Statistics Project
MATH3001.description: This course enables the student to undertake an investigation into a specific area of mathematics and statistics under the supervision of a member of staff from the School of Mathematics & Statistics.

MATH3002.title: Mathematics/Statistics Project
MATH3002.description: This course enables the student to undertake an investigation into a specific area of mathematics and statistics under the supervision of a member of staff from the School of Mathematics & Statistics.

MATH3041.title: Mathematical Modelling for Real World Systems
MATH3041.description: Why are no two snowfakes alike? When will the next major stock market collapse occur? Which is the greatest sporting nation on earth? Addressing real world problems involves the steps of formulating a mathematical description of the problem, solving the mathematical model, interpreting the mathematical solution and critically evaluating the model.

MATH3101.title: Computational Mathematics for Science and Engineering
MATH3101.description: Partial differential equations (PDEs) provide a natural mathematical description for many phenomena of interest in science and engineering.

MATH3121.title: Mathematical Methods and Partial Differential Equations
MATH3121.description: This course builds on MATH2120 Mathematical Methods for Differential Equations in that it is concerned with ways of solving the (usually partial) differential equations that arise mainly in physical, biological and engineering applications.

MATH3161.title: Optimization
MATH3161.description: Optimization problems, in which one wants to find the values of variables to maximize or minimize an objective function subject to constraints on which variables are allowed, are common throughout the physical and biological sciences, economics, finance and engineering.

MATH3171.title: Linear and Discrete Optimization Modelling
MATH3171.description: Optimization is the mathematical problem of finding a decision to achieve the best possible outcome while satisfying certain restrictions.

MATH3201.title: Dynamical Systems and Chaos
MATH3201.description: A dynamical system is any system whose state changes as a function of time.

MATH3261.title: Fluids, Oceans and Climate
MATH3261.description: The mathematical modelling and theory of problems arising in the flow of fluids, the oceans and the global climate; Cartesian tensors, kinematics, mass conservation, vorticity, Navier-Stokes equation; topics from inviscid and viscous fluid flow, gas dynamics, sound waves, water waves.

MATH3311.title: Mathematical Computing for Finance
MATH3311.description: In the end, finance is concerned with making definite numerical recommendations which frequently can only be made by analysing sophisticated models using high-speed computers.

MATH3361.title: Stochastic Differential Equations: Theory, Applications, and Numerical Methods
MATH3361.description: Stochastic differential equation models play a prominent role in a range of application areas, including biology, chemistry, epidemiology, mechanics, microelectronics, economics, and finance.

MATH3411.title: Information, Codes and Ciphers
MATH3411.description: Discrete communication channels: information theory, compresssion and error control coding, cryptography.

MATH3511.title: Transformations, Groups and Geometry
MATH3511.description: Euclidean geometry, geometry of triangles, transformations, groups, symmetries, projective geometry.

MATH3521.title: Algebraic Techniques in Number Theory
MATH3521.description: The integers, residue class arithmetic, theorems of Lagrange, Fermat and Euler, groups of units, Chinese remainder theorem, primitive roots, Gaussian integers, division algorithm and principal ideals in Z[i], quadratic residues, algebraic number fields, extensions, Eisenstein's test, ruler and compass constructions.

MATH3531.title: Topology and Differential Geometry
MATH3531.description: This major theme of this course is the study of properties of curves and surfaces that are preserved under changes: differentiable changes in differential geometry and continuous changes intopology.

MATH3560.title: History of Mathematics
MATH3560.description: The development of mathematical ideas has often been very slow and at times tortuous, but nearly always interesting.

MATH3570.title: Foundations of Calculus
MATH3570.description: What does it mean for a limit to exist? What does it mean for a function to be continuous or differentiable? There are functions which are continuous everywhere but differentiable nowhere! Are there functions whose integral does not exist? In this course, we look again at the essential concepts of limit, continuity, differentiability and integrability and try to place them on a sure footing.

MATH3611.title: Higher Analysis
MATH3611.description: Limits and continuity are the central concepts of calculus in one and several variables.

MATH3701.title: Higher Topology and Differential Geometry
MATH3701.description: Topology and differential geometry both deal with the study of shape: topology  from a continuous and differential geometry from a differentiable  viewpoint.

MATH3711.title: Higher Algebra
MATH3711.description: In Higher Algebra we examine some of the basic notions of modern algebra that arose in the late 19th and early 20th century.

MATH3801.title: Probability and Stochastic Processes
MATH3801.description: Introduction to stochastic processes, that is, processes that evolve over time such as price fluctuations of a stock.

MATH3811.title: Statistical Inference
MATH3811.description: Coverage of the main parametric and non-parametric and techniques used in statistics.

MATH3821.title: Statistical Modelling and Computing
MATH3821.description: Introduction to flexible and modern approaches to statistical modelling and statistical computing.

MATH3831.title: Statistical Methods in Social and Market Research
MATH3831.description: In this course you will develop skills important for the design and analysis of research in the social sciences and in market research.

MATH3841.title: Statistical Analysis of Dependent Data
MATH3841.description: This course extends statistical modelling from independently distributed data to modelling dependence in observed data, and develops an understanding of basic distributions and models useful in practical situations.

MATH3851.title: Experimental Design and Categorical Data
MATH3851.description: This course focuses on the principles of good experimental design and the statistical tools appropriate for discrete valued data.

MATH3871.title: Bayesian Inference and Computation
MATH3871.description: After describing the fundamentals of Bayesian inference, this course will examine the specification of prior and posterior distributions, Bayesian decision theoretic concepts, the ideas behind Bayesian hypothesis tests, model choice and model averaging, and evaluate the  capabilities of several common model types, such as hierarchical and mixture models.

MATH3901.title: Higher Probability and Stochastic Processes
MATH3901.description: As for MATH3801 but in greater depth:Introduction to stochastic processes, that is, processes that evolve over time such as price fluctuations of a stock.

MATH3911.title: Higher Statistical Inference
MATH3911.description: As for MATH3811 but in greater depth.

MATH4001.title: Mathematics and Statistics Honours Thesis
MATH4001.description: This course, taken three times over three consecutive terms, forms the thesis component of the honours streams for applied mathematics, pure mathematics, physical oceanography, quantitative risk or statistics.

MATH4002.title: MathsStats Hons Thesis B
MATH4002.description: This course along with MATH4001 (MathsStats Hons Thesis A) form the thesis component of the honours streams for applied mathematics, pure mathematics, physical oceanography or statistics.

MATH4011.title: Quantitative Risk Thesis / Project A
MATH4011.description: Under the supervision of a member of the academic staff from the School of Mathematics and Statistics a student undertakes a major project in the area of Quantitative Risk.

MATH4012.title: Quantitative Risk Thesis / Project B
MATH4012.description: Under the supervision of a member of the academic staff from the School of Mathematics and Statistics a student undertakes a major project in the area of Quantitative Risk.

MATH4103.title: Applied Mathematics Honours (Full Time)
MATH4103.description: Skill in practical numerical computing is highly recommended for students taking this course.

MATH4603.title: Pure Mathematics Honours (Full Time)
MATH4603.description: Undergraduate thesis together with advanced lectures on topics chosen from the fields of current interest in Pure Mathematics.

MATH4604.title: Pure Mathematics Honours (Part Time)
MATH4604.description: Undergraduate thesis together with advanced lectures on topics chosen from the fields of current interest in Pure Mathematics.

MATH4903.title: Statistics Honours (Full Time)
MATH4903.description: Undergraduate thesis together with advanced lectures on topics chosen from the following fields: mathematical basis, experimental design, response surfaces, stochastic processes, theories of inference, sequential analysis, nonparametric methods, multivariate analysis, mathematical programming, information theory, discrete distributions.

MATH4904.title: Statistics Honours (Part Time)
MATH4904.description: Undergraduate thesis together with advanced lectures on topics chosen from the following fields: mathematical basis, experimental design, response surfaces, stochastic processes, theories of inference, sequential analysis, nonparametric methods, multivariate analysis, mathematical programming, information theory, discrete  distributions.

MATH6781.title: Biomathematics
MATH6781.description: Introduction to mathematical modelling and data analysis for biological and biomedical systems.

MATS1101.title: Engineering Materials and Chemistry
MATS1101.description: Materials Strand: Structure-property relationships of the main types of engineering materials (metals, ceramics, polymers and composites).

MATS1110.title: Introduction to Materials for Engineering Applications
MATS1110.description: This course introduces Engineering students to the field of Materials Science and Engineering.

MATS1192.title: Design and Application of Materials in Science and Engineering
MATS1192.description: The design of materials for applications in industry and society including, for example, metallurgical, electronic, medical, packaging and transport.

MATS2001.title: Physical Properties of Materials
MATS2001.description: -Modern atomic theory: shortfall of classical physics and an introduction to wave mechanics; many-electron atoms and the Pauli exclusion principle; zone and band theories.

MATS2003.title: Materials Characterisation
MATS2003.description: Introduction to crystallography: crystal symmetry, Bravais lattices and crystal structures; Miller and Miller-Bravais Indices.

MATS2004.title: Mechanical Behaviour of Materials
MATS2004.description: Stress-strain behaviour; atomic bonding and elastic modulus; dislocations and yielding; deformation behaviour of polymers; brittle fracture and Weibull modulus; creep.

MATS2005.title: Introduction to Fluid Flow and Heat Transfer
MATS2005.description: Fluid properties, Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluids; principles of fluid motion, mass and momentum balances; turbulent flow, dimensional analysis; mechanical energy balance, Bernoulli's equation; conduction and Fourier's law, steady-state conduction; forced and natural convection heat transfer; radiation, single body radiation, radiation exchange between objects.

MATS2006.title: Diffusion and Kinetics
MATS2006.description: Introduction to solid state diffusion, atomistics of diffusion, Fick's first and second laws; thin film solution and tracer diffusion measurements, semi-infinite and infinite diffusion couples - diffusion in a concentration gradient; temperature effects; surface, grain boundary and dislocation pipe diffusion; diffusion in ionic solids, interdiffusion and the Kirkendall effect, measurement of variable diffusion coefficients; thermodynamics vs.

MATS2007.title: Sustainable Materials Processing
MATS2007.description: This is a capstone course Topics would include: Problem solving methodology; environmental footprint - production, maintenance and end-of-life disposal; embodied energy; pollution and carbon estimation and accounting; life cycle analysis; energy recovery; carbon sequestration; pollution minimisation; sustainable materials and processing technologies.

MATS2008.title: Thermodynamics and Phase Equilibria
MATS2008.description: Thermodynamic functions and properties of materials (chemical, mechanical and magnetic systems); thermodynamic laws and their application to materials: chemical equilibrium, gas-solid equilibria, Ellingham diagrams; electrochemistry: Porbaix diagrams; thermodynamics of solutions; construction and interpretation of 2 component phase diagrams.

MATS3001.title: Micromechanisms of Mechanical Behaviour of Metals

MATS3002.title: Fundamentals of Ceramic Processing
MATS3002.description: Processing of ceramics and its relationship to structure, properties and performance of ceramic materials.

MATS3003.title: Engineering in Process Metallurgy
MATS3003.description: Basic mechanisms of heat, mass and fluid flow; fluid statics and fluid dynamics in metallurgy; macroscopic balance for isothermal systems; dimensional analysis and reactor design; heat and mass transfer through motionless media; heat and mass transfer in convective flow systems.

MATS3004.title: Polymer Science and Engineering 1
MATS3004.description:
The course is divided into 4 sections:
Polymer Chemistry and Synthesis: raw materials and synthesis of polymers; monomers, homopolymers, copolymers; basic organic chemistry and applied polymer chemistry; free radical polymerization, kinetics and mechanism; ionic and condensation polymerization, kinetics and mechanism.

MATS3005.title: Phase Transformations
MATS3005.description: Nucleation in the liquid and solid states; thermodynamics of phase transformations; solidification of pure metals and alloys; thermal supercooling; constitutional supercooling; interface stability; solute redistribution; glass formation; crystal growth techniques.

MATS3006.title: Design and Application of Materials in Science and Engineering 3
MATS3006.description: The purpose of this course is to provide students with the tools required for computational design and modelling for technological and professional materials engineering applications.

MATS3007.title: Materials Industry Management
MATS3007.description: Project Management: the stages of a project; planning; scheduling; personal dynamics; reporting; stakeholders; development of a project plan pertinent to the materials industry.

MATS4001.title: Secondary Processing of Metals
MATS4001.description: Solidification, welding (emphasis on effect of welding on microstructure, HAZ's etc), fundamentals of metal working (including hot working, Zener-Hollomon parameter, dynamic recovery and recrystallization and cold working including slip line field theory, slab and upper bound analyses, formability, residual stresses), powder metallurgy and sintering, machining, recrystallisation phenomena.

MATS4002.title: Design and Advanced Ceramics
MATS4002.description: Design with advanced ceramics for structural, thermal, electrical, piezoelectric, chemical, catalytic, and wear applications.

MATS4003.title: Process Metallurgy Advanced
MATS4003.description: Reaction rate and expressions for different reaction systems; kinetics and thermodynamics of metallurgical reactions; heat balance and mass balance of chemical reactors; batch and semibatch reactors; plug flow reactors (gas reactants in most metallurgical processes); mixed tank reactors (smelting, steel refining); catalytic reactions Heterogeneous reactions; fixed bed reactors (stack leaching processes); fluidised bed reactors (fluid bed roasting, alternative ironmaking technologies); moving bed reactors (blast furnace, Corex process).

MATS4004.title: Fracture Mechanics and Failure Analysis
MATS4004.description: Fracture mechanics, remnant life assessment, general practice in failure analysis, fractographic analysis, ductile and brittle fracture, fatigue, stress corrosion cracking, hydrogen embrittlement, fracture criteria in design, fracture toughness and fatigue testing.

MATS4005.title: Composites and Functional Materials

MATS4006.title: Polymer Science and Engineering 2
MATS4006.description:
The course is divided into four sections:
Advances in Polymer Synthesis: synthetic polymers/copolymers, biopolymers and blending routes to produce polymers with enhanced functionalities Polymer Physics and Bulk Properties: rheology: dilute, concentrated polymer solutions and melt polymers; rubber elasticity theory; gelation phenomena; elastic deformation and viscoelasticity; electric and optical properties; surfaces and interfaces; degradation modes of polymers Functional polymers: design and application of advanced polymers, including but not limited to polymers in optoelectronics, solar technology, and medicine.

MATS4007.title: Engineered Surfaces to Resist Corrosion and Wear

MFAC3503.title: Psychiatry
MFAC3503.description: OBJECTIVES: - be aware of the key symptoms and signs of the major psychiatric disorders; - be able to take a psychiatric history and conduct a mental state examination; - acquire those skills necessary to make relevant diagnoses and to implement those management strategies necessary for a doctor in general or non-psychiatric specialist practice; - be able to assess a patient's personailty, psychological adjustment, coping repertoires and social functioning; - appreciate the importance of psychological factors in the diagnosis and treatment of illness; - be aware of the appropriate sections of the Mental Health Act and Guardianship legislation, and so be able to refer patients appropriately to psychiatric facilities, where appropriate; - acquire basic knowledge in special areas of forensic psychiatry, child psychiatry, ethics, general practice psychiatry and liaison psychiatry; - be competent in prescribing psychotropic medication; - be able to use simple cognitive and behavioural techniques.

This course provides an insight into the strategies and organisational structures of companies from Asia (including the Japanese keiretsu, Korean Chaebol and Chinese state enterprises and family business); the internationalisation and growing global competitiveness of multinationals from this region; and the forms that entrepreneurship takes in different countries in Asia.

MGMT3728.description: Examines contemporary remuneration and performance management from both applied and theoretical perspectives, emphasising theories, practices and forces associated with the current trend away from traditional fixed, job-based pay to variable, person-based and performance-based remuneration.

MGMT3729.description: This course critically examines the theory and practice of learning and development.

MGMT3730.title: Human Resource Analytics
MGMT3730.description: The subject Human Resource Analytics provides students with the data analytics knowledge, skills, and competencies to effectively address HR issues in private, public, and not-for-profit organisations.

MGMT4101.description: This course is required by students undertaking BCom(Hons) program in International Business (IB) in the School of Management, and other research students according to their program requirements.

MGMT4104.description: This course is required by students undertaking BCom(Hons) program in Human Resource Management (HRM) in the School of Management, and other research students according to their program requirements.

MGMT4500.description: In this course, the student will conduct an independent piece of research which is empirical in nature (or consistent with conventional research modes in International Business).

MGMT4501.description: In this course, the student will conduct an independent piece of research which is empirical in nature (or consistent with conventional research modes in International Business).

In this course, the student will conduct an independent piece of research which is empirical in nature (or consistent with conventional research modes in Human Resource Management).

MGMT4739.description: In this course, the student will conduct an independent piece of research which is empirical in nature (or consistent with conventional research modes in Human Resource Management).

MGMT4750.description: In this course, the student will conduct an independent piece of research which is empirical in nature (or consistent with conventional research modes in Management).

MICR2011.title: Microbiology 1
MICR2011.description: Microscopic life pervades every aspect of our lives, influencing our health, diet, and environment.
MICR2011.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

MICR3061.title: Viruses and Disease
MICR3061.description: This course explores the biology of human and animal viruses and their unique properties that enable their persistence and spread.
MICR3061.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

MICR3071.title: Environmental Microbiology
MICR3071.description: The field of Environmental Microbiology offers great potential for the development of new and innovative strategies and products for the management and protection of the environment.
MICR3071.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

MICR3621.title: Microbial Genetics (Advanced)
MICR3621.description: This course is available to Advanced Science students, or as an advanced option for students in other UNSW programs.
MICR3621.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

MICR4013.title: Microbiology Honours Full-Time
MICR4013.description: Advanced training in selected areas of Microbiology and Immunology: a formal component consisting of seminars, tutorials, use of information science in biology and written assignments, plus a supervised research program in a specific area of microbiology or immunology.
MICR4013.school: School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences

MINE1010.title: Mineral Resources Engineering
MINE1010.description: This course includes an overview of the Australian minerals industry and the presence and development of mineral resources in Australia; the role of the mining engineer and career path options; awareness of major mineral types and distribution in Australia; basic mining concepts and systems, operations, equipment & services; an introduction to risk management and general issues of safety, health and wellbeing, including important issues for the safety of persons visiting or working at mining operations in remote or bushland areas.
MINE1010.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE2010.title: Mining Project Development
MINE2010.description: The course covers the life cycle of a mining project including the  various processes involved with the development and operation of a  mining project including exploration & geology, mine planning, mine  operations, minerals beneficiation and marketing.
MINE2010.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE2610.title: Mining Services
MINE2610.description: The aim of this course is two fold:The first half of the course aims to provide a broad overview of the surveying and spatial industry.
MINE2610.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE2810.title: Minerals and Processing
MINE2810.description: This is an introductory course in metallurgical processing, designed for students with no prior training in this area.
MINE2810.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3000.title: Research Elective
MINE3000.description: Assumed knowledge: Mining Systems, Socio-environmental Aspects of Mining, Resource Estimation and Mining Geomechanics.
MINE3000.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3220.title: Resource Estimation
MINE3220.description: Resource and reserve estimation of coal and metalliferous deposits.
MINE3220.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3230.title: Mine Planning
MINE3230.description: This course deals with the theoretical principles and practical methodologies associated with mine planning and project evaluation techniques.
MINE3230.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3310.title: Mining Geomechanics
MINE3310.description: This course aims to provide students with the basic knowledge required to undertake geotechnical investigations.
MINE3310.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3430.title: Mining Systems
MINE3430.description: This course presents a systems approach to the principles, design and application of the major surface and underground mining methods together with the associated equipment, services and infrastructure.
MINE3430.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3440.title: Surface Mining Systems
MINE3440.description: This is an advanced course building on the learning acquired in the Mining Systems course.
MINE3440.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3450.title: Underground Mining Systems
MINE3450.description: This course will provide a detailed understanding of advanced underground mining systems and technologies.
MINE3450.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3510.title: Mine Ventilation
MINE3510.description: This course details the attributes, knowledge, and techniques that are required to provide a safe underground working environment through sound ventilation practice.
MINE3510.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3630.title: Rock Breakage
MINE3630.description: This course covers the principal methods of rock breakage used in mining including machine mining, drilling and blasting.
MINE3630.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3800.title: Mineral Processing
MINE3800.description: Minerals Engineering is the link between mining and the utilisation of mineral resources, and is a key operation in the minerals industry.
MINE3800.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE3910.title: Socio-Environmental Aspects of Mining
MINE3910.description: This course provides a comprehensive and practical understanding of the impacts both positive and negative that mining may have on society and the environment.
MINE3910.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4250.title: Hardrock Mine Design and Feasibility Project
MINE4250.description: Development of a pre-feasibility study for a metalliferous mining project.
MINE4250.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4260.title: Coal Mine Design and Feasibility Project
MINE4260.description: In this course a potential coal project will be evaluated from the prospective of open cut and underground mining.
MINE4260.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4310.title: Mine Geotechnical Engineering
MINE4310.description: This course aims to provide students with the ability to apply soil and rock mechanics to the design of underground and surface mine excavations and associated infrastructure.
MINE4310.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4320.title: Advanced Geotechnical Engineering
MINE4320.description: This course aims to provide students with the advanced knowledge to apply soil and rock mechanics to the solution of complex underground and surface mining problems.
MINE4320.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4440.title: Mining Research Project I
MINE4440.description: This course is intended to develop the capability and requisite skills of an engineer to build a foundation of knowledge related to a particular industry-related problem.
MINE4440.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4450.title: Mining Research Project II
MINE4450.description: This course is intended to develop the capability and requisite skills of an engineer to build a foundation of knowledge related to a particular industry-related problem.
MINE4450.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4510.title: Advanced Mine Ventilation
MINE4510.description: This course is intended to develop the capability and requisite skills of an engineer to build a foundation of knowledge related to a ventilation problems and design issues with underground mines.
MINE4510.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4610.title: Mining Asset Management and Services
MINE4610.description: This course will enable the student to appreciate the economic importance of proactive maintenance and services management in mining operations and to develop skills in decision making in relation to effective management practices.
MINE4610.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4710.title: Mine Management
MINE4710.description: The course provides an appreciation of management principles and practices vital to a mine manager's successful running of a mining business.
MINE4710.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4820.title: Advanced Mineral Processing
MINE4820.description: The objective of this course is to provide mining engineering students a background in mineral processing with a focus on geometallurgy.
MINE4820.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4910.title: Mining in a Global Environment
MINE4910.description: This course provides students with the tools necessary to meet the challenges of working for mining companies as mining engineers and managers in an international (and/or remote Australian) setting.
MINE4910.school: School of Minerals & Energy Resources Engineering

MINE4951.title: Research Thesis A
MINE4951.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

MINE4952.title: Research Thesis B
MINE4952.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

MINE4953.title: Research Thesis C
MINE4953.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

MMAN1300.title: Engineering Mechanics
MMAN1300.description: This is the foundation engineering science course for all five plans in the School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, with content as follows: Revision of vectors, resultants and components, moments; The free body diagram; Equilibrium of planar rigid objects; Equilibrium of systems of co-planar multi-force members and planar trusses; Friction; Mass centre, centroids, distributed forces; Internal forces in beams; Introduction to 3-dimensional statics; Plane particle kinematics, including curvilinear and relative motion; Plane particle kinetics, including equations of motion, work-energy-power, friction, impulse-momentum, impact; Kinetics of systems of particles; Introduction to plane kinematics of rigid bodies, types of rigid body motion (translation, rotation about a fixed axis); Mass moment of inertia, parallel axis theorem, moment of inertia for various shapes, Introduction to plane kinetics of rigid bodies, rigid body in plane motion, equations of motion, work-energy for a rigid body.
MMAN1300.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN2100.title: Engineering Design 2
MMAN2100.description: This course focuses on the subject of engineering design, which plays the role in guiding an engineer or a team of engineers to think like a designer along a systemic, rational, and creative pathway, towards breakthrough innovations of new product/service.

MMAN2130.title: Design and Manufacturing
MMAN2130.description: This course introduces basic aspects of design and manufacturing, process selection, manufacturing processes, material selection based on material and physical properties and the use of computers in the design process.
MMAN2130.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN2300.title: Engineering Mechanics 2
MMAN2300.description: This course covers the practical application of engineering mechanics and mechanical vibrations.
MMAN2300.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN2400.title: Mechanics of Solids 1
MMAN2400.description: This is the fundamental engineering course for mechanical engineers, with content as follows: Stress, strain.

MMAN2600.title: Fluid Mechanics
MMAN2600.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN2700.title: Thermodynamics

MMAN3000.description: Professional Engineering and Communication is a subject designed to expose and involve students in a wide variety of topics and tasks which will be of lasting use going into Industrial Training, the final year thesis, and beyond that, a career in engineering.
MMAN3000.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN3200.title: Linear Systems and Control

MMAN3200.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN3400.title: Mechanics of Solids 2
MMAN3400.description: Membrane stresses in axisymmetric shells, simple bending, bending of composite and reinforced concrete beams, principal and cross moments of area, unsymmetrical bending, transverse shear stresses in beams, shear centre, column buckling, theory of elasticity: compatibility - equilibrium - constitutive equations - plane stress/strain, st Venant's principal, application of theory of elasticity to axisymmetric problems, torsion of prismatic bars, Prandtl's membrane analogy, torsion of multiply connected thin-walled sections, deflection analysis based on the principle of virtual work, various modes of fracture, crack-tip stresses, stress intensity factor, fracture toughness, crack growth due to fatigue.
MMAN3400.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN4010.title: Thesis A
MMAN4010.description: This course is the first of two parts and is undertaken before MMAN4020 Thesis B.
MMAN4010.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN4200.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN4400.title: Engineering Management
MMAN4400.description: Manufacturing operations and competitiveness, concurrent product and process design, manufacturing processes and technologies, global supply chain, E-manufacturing, Just-in-time and lean manufacturing, enterprise resource planning, production and materials planning, statistical process control techniques, quality and project management.
MMAN4400.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN4410.title: Finite Element Methods
MMAN4410.description: The following assumed knowledge is expected for postgraduate students undertaking this course: MMAN2400.
MMAN4410.school: School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering

MMAN4951.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

MTRN4230.description: The course introduces students to the analysis and use of robot manipulators, by exposing them to the theoretical basis of robotics as well as their practical implementation.

MTRN9400.description: This course provides a mathematical introduction to the mechanics and control of robotic systems including robot manipulators, mobile ground robots and quadrotors.

MUSC1101.title: Music Reinvented
MUSC1101.description: Designed as an introduction to a wide range of musical styles, techniques and circumstances as well as methods of study in music.
MUSC1101.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC1101.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC1602.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC1603.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC1604.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC1707.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC1707.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC1708.description: In this practical course, you will develop your instrumental or vocal skills and gain experience in applying them through participation in workshops, masterclasses and ensembles.
MUSC1708.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC1708.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2111.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2113.description: This course offers students the opportunity to study the history of the relationship between music and film and to gain an understanding of the main historical developments surrounding the use of music in film.
MUSC2113.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2113.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2115.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2116.description: Music is part of the life of people everywhere, and as George Eliot once said, there is no feeling, except the extremes of fear and grief, that does not find relief in music.
MUSC2116.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2116.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2117.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2118.description: This course focuses on the study of Balinese gamelan music and its cultural context during a two-week field trip in Bali over the July mid-year recess.
MUSC2118.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2118.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2602.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2603.title: Materials and Structures of Music 4
MUSC2603.description: This core course extends the student’s knowledge of the materials, structures, and processes of tonal music to an advanced level via the study and application of harmonic and melodic practices in both advanced counterpoint, focusing partly on the study of the music of J.
MUSC2603.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2603.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2703.description:
Subject Area: Music Performance, Music Ensemble
In this practical course you will extend your advanced instrumental, vocal or composition skills with one-to-one support from a specialist tutor, and contextualise the application of those skills through participation in workshops, masterclasses and ensembles.
MUSC2703.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2703.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2801.title: Music Performance Styles and Interpretation
MUSC2801.description: This course develops specialised knowledge of a range of music styles including those derived from particular historical periods, genres and approaches to music interpretation.
MUSC2801.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2801.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2802.title: Music Studio Teaching

MUSC2802.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2802.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2803.description: This course provides an introduction to sound technology and its creative applications.
MUSC2803.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2803.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC2804.title: Music at the edge
MUSC2804.description: This course is about music at the edge of, for example: noise; violence; comprehensibility; sound; organization; politics; seeing; good taste; the mainstream.
MUSC2804.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC2804.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3104.title: Contemplating Jazz: History, Style, Reception
MUSC3104.description: Since its beginnings around a century ago, jazz has consistently enthused listeners with the inventiveness, expressiveness and virtuosity of its performers, and the variety of its styles.
MUSC3104.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3104.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3105.title: Psychology of Music
MUSC3105.description: This course asks questions about music cognition and behaviour: How do we perceive music? Why can an instrument sound musical? How do we respond to and process the sound? What happens when we are preparing and performing music? Why can performers become debilitatingly nervous? What is the relation between music, sex and cheesecake? Can music make you smarter, and what is the Mozart Effect? Why does that tune get stuck in my head? How old must a person be before they can hear and appreciate music? You will address these and related questions through examination of the music psychology literature, and the critical evaluation of your own musical attitudes, beliefs and behaviours.
MUSC3105.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3105.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3162.title: Twentieth Century Music
MUSC3162.description: Focuses on the major trends and developments in 20th century concert music through a study of technical processes in a wide range of listening examples.
MUSC3162.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3162.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3302.title: Musical Transformations: Orchestration, Arrangement, Transcription and Recomposition
MUSC3302.description: In this course you will learn some key methods of musical transformation.
MUSC3302.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3302.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3705.title: Performance Laboratory C
MUSC3705.description: The acquisition of highly developed collaborative and presentation skills is increasingly important in contemporary music making and thus relevant for the pre-professional training of all students in all majors of the BMus program.
MUSC3705.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3705.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3706.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3706.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3801.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3801.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3805.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3806.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3807.school: School of the Arts and Media
MUSC3807.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

MUSC3808.title: Becoming a Performer

This course is offered in two modes: either face to face (on campus) and fully online
The overall aim of this course is to enable students to develop their understanding of both public health policy and programs as a part of public health practice.

PHYS4143.description: Students will take two of the four lecture modules offered in general relativity; quantum field theory; astrophysics; and quantum matter, information and computing.

PHYS4146.description: Students in this course undertake a full year research project under the supervision of an academic in the School of Physics.

PHYS4200.description: In this course students will undertake a one-term research project supervised by an academic staff member in one of our research groups.

PHYS6143.title: Contemporary Physics A
PHYS6143.description: Students will take one of the four lecture modules offered in general relativity; quantum field theory; astrophysics; and quantum matter, information and computing.

PLAN0082.description: Please Note: Co-op students are not liable for tuition fee charges for this course.

PLAN1001.title: Introduction to Planning

PLAN1003.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

PLAN1004.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

PLAN2001.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

PLAN2002.title: Geographical Information Systems and Urban Informatics

PLAN2003.title: Urban Design

PSYC1062.description: The subject matter of this course covers theories and research regarding the science of self-optimisation (e.

PSYC4103.description: This course is compulsory for students undertaking honours in psychology.

Unit A: Introduction to the basic functions and properties of drilling fluids and cement slurries.

PTRL4951.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

PTRL4952.description: The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis.

SART1502.title: Drawing
SART1502.description: This course will enable students to develop a command of drawing as a visual arts discipline and to relate the art of drawing to other areas of creative endeavour.
SART1502.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART1641.title: Video Art
SART1641.description: These courses offer students the opportunity to gain an awareness of the nature and variety of experiences included in the television area, to appreciate the specific qualities and potential of the video and electronic media and to acquire the technical, intellectual and creative skills necessary for the creation of original video work.
SART1641.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2361.title: Advanced Etching
SART2361.description: This course allows students to develop the basic principles and techniques of intaglio printing, including etching, drypoint and engraving.
SART2361.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2400.title: Painting and Materiality
SART2400.description: Painting and Materiality facilitates an exploration of painting processes, materials and supports, in order to broaden your understanding of the language of painting and its possibilities.
SART2400.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2401.title: Painting and Technology
SART2401.description: This course encourages you to consider technology's relationship to the evolution of painting through both historical and contemporary contexts.
SART2401.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2403.title: Painting: Space, Time and Place
SART2403.description: In this course, you will explore the roles of spatiality, temporality and site in relation to representation in contemporary painting.
SART2403.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2404.title: Printmaking: Etching
SART2404.description: SART2404 Printmaking - Etching offers studio-based instruction in a range of etching techniques.
SART2404.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2405.title: Printmaking: Relief Printing
SART2405.description: SART2405 Printmaking: Relief Printing offers studio-based instruction in a range of relief printing and intaglio matrix based techniques.
SART2405.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2407.description: SART2407 Printmaking: Screenprinting offers studio-based instruction in screenprinting techniques to create images using hand drawn, photo-generated and colour separation methods.
SART2407.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2408.description: This course introduces you to the value of fieldwork conducted outside the studio in urban and natural environments to enrich the content of your practice.
SART2408.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2410.title: SPI: Mixed Methods
SART2410.description: This studio based course, SPI: Mixed Methods, begins with an exploration of articulated space, form and materiality to explore corporeal movement in stasis.
SART2410.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2411.title: Sculpture Performance & Installation: Space Content Action
SART2411.description: In this course, you will experiment with new methods of production, such as kinetic structures, digital technologies and their interface with innovative applications of traditional modes of production.
SART2411.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2412.title: Drawing: Materials and Construction
SART2412.description: Drawing: Materials and Construction invites you to explore various drawing methodologies as well as new and traditional processes of making drawing relating to contemporary aesthetics.

SART2413.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2415.title: Photographic Worlds: Interventions and Fictions
SART2415.description: At what point do worlds and photographs collide to confuse perception, fabricate logic or create social tension? In this course you will explore the nature of photographic vision and the staging of ideas through the lens of medium format photography.
SART2415.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2416.title: Photogram to Instagram

SART2417.title: Photography and Shaping Light
SART2417.description: Light can be the difference between materiality and immateriality – it's all in the way the shadows fall.
SART2417.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2501.title: Life Painting
SART2501.description: The aim of this course is to enable students to develop a command of painting as a visual arts discipline whilst consolidating and extending previously acquired painting skills and applying these to various aspects of life painting.
SART2501.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2828.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2829.title: Anatomy for Artists
SART2829.description: This course will provide an introduction to human anatomy primarily through the study of surface form and skeletal and muscular structures.
SART2829.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2836.title: Colour
SART2836.description: This course will investigate the theory and practice of colour as it applies to the discipline of painting.
SART2836.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2841.title: Electronic Technologies
SART2841.description: This is a workshop based course which aims to provide the student with skills in the application of low voltage electricity and electronics sculpture.
SART2841.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2842.title: Metal Casting
SART2842.description: This is a practical class for those students seeking skills in metal casting and mould making.
SART2842.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART2859.title: Abstraction for Drawing and Painting
SART2859.description: This course will assist students to develop and extend their awareness of concepts of abstraction.
SART2859.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3400.title: Painting in the Expanded Field
SART3400.description: Painting in the Expanded Field will encourage you to develop an individually conceived art practice that explores materials, processes, technologies and formats which can contribute to a broader understanding of painting as a discipline.
SART3400.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3401.title: Painting Futures Studio
SART3401.description: Painting Futures Studio will enable you to develop an individually conceived art practice that explores  speculative propositions and tests new ideas.
SART3401.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3402.title: Painting: Studio in Context
SART3402.description: This course allows you to concentrate on your major creative direction as an artist.
SART3402.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3403.description: Painting: Studio Practice requires you to undertake advanced research and experimentation with mediums and processes contextualised by contemporary painting practice and your individual research priorities.
SART3403.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3406.description: Printmaking: Media and the Message is a Level 3 course which furthers your awareness of the roles and diversity of the printmaking as a media of contemporary art practice.
SART3406.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3408.title: SPI: The Public Domain

SART3408.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3409.title: SPI: Self Initiated Work
SART3409.description: This studio based course teaches Sculpture, Performance, and Installation Art in all its cross disciplinary, cross cultural guises.

SART3411.description: The principal aim of this course, SPI: Studio Research, is to support the exploratory research underpinning your  production of a substantial body of experimental artworks for public exhibition.
SART3411.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3412.title: Experimental Drawing
SART3412.description: The ‘Experimental Drawing’ course is designed to introduce the experience of creatively exploring experimental materials, processes, methods and ideas in contemporary drawing practice.
SART3412.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3413.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

How can photography explore and inform our concepts of natural landscapes and urban environments? This course introduces you to the relationships between memory, place and the everyday through the photographic practices of site-specific research, archival exploration and storytelling.
SART3414.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3415.title: Photography: Independent Studies
SART3415.description: This course provides the opportunity for you to further advance and refine your research, methodologies, and practical skills into an emerging art practice.
SART3415.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3416.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3800.title: Professional Practice
SART3800.description: This course provides you with a range of skills that prepare you for working as an artist or culture maker.
SART3800.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SART3801.title: Special Projects - Studio

SART3801.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SCIF1004.title: Science and the Cinema

SCIF1111.description: SCIF1111 introduces students to the skills required by a professional in medical research.

SCIF1131.title: Introductory Skills for Science
SCIF1131.description: SCIF1131 provides the opportunity for students to become aware of and develop their professional capabilities.

SCIF2041.title: Research Internship A

SCIF2199.description: This course has been developed for students who find a work placement/internship (unpaid or paid) and would like to receive academic credit for the placement.

SCIF3041.title: Research Internship B
SCIF3041.description: Short theoretical or experimental research project, supervised by a member of academic staff.

SCIF3900.title: Sustainable Tourism in Regional Australia

SDES3414.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SDES3801.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SDES4205.title: Information Graphics: Design and Visualising Data

SDES4205.faculty: Faculty of Arts, Design and Architecture

SENG2021.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

SENG3011.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

SENG4920.title: Ethics and Management
SENG4920.description: This course develops a framework on which management and ethical issues can be developed.
SENG4920.school: School of Computer Science and Engineering

SERV9999.title: Tourism & Event Mgt: Sustaining the Attraction of Aust

SOCW3012.description: This course allows you to apply the theoretical and skills based learning in a practice setting.

SOCW3013.title: Social Work Practice Level 3 Placement B
SOCW3013.description: In this course you will apply the theoretical and skills based learning in a practice setting.

SOCW4003.description: You will study a specific method of social work practice in-depth.
